findingType.name: Suspected duplicated code
findingType.shortMessage: Duplicated code often causes problems in long-term maintenance, due to flaws being fixed in one copy, but not the other.
findingType.info:
This is often due to copy-and-paste programming, and it often causes problems in long-term maintenance, due to flaws being fixed in one copy, but not the other.

Consider refactoring this duplicated code into a single method.

findingType.name: Useless/vacuous call to EasyMock method
findingType.shortMessage: Useless/vacuous call to EasyMock method.
findingType.info:
This call doesn't pass any objects to the EasyMock method, so the call doesn't do anything.

EasyMock provides Mock Objects for interfaces in JUnit tests by generating them on the fly using Java's proxy mechanism. For more information please visit www.easymock.org.

findingType.name: Signature declares use of unhashable class in hashed construct
findingType.shortMessage: Signature declares use of unhashable class in hashed construct.
findingType.info: A method, field or class declares a generic signature where a non-hashable class is used in context where a hashable class is required. A class that declares an equals() method but inherits a hashCode() method from java.lang.Object is unhashable, since it doesn't fulfill the requirement that equal objects have equal hash codes.

findingType.name: Unchecked type in generic call
findingType.shortMessage: Unchecked type in a generic call. This could be a type mismatch that the compiler is not able to detect.
findingType.info:
This call to a generic collection method passes an argument of compile type Object where a specific type from the generic type parameters is expected. Thus, neither the standard Java type system nor static analysis can provide useful information on whether the object being passed as a parameter is of an appropriate type.

An example of this finding is shown in the code snippet below.

final Object o = "1";
Set<Integer> intSet = new HashSet<Integer>();
intSet.remove(o);

In this case the call to remove o from the set compiles because the remove() method takes an argument of type Object rather than of the generic type (for backwards compatibility). In this example the call to remove() can be safely deleted. In general, it is recommended to examine the finding and determine if it has identified a type mismatch that the compiler was not able to report.

findingType.name: Swing methods should be invoked in Swing thread
findingType.shortMessage: Certain Swing methods need to be invoked in the Swing event dispatch thread.
findingType.info:
(From JDC Tech Tips): The Swing methods show(), setVisible(), and pack() will create the associated peer for the frame. With the creation of the peer, the system creates the event dispatch thread. This makes things problematic because the event dispatch thread could be notifying listeners while pack and validate are still processing. This situation could result in two threads going through the Swing component-based GUI—it's a serious flaw that could result in deadlocks or other related threading issues. A pack call causes components to be realized. As they are being realized (that is, not necessarily visible), they could trigger listener notification on the event dispatch thread.

Recommendations for thread safety have changed slightly since this article was written. It is now recommended that you use invokeLater() to create the GUI on the event-dispatching thread, rather than constructing the GUI on the main thread. So the below code violates this recommendation.

import javax.swing.JButton;
import javax.swing.JFrame;

public class GUI extends JFrame {

  public GUI() {
    super("GUI");
    setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.DISPOSE_ON_CLOSE);
    final JButton button = new JButton("Hello, Swing!");
    add(button);
    pack();
  }

  public static void main(String[] args) {
    final GUI gui = new GUI();
    gui.setVisible(true);
 }
}

At issue is the construction of the Swing objects and the call to setVisible() in the main thread. The below code fixes the program by moving these actions onto the event dispatch thread using the invokeLater() method.

import javax.swing.JButton;
import javax.swing.JFrame;
import javax.swing.SwingUtilities;

public class GUI extends JFrame {

  public GUI() {
    super("GUI");
    setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.DISPOSE_ON_CLOSE);
    final JButton button = new JButton("Hello, Swing!");
    add(button);
    pack();
  }

  public static void main(String[] args) {
    SwingUtilities.invokeLater(new Runnable() {
      @Override public void run() {
        final GUI gui = new GUI();
        gui.setVisible(true);
      }
    });
  }
}

findingType.name: Caught infinite loop
findingType.shortMessage: An apparent infinite loop that doesn't seem to have a way to terminate.
findingType.info: This loop doesn't seem to have a way to terminate (other than by perhaps throwing an exception).

findingType.name: Caught infinite recursive loop
findingType.shortMessage: An apparent infinite recursive loop that could result in a stack overflow.
findingType.info: This method unconditionally invokes itself. This would seem to indicate an infinite recursive loop that will result in a stack overflow.

findingType.name: Container added to itself
findingType.shortMessage: A container is added to itself, computing its hash code could throw a StackOverflowException.
findingType.info: A container is added to itself. As a result, computing the hash code via hashCode() will throw a StackOverflowException.

findingType.name: Volatile reference to array
findingType.shortMessage: A volatile reference to an array doesn't treat the array elements as volatile. This could indicate a race condition.
findingType.info: This declares a volatile reference to an array, which might not be what you want. With a volatile reference to an array, reads and writes of the reference to the array are treated as volatile, but the array elements are non-volatile. To get volatile array elements, you will need to use one of the atomic array classes in java.util.concurrent (provided in Java 5.0).

findingType.name: Unsafe inheritance of the getResource method
findingType.shortMessage: Usage of the getResource method may be unsafe if class is extended.
findingType.info:
Calling this.getClass().getResource(...) could give results other than expected if this class is extended by a class in another package.

To prohibit extension of this class it can be declared to be final.

findingType.name: Synchronize and subsequent null check on the same field
findingType.shortMessage: Synchronize and subsequent null check on the same field could indicate that a NullPointerException may be thrown.
findingType.info:
This field is not likely to be null because it is currently synchronized on. If the field is null when it is synchronized then a NullPointerException will be thrown and the subsequent check would be pointless.

This finding might indicated a muddled design or a lack of understanding of Java semantics.

findingType.name: Creates empty Zip file entry
findingType.shortMessage: Creates an empty Zip file entry
findingType.info: The code calls putNextEntry(), immediately followed by a call to closeEntry(). This results in an empty ZipFile entry. The contents of the entry should be written to the ZipFile between the calls to putNextEntry() and closeEntry().

findingType.name: Creates empty Jar file entry
findingType.shortMessage: Creates an empty Jar file entry
findingType.info: The code calls putNextEntry(), immediately followed by a call to closeEntry(). This results in an empty JarFile entry. The contents of the entry should be written to the JarFile between the calls to putNextEntry() and closeEntry().

findingType.name: Avoid catching IllegalMonitorStateException
findingType.shortMessage: Dubious code that is catching IllegalMonitorStateException may be masking a design flaw in your code.
findingType.info:
IllegalMonitorStateException is generally only thrown in case of a design flaw in your code—calling wait or notify on an object you do not hold a lock on.

It is recommended that this catch be removed from your code and the design flaw fixed.

findingType.name: Avoid using float type for math operations
findingType.shortMessage: Method performs math using floating point precision, consider using double precision instead.
findingType.info:
The method performs math operations using floating point precision. Floating point precision is very imprecise. For example, 16777216.0f + 1.0f = 16777216.0f.

Consider using double precision math instead. To do this change float type variables to double type variables and avoid the f prefix on floating point constants.

findingType.name: Clone method must implement Cloneable
findingType.shortMessage: This class implements Cloneable but does not define or use clone method.
findingType.info:
This class implements the Cloneable interface but does not define or use the clone() method. A class that implements Cloneable is expected to provide a properly functioning public clone() method.

The method clone() should only be implemented if the class implements the Cloneable interface with the exception of a final method that only throws CloneNotSupportedException.

Overall it is considered bad practice to use the extralinguistic clone mechanism (reference Bloch's Effective Java (second edition) item 11). A copy constructor is one alternative approach.

public MyClass(MyClass o) { ... }

A copy factory is another alternative approach.

public static MyClass newInstance(MyClass o) { ... }

Either one of these alternatives is considered better practice in modern Java programs.

findingType.name: No super.clone() call in clone method
findingType.shortMessage: This non-final class defines a clone method that does not call super.clone().
findingType.info:
This non-final class defines a clone() method that does not call super.clone(). If this class, which we will call A, is extended by a subclass B, and the subclass B calls super.clone(), then it is likely that B's clone() method will return an object of type A, which violates the contract for clone().

If all clone() methods call super.clone(), then they are guaranteed to use Object.clone(), which always returns an object of the correct type.

Overall it is considered bad practice to use the extralinguistic clone mechanism (reference Bloch's Effective Java (second edition) item 11). A copy constructor is one alternative approach.

public MyClass(MyClass o) { ... }

A copy factory is another alternative approach.

public static MyClass newInstance(MyClass o) { ... }

Either one of these alternatives is considered better practice in modern Java programs.

findingType.name: Use of a future keyword as identifier
findingType.shortMessage: Use of an identifier that is a keyword in later versions of Java.
findingType.info: This identifier is a word that is reserved as a keyword in later versions of Java, and your code will need to be changed in order for it to compile in later versions of Java. It is recommended that you change this identifier as soon as possible.

findingType.name: Method might drop an exception
findingType.shortMessage: Method might drop an exception.
findingType.info: This method might drop an exception that may indicate a serious problem has occurred in the running program. In general, exceptions should be handled or reported in some way, or they should be thrown out of the method.

findingType.name: Method might ignore an exception
findingType.shortMessage: Method might ignore an exception.
findingType.info: This method might ignore an exception that my indicate a serious problem has occurred in the running program. In general, exceptions should be handled or reported in some way, or they should be thrown out of the method.

findingType.name: Method requires security permission check
findingType.shortMessage: Method is invoked that should be only be invoked inside a doPrivileged block.
findingType.info: This code invokes a method that requires a security permission check. If this code will be granted security permissions, but might be invoked by code that does not have security permissions, then the invocation needs to occur inside a doPrivileged block.

findingType.name: Classloader creation requires security permission check
findingType.shortMessage: Classloaders should only be created inside a doPrivileged block.
findingType.info: This code creates a classloader, which requires a security manager. If this code will be granted security permissions, but might be invoked by code that does not have security permissions, then the classloader creation needs to occur inside a doPrivileged block.

findingType.name: Field isn't final in an immutable class
findingType.shortMessage: Fields that are declared within an immutable class should be final.
findingType.info: This class is annotated with the net.jcip.annotations.Immutable annotation, and the rules for that annotation require that all fields are final. This class is in violation of those rules.

findingType.name: Thread passed where Runnable is expected
findingType.shortMessage: A Thread object has been passed as a parameter to a method where a Runnable is expected.
findingType.info:
A Thread object is passed as a parameter to a method where a Runnable is expected. This is unusual, and may indicate a logic error or cause unexpected behavior.

Consider changing the type of the object to not be a Thread.

findingType.name: Avoid collections of URLs
findingType.shortMessage: Maps and sets of URLs can be horrible performance hogs.
findingType.info: This method or field is or uses a Map or Set of URLs. Since both the equals and hashCode methods of URL perform domain name resolution, this can result in a big performance hit. See http://michaelscharf.blogspot.com/2006/11/javaneturlequals-and-hashcode-make.html for more information. Consider using java.net.URI instead.

findingType.name: Blocking methods on URL
findingType.shortMessage: The equals and hashCode methods of URL are blocking. This could result in a big performance hit.
findingType.info:
The equals and hashCode method of URL perform domain name resolution, this can result in a big performance hit. See Michael Scharf's Blog entry on this topic for more information.

Consider using java.net.URI instead. When using URI objects in your code it is straightforward to convert one to a URL object as shown in the code below. This might be necessary to use the object with some libraries and frameworks.

try {
  URI uri = new URI("http://www.surelogic.com");
  URL url = uri.toURL();
  assert uri.getHost().equals(url.getHost());
} catch (Exception e) {
  // handle URL and URI exceptions
}

findingType.name: Annotation is not visible to reflection
findingType.shortMessage: Can't use reflection to check for presence of annotation with default retention.
findingType.info:
Unless an annotation has itself been annotated with a @Retention other than the default of source-only retention, the annotation isn't retained in the classfile and can't be observed using reflection, i.e., using the isAnnotationPresent method.

The standard annotation @SuppressWarnings is not retained in the classfile, however @Deprecated is as shown in the code below.

@Documented
@Retention(RetentionPolicy.RUNTIME)
public @interface Deprecated {}

findingType.name: Avoid calling System.exit()
findingType.shortMessage: Calling System.exit() may make it difficult for your code to be invoked by other code.
findingType.info:
Invoking System.exit() shuts down the entire Java virtual machine. This should only been done when it is appropriate. Such calls make it hard or impossible for your code to be invoked by other code. Consider throwing a RuntimeException instead.

It is prohibited for any EJB to invoke this call and shutdown the container (reference section 21.1.2 of the EJB 3.0 Specification).

findingType.name: Avoid the dangerous runFinalizersOnExit() method
findingType.shortMessage: Calling dangerous method runFinalizersOnExit() could result in erratic behavior or deadlock.
findingType.info:
Never call System.runFinalizersOnExit or Runtime.runFinalizersOnExit for any reason: they are among the most dangerous methods in the Java libraries. — Joshua Bloch (reference Bloch's Effective Java (second edition) item 7)

Calling runFinalizersOnExit is inherently unsafe. It may result in finalizers being called on live objects while other threads are concurrently manipulating those objects, resulting in erratic behavior or deadlock.

Any Java program which depends upon finalizers, or a programmer who thinks of them as similar to C++ destructors, is headed for serious trouble. Work to avoid the use of finalizers in your code for non-memory resources. In Java, try-finally blocks should be used for this purpose.

findingType.name: Use of inefficient String constructor
findingType.shortMessage: Use of String constructor wastes memory and is inefficient.
findingType.info:
Using the java.lang.String(String) constructor wastes memory because the object so constructed will be functionally indistinguishable from the String passed as a parameter. Just use the argument String directly. For example, new String("Hi") is replaced with "Hi" and new String(s) is replaced with s.

Avoid instantiating String objects; this is usually unnecessary.

Creating a new java.lang.String object using the no-argument constructor wastes memory because the object so created will be functionally indistinguishable from the empty string constant "" Java guarantees that identical string constants will be represented by the same String object. Therefore, you should just use the empty string constant directly.

findingType.name: Avoid calling toString() on a String
findingType.shortMessage: Method invokes the toString() method on a String.
findingType.info: Calling String.toString() is just a redundant operation. Just use the String directly. For example, s.toString() is replaced with s.

findingType.name: Avoid explicit garbage collection
findingType.shortMessage: Explicit garbage collection is being invoked which is extremely dubious except in benchmarking code.
findingType.info:
This code explicitly invokes garbage collection. Except for use in benchmarking, this is very dubious. It is recommended that these calls be removed from your program.

In the past, situations where people have explicitly invoked the garbage collector in routines such as close or finalize methods has led to huge performance black holes. Garbage collection can be expensive. Any situation that forces hundreds or thousands of garbage collections will bring the machine to a crawl.

findingType.name: Inefficient boolean constructor
findingType.shortMessage: Method invokes inefficient Boolean constructor; use Boolean.valueOf(...) instead.
findingType.info: Creating new instances of java.lang.Boolean wastes memory, since Boolean objects are immutable and there are only two useful values of this type. Use the Boolean.valueOf() method, Boolean.TRUE or Boolean.FALSE, or autoboxing if you are using Java 1.5 or above to create Boolean objects instead.

findingType.name: Inefficient number constructor
findingType.shortMessage: This code invokes inefficient number constructor. Use static valueOf instead.
findingType.info:
Using new Integer(int) (or any number constructor such as new Double(double)) is guaranteed to always result in a new object whereas Integer.valueOf(int) allows caching of values to be done by the compiler, class library, or JVM. Using of cached values avoids object allocation and the code will be faster.

For the integer numbers, values between -128 and 127 are guaranteed to have corresponding cached instances and using valueOf() is approximately 3.5 times faster than using the constructor. For values outside the constant range the performance of both styles is the same.

Unless the class must be compatible with JVMs predating Java 1.5, use either autoboxing or the valueOf() method when creating instances of Double, Float, Long, Integer, Short, Character, and Byte.

findingType.name: Use length() or isEmpty() to check if a String is empty
findingType.shortMessage: Method invokes inefficient String.equals(""); use String.length() == 0 instead.
findingType.info:
An object is compared to the empty String object using the equals() method here. Checking that the String object's length is zero may be faster, and removes String constants from the class file. Change s.equals("") or "".equals(s) to s.length() == 0

If you are using JDK 1.6 or above an isEmpty() method was added to the String class which will directly answer the query. Thus in the example above use s.isEmpty().

findingType.name: Use Locale parameterized versions of toUpperCase() and toLowerCase() methods
findingType.shortMessage: Consider using the Locale parameterized version of the invoked method.
findingType.info:
A String is being converted to upper or lowercase, using the platform's default encoding. This may result in improper conversions when used with international characters. Consider using the below versions instead.

String.toUpperCase(Locale)
String.toLowerCase(Locale)

One instance where this might be an issue is conversion of local insensitive strings. To obtain correct results for locale insensitive strings, use toUpperCase(Locale.ENGLISH).

findingType.name: Unboxed and coerced for ternary operator
findingType.shortMessage: A primitive value is unboxed and coerced for use with the ternary operator.
findingType.info:
A wrapped primitive value is unboxed and converted to another primitive type as part of the evaluation of a conditional ternary operator (the b ? e1 : e2 operator). The semantics of Java mandate that if e1 and e2 are wrapped numeric values, the values are unboxed and converted/coerced to their common type (e.g, if e1 is of type Integer and e2 is of type Float, then e1 is unboxed, converted to a floating point value, and boxed. See JLS Section 15.25.

This behavior can be unexpected and can be a source of subtle bugs.

findingType.name: Boxing immediately unboxed
findingType.shortMessage: A primitive value is boxed and then immediately unboxed.
findingType.info:
A primitive is boxed, and then immediately unboxed. This probably is due to a manual boxing in a place where an unboxed value is required, thus forcing the compiler to immediately undue the work of the boxing.

This change may improve program performance.

findingType.name: Boxing immediately unboxed to perform coercion
findingType.shortMessage: A primitive value is boxed then unboxed to perform primitive coercion.
findingType.info:
A primitive boxed value constructed and then immediately converted into a different primitive type (e.g., new Double(d).intValue()). Just perform direct primitive coercion (e.g., (int) d).

This change may improve program performance.

findingType.name: Boxed primitive used just to call toString()
findingType.shortMessage: Method allocates a boxed primitive just to call toString.
findingType.info:
A boxed primitive is allocated just to call toString(). It is more effective to just use the static form of toString on each wrapper type which takes the primitive value. So,

Replace...With this...
new Integer(1).toString()Integer.toString(1)
new Long(1).toString()Long.toString(1)
new Float(1.0).toString()Float.toString(1.0)
new Double(1.0).toString()Double.toString(1.0)
new Byte(1).toString()Byte.toString(1)
new Short(1).toString()Short.toString(1)
new Boolean(true).toString()Boolean.toString(true)

findingType.name: Avoid allocating an object to obtain the class object
findingType.shortMessage: Method allocates an object, only to get the class object. Use .class property of the class instead.
findingType.info:
This method allocates an object just to call getClass() on it, in order to retrieve the class object for it. It is simpler to just access the .class property of the class.

For example, change (new Foo()).getClass() to Foo.class.

findingType.name: Monitor wait() on a util concurrent Condition object
findingType.shortMessage: Monitor wait() called on a util concurrent Condition object, use await() instead.
findingType.info:
This method calls wait() on a java.util.concurrent.locks.Condition object. Waiting for a Condition should be done using one of the await() methods defined by the Condition interface.

This is highly confusing code that can lead to subtle concurrency bugs.

findingType.name: Random value from 0 and 1 is to coerced to int
findingType.shortMessage: A random value from 0 to 1 is coerced to the integer 0. This is probably not the desired behavior. Consider fixing with the Random.nextInt method.
findingType.info:
A random value from 0 to 1 is being coerced to the integer value 0. This is probably not the desired behavior.

You probably wanted to multiply the random value by something before coercing it to an integer. It is highly recommended that the nextInt method (of the Random class) be used for this purpose because it avoid several tricky implementation issues (for more information see its method documentation).

findingType.name: Use nextInt() not nextDouble() to generate a random integer
findingType.shortMessage: Use the nextInt() method of Random rather than nextDouble() to generate a random integer.
findingType.info:
If r is a java.util.Random object, you can generate a random number from 0 to n-1 using r.nextInt(n) Rather than using (int)(r.nextDouble() * n).

It is highly recommended that the nextInt method be used for this purpose because it avoid several tricky implementation issues (for more information see its method documentation).

findingType.name: Nonconstant String passed to execute() may be vulnerable to SQL injection
findingType.shortMessage: A Nonconstant string passed to execute() method on an SQL statement. This may be vulnerable to SQL injection.
findingType.info: The method invokes the execute method on an SQL statement with a String that seems to be dynamically generated. Consider using a prepared statement instead. It is more efficient and less vulnerable to SQL injection attacks.

findingType.name: Prepared statement generated from nonconstant String may be vulnerable to SQL injection
findingType.shortMessage: A prepared statement is generated from a nonconstant String. This may be vulnerable to SQL injection.
findingType.info: The code creates an SQL prepared statement from a nonconstant String. If unchecked, tainted data from a user is used in building this String, SQL injection could be used to make the prepared statement do something unexpected and undesirable.

findingType.name: Useless Thread
findingType.shortMessage: A thread was created using the default empty run() method. Delete this thread.
findingType.info: This method creates a thread without specifying a run method either by deriving from (i.e., subclassing) the Thread class, or by passing a Runnable object. This thread, then, does nothing but waste time.

findingType.name: Double-checked locking
findingType.shortMessage: Possible instance of double-check locking on a field.
findingType.info:
This method may contain an instance of double-checked locking. This idiom is not correct according to the semantics of the Java memory model.

For more detailed information on this problem and how to correct it, see the web page http://www.cs.umd.edu/~pugh/java/memoryModel/DoubleCheckedLocking.html as well as http://www.javaworld.com/javaworld/jw-02-2001/jw-0209-double.html .

findingType.name: Finalizer nulls fields
findingType.shortMessage: Finalizer nulls fields which does not aid garbage collection.
findingType.info:
This finalizer nulls out fields. This is usually an error, as it does not aid garbage collection, and the object is going to be garbage collected anyway.

It is recommended to try to remove all finalizers from your program.

findingType.name: Finalizer only nulls out fields
findingType.shortMessage: Finalizer only nulls out fields. This finalize method should be removed.
findingType.info:
This finalizer does nothing except null out fields. This is completely pointless, and requires that the object be garbage collected, finalized, and then garbage collected again. You should just remove the finalize method.

It is recommended to try to remove all finalizers from your program.

findingType.name: Finalize method should be protected
findingType.shortMessage: Finalizer method should be declared to be protected, not public. Other classes can call public methods. Change the visibility or remove it.
findingType.info:
A class's finalize() method should have protected access, not public.

If you override finalize(), make it protected. If you make it public, other classes may call it.

It is recommended to try to remove all finalizers from your program.

findingType.name: Empty finalizer block
findingType.shortMessage: Empty finalizer should be removed
findingType.info:
Empty finalize() methods are useless, so they should be deleted.

It is recommended to try to remove all finalizers from your program.

findingType.name: Finalizer nullifies superclass finalizer
findingType.shortMessage: Finalizer nullifies superclass finalizer. Consider removing this method.
findingType.info:
This empty finalize() method explicitly negates the effect of any finalizer defined by its superclass. Any finalizer actions defined for the superclass will not be performed. Unless this is intended, delete this method.

It is recommended to try to remove all finalizers from your program.

findingType.name: Finalize() only calls super.finalize()
findingType.shortMessage: Finalizer does nothing but call its superclass finalizer. Consider removing this method.
findingType.info:
The only thing this finalize() method does is call the superclass's finalize() method, making it redundant. Delete this method.

It is recommended to try to remove all finalizers from your program.

findingType.name: Finalize() does not call super.finalize()
findingType.shortMessage: Finalizer does not call the superclass finalizer as its last operation. Add a call to super.finalize() to this method.
findingType.info:
This finalize() method does not make a call to its superclass's finalize() method. So, any finalizer actions defined for the superclass will not be performed.

To fix this problem add a call to super.finalize(). Note that this method's last action should be the call to super.finalize().

It is recommended to try to remove all finalizers from your program.

findingType.name: Avoid calling finalize() explicitly
findingType.shortMessage: Explicit invocation of finalizer found. This is almost always a bug.
findingType.info:
This method contains an explicit invocation of the finalize() method on an object. Because finalizer methods are supposed to be executed once, and only by the VM, this is a bad idea.

If a connected set of objects becomes finalizable, then the VM will invoke the finalize() method on all the finalizable objects, possibly at the same time in different threads. Thus, it is a particularly bad idea, in the finalize() method for a class X, to invoke finalize() on objects referenced by X, because they may already be getting finalized in a separate thread.

It is recommended to try to remove all finalizers from your program.

findingType.name: Don't define equals() for enum
findingType.shortMessage: Covariant equals() method defined for enum. This is a bad practice.
findingType.info: This class defines an enumeration, and equality on enumerations are defined using object identity. Defining a covariant equals method for an enumeration value is exceptionally bad practice, since it would likely result in having two different enumeration values that compare as equals using the covariant enum method, and as not equal when compared normally. Don't do it.

findingType.name: Equals() defined that does not override Object.equals
findingType.shortMessage: Covariant equals() method defined, Object.equals(Object) inherited.
findingType.info:
This class defines a covariant version of the equals() method, but inherits the normal equals(Object) method defined in the base java.lang.Object class. The class probably intended to define a non-covariant version of equals() and use the @Override tag if using JDK 1.5 or above as shown in the code below. In addition, to correctly override the equals method in java.lang.Object, the parameter must have the type java.lang.Object.

@Override public boolean equals(Object obj) {
  // implementation (don't forget to override hashCode as well!)
}

If this was not the intent of the class, then the method should be renamed something other than equals to avoid confusion.

findingType.name: Equals() override is not symmetric
findingType.shortMessage: Method overrides equals() in superclass and may not be symmetric.
findingType.info:
This class defines an equals method that overrides an equals method in a superclass. Both equals methods methods use instanceof in the determination of whether two objects are equals. This is fraught with peril, since it is important that the equals method is symmetrical (in other words, a.equals(b) == b.equals(a)). If B is a subtype of A, and A's equals method checks that the argument is an instanceof A, and B's equals method checks that the argument is an instanceof B, it is quite likely that the equivalence relation defined by these methods is not symmetric.

See Bloch's Effective Java (second edition) item 8 for (much) more information.

findingType.name: Huge shared string constant
findingType.shortMessage: Huge string constants are duplicated across multiple class files.
findingType.info:
A large String constant is duplicated across multiple class files. This is likely because a final field is initialized to a String constant, and the Java language mandates that all references to a final field from other classes be inlined into that classfile.

See JDK bug 6447475 for a description of an occurrence of this bug in the JDK and how resolving it reduced the size of the JDK by 1 megabyte.

findingType.name: Argument might be null
findingType.shortMessage: Method does not check for a null argument.
findingType.info: A parameter to this method has been identified as a value that should always be checked to see whether or not it is null, but it is being dereferenced without a preceding null check.

findingType.name: Equals() should handle null argument
findingType.shortMessage: This equals() method does not check for null argument. This contract violation should be fixed.
findingType.info: This implementation of equals(Object) violates the contract defined by java.lang.Object.equals() because it does not check for null being passed as the argument. By the defined contract, all equals() methods should return false if passed a null value.

findingType.name: Covariant compareTo() method
findingType.shortMessage: Covariant compareTo() method defined.
findingType.info:
This class defines a covariant version of compareTo(). To correctly implement (or override if an implementation is provided by a superclass) the compareTo() method in the Comparable interface, the parameter of compareTo() must have type java.lang.Object.

If this was not the intent of the class, then the method should be renamed something other than compareTo to avoid confusion.

findingType.name: Use of unhashable class
findingType.shortMessage: Use of class without a hashCode() method in a hashed data structure.
findingType.info: A class defines an equals(Object) method but not a hashCode() method, and thus doesn't fulfill the requirement that equal objects have equal hash codes. An instance of this class is used in a hash data structure, making the need to fix this problem of highest importance.

findingType.name: Defines hashCode() but inherits equals()
findingType.shortMessage: Class defines hashCode() but inherits equals().
findingType.info:
This class defines a hashCode() method but inherits its equals() method from java.lang.Object (which defines equality by comparing object references). Although this will probably satisfy the contract that equal objects must have equal hashcodes, it is probably not what was intended by overriding the hashCode() method. Overriding hashCode() typically implies that the object's identity is based on criteria more complicated than simple reference equality.

If you don't think instances of this class will ever be inserted into a HashMap/Hashtable, the recommended hashCode implementation to use is:

@Override public int hashCode() {
  assert false : "hashCode not designed";
  return 42; // any arbitrary constant will do
}

Note however, that some Java IDEs, such as Eclipse, will generate a reasonable equals and hashcode for you.

Override both public boolean Object.equals(Object other), and public int Object.hashCode(), or override neither. Even if you are inheriting a hashCode method from a parent class, consider implementing hashCode and explicitly delegating to your superclass.

For more information on this topic please reference items 8 and 9 of Bloch's Effective Java (second edition).

findingType.name: Defines compareTo() but uses Object.equals()
findingType.shortMessage: Class defines a compareTo(...) method but uses Object.equals().
findingType.info:
This class defines a compareTo(...) method but inherits its equals method from java.lang.Object. Generally, the compareTo method should return zero if and only if equals returns true. If this is violated, weird and unpredictable failures will occur in classes such as PriorityQueue. In Java 5 the remove method of PriorityQueue uses the compareTo method, while in Java 6 it uses the equals method.

From the Javadoc for the compareTo method in the Comparable interface:

It is strongly recommended, but not strictly required that (x.compareTo(y)==0) == (x.equals(y)). Generally speaking, any class that implements the Comparable interface and violates this condition should clearly indicate this fact. The recommended language is "Note: this class has a natural ordering that is inconsistent with equals."

For more information on this topic please reference item 12 of Bloch's Effective Java (second edition).

findingType.name: Defines equals() but inherits hashCode()
findingType.shortMessage: Class defines equals() but inherits hashCode().
findingType.info:
This class overrides equals(Object), but does not override hashCode(), and inherits the implementation of hashCode() from java.lang.Object. The implementation of hashCode in java.lang.Object returns the identity hash code, an arbitrary value assigned to the object by the VM). Therefore, the class is likely to violate the invariant that equal objects must have equal hashcodes.

If you don't think instances of this class will ever be inserted into a HashMap/Hashtable, the recommended hashCode implementation to use is:

@Override public int hashCode() {
  assert false : "hashCode not designed";
  return 42; // any arbitrary constant will do
}

Note however, that some Java IDEs, such as Eclipse, will generate a reasonable equals and hashcode for you.

Override both public boolean Object.equals(Object other), and public int Object.hashCode(), or override neither. Even if you are inheriting a hashCode method from a parent class, consider implementing hashCode and explicitly delegating to your superclass.

For more information on this topic please reference items 8 and 9 of Bloch's Effective Java (second edition).

findingType.name: Inherits equals() but uses hashCode()
findingType.shortMessage: Class inherits equals() but uses Object.hashCode().
findingType.info:
This class inherits equals(Object) from an abstract superclass, and hashCode() from java.lang.Object The implementation of hashCode in java.lang.Object returns the identity hash code, an arbitrary value assigned to the object by the VM). Therefore, the class is likely to violate the invariant that equal objects must have equal hashcodes.

If you don't think instances of this class will ever be inserted into a HashMap/Hashtable, the recommended hashCode implementation to use is:

public int hashCode() {
  assert false : "hashCode not designed";
  return 42; // any arbitrary constant will do
}

Note however, that some Java IDEs, such as Eclipse, will generate a reasonable equals and hashcode for you.

Override both public boolean Object.equals(Object other), and public int Object.hashCode(), or override neither. Even if you are inheriting a hashCode method from a parent class, consider implementing hashCode and explicitly delegating to your superclass.

For more information on this topic please reference items 8 and 9 of Bloch's Effective Java (second edition).

findingType.name: String comparison with == or !=
findingType.shortMessage: Suspicious comparison of String objects using == or !=.
findingType.info:
This code compares java.lang.String objects for reference equality using the == or != operators. Unless both strings are constants in a source file or have been interned using the String.intern() method, the same string value may be represented by two different String objects. In short, only very specialized code should use == or != operators on strings as this is unusual and can create subtle bugs in your code.

This is even worse if the string is a parameter. Requiring callers to pass only String constants or interned strings to a method is unnecessarily fragile, and rarely leads to measurable performance gains.

Consider using the equals(Object) method instead. For example, change s1 == s2 with s1.equals(s2) where you are sure that s1 is non-null.

If you are comparing a constant string to any other string always call equals on the constant as this avoids any possibility of a NullPointerException. For example, use "hello".equals(s1) rather than s1.equals("hello").

findingType.name: Annotated field is not guarded
findingType.shortMessage: Annotated field is not guarded against concurrent access.
findingType.info: This field is annotated with net.jcip.annotations.GuardedBy, but can be accessed in a way that seems to violate the annotation.

findingType.name: Inconsistent field synchronization
findingType.shortMessage: Inconsistent synchronization of fields. Possible race condition detected.
findingType.info:
The fields of this class appear to be accessed inconsistently with respect to synchronization. This bug report indicates that the bug pattern detector judged that

  1. The class contains a mix of locked and unlocked accesses,
  2. At least one locked access was performed by one of the class's own methods, and
  3. The number of unsynchronized field accesses (reads and writes) was no more than one third of all accesses, with writes being weighed twice as high as reads

A typical bug matching this bug pattern is forgetting to synchronize one of the methods in a class that is intended to be thread-safe.

Note that there are various sources of inaccuracy in this detector; for example, the detector cannot statically detect all situations in which a lock is held. Also, even when the detector is accurate in distinguishing locked versus unlocked accesses, the code in question may still be correct.

To address this issue you must determine what the programmer intended with respect to concurrency policy design intent and ensure that this class faithfully implements that intent.

findingType.name: Naked notify()
findingType.shortMessage: Naked notify(), no apparent change has been made to mutable object state.
findingType.info:
A call to notify() or notifyAll() was made without any (apparent) accompanying modification to mutable object state. In general, calling a notify method on a monitor is done because some condition another thread is waiting for has become true. However, for the condition to be meaningful, it must involve a heap object that is visible to both threads.

This bug does not necessarily indicate an error, since the change to mutable object state may have taken place in a method which then called the method containing the notification.

findingType.name: Exposing a mutable array
findingType.shortMessage: Public static method may expose internal representation by returning a mutable array.
findingType.info:
A public static method returns a reference to an array that is part of the static state of the class. Any code that calls this method can freely modify the underlying array. If the array is accessed by untrusted code, and unchecked changes to the mutable array would compromise security or other important properties, you will need to do something different.

One possible fix is to return a copy of the array.

findingType.name: Exposing a mutable object
findingType.shortMessage: May expose internal representation by returning a reference to a mutable object.
findingType.info:
Returning a reference to a mutable object value stored in one of the object's fields exposes the internal representation of the object. If instances are accessed by untrusted code, and unchecked changes to the mutable object would compromise security or other important properties, you will need to do something different.

Returning a new copy of the object is better approach in many situations.

findingType.name: Exposing a mutable object by reference
findingType.shortMessage: May expose internal representation by incorporating a reference to a mutable object.
findingType.info:
This code stores a reference to an externally mutable object into the internal representation of the object. If instances are accessed by untrusted code, and unchecked changes to the mutable object would compromise security or other important properties, you will need to do something different.

Storing a copy of the object is better approach in many situations.

findingType.name: Exposing mutable state via a static field
findingType.shortMessage: May expose internal static state by storing a mutable object into a static field.
findingType.info:
This code stores a reference to an externally mutable object into a static field. If unchecked changes to the mutable object would compromise security or other important properties, you will need to do something different.

Storing a copy of the object is better approach in many situations.

findingType.name: Invokes run() on a thread
findingType.shortMessage: Invokes run() on a thread, it is likely that this code intended to invoke start() instead.
findingType.info: This method explicitly invokes run() on an object. In general, classes implement the Runnable interface because they are going to have their run() method invoked in a new thread, in which case Thread.start() is the right method to call.

findingType.name: Spinning on a field read
findingType.shortMessage: This method spins in a loop which reads a field. This may be changed into an infinite loop by the compiler.
findingType.info:
This method spins in a loop which reads a field. The compiler may legally hoist the read out of the loop, turning the code into an infinite loop.

The class should be changed so it uses proper synchronization, likely including wait and notify calls. Also consider the use of the classes in java.util.concurrent and java.util.concurrent.atomic.

findingType.name: Dangerous use of non-short-circuit logic
findingType.shortMessage: Potentially dangerous use of non-short-circuit logic.
findingType.info:
This code seems to be using non-short-circuit logic, i.e., & or |, rather than short-circuit logic, i.e., && or ||. In addition, it seem possible that, depending on the value of the left hand side, you might not want to evaluate the right hand side (because it would have side effects, could cause an exception or could be expensive.

Non-short-circuit logic causes both sides of the expression to be evaluated even when the result can be inferred from knowing the left-hand side. This can be less efficient and can result in errors if the left-hand side guards cases when evaluating the right-hand side can generate an error.

It is considered best practice to use short-circuit logic in most expressions. Document exceptions in the code with clear reasons why the exception is required.

See the Java Language Specification for further details.

findingType.name: Questionable use of non-short-circuit logic
findingType.shortMessage: Questionable use of non-short-circuit logic.
findingType.info:
This code seems to be using non-short-circuit logic, i.e., & or |, rather than short-circuit logic, i.e., && or ||.

Non-short-circuit logic causes both sides of the expression to be evaluated even when the result can be inferred from knowing the left-hand side. This can be less efficient and can result in errors if the left-hand side guards cases when evaluating the right-hand side can generate an error.

It is considered best practice to use short-circuit logic in most expressions. Document exceptions in the code with clear reasons why the exception is required.

See the Java Language Specification for further details.

findingType.name: Two lock wait()
findingType.shortMessage: Wait with two locks held. Only one lock released by the wait.
findingType.info:
Waiting on a monitor while two locks are held may cause deadlock. Performing a wait only releases the lock on the object being waited on, not any other locks.

This not necessarily a bug, but is worth examining closely especially if there is also a warning about a two lock notify.

findingType.name: Two lock notify()
findingType.shortMessage: Notify with two locks held.
findingType.info:
The code calls notify() or notifyAll() while two locks are held. If this notification is intended to wake up a wait() that is holding the same locks, it may deadlock, since the wait will only give up one lock and the notify will be unable to get both locks, and thus the notify will not succeed.

If there is also a warning about a two lock wait, the probably of a bug is quite high.

findingType.name: Unconditional wait()
findingType.shortMessage: Unconditional wait could cause your code to hang
findingType.info: This method contains a call to java.lang.Object.wait() which is not guarded by conditional control flow. The code should verify that condition it intends to wait for is not already satisfied before calling wait. The reason for this is that when you invoke wait any previous notifications (i.e., those made in the past) will be ignored and your program could hang.

findingType.name: Uninitialized field read
findingType.shortMessage: Uninitialized read of a field within a constructor.
findingType.info: This constructor reads a field which has not yet been assigned a value. This issue is often caused when the programmer mistakenly uses the field instead of one of the constructor's parameters.

findingType.name: Synchronized setter unsynchronized getter
findingType.shortMessage: Unsynchronized get method with a corresponding synchronized set method. This may cause incorrect program behavior.
findingType.info:
This class contains similarly-named get and set methods where the set method is synchronized and the get method is not. This may result in incorrect behavior at runtime, as callers of the get method will not necessarily see a consistent state for the object. The get method should be made synchronized.

This situation is caused because of the Java Memory Model which requires that the program provide for reliable communication between threads as well as for mutual exclusion. See the Java Language Specification for further details. In addition, please reference Bloch's Effective Java item 66.

findingType.name: Initialization circularity
findingType.shortMessage: Initialization circularity between two classes should be removed.
findingType.info: A circularity was detected in the static initializers of the two classes referenced by the bug instance. Many kinds of unexpected behavior may arise from such circularity. It is recommended that this implementation be changed to avoid circularity.

findingType.name: Superclass uses subclass during initialization
findingType.shortMessage: Superclass uses subclass during initialization.
findingType.info:
During the initialization of a class, the class makes an active use of a subclass. That subclass will not yet be initialized at the time of this use. For example, in the following code, foo will be null.

public class CircularClassInitialization {

  static class InnerClassSingleton extends CircularClassInitialization {
    static InnerClassSingleton singleton = new InnerClassSingleton();
  }

  static CircularClassInitialization foo = InnerClassSingleton.singleton; // will be null
}

This finding probably indicates a muddled implementation or a misunderstanding of the details of how Java instantiates objects.

findingType.name: Next() must throw NoSuchElementException
findingType.shortMessage: The next() method implementation in this class should throw NoSuchElementException exception when there are no more elements to return.
findingType.info:
This class implements the java.util.Iterator interface. However, its next() method is not capable of throwing java.util.NoSuchElementException.

The next() method should be changed so it throws NoSuchElementException if is called when there are no more elements to return.

findingType.name: Synchronization on a shared constant
findingType.shortMessage: Synchronization on a shared constant could lead to deadlock.
findingType.info:
The code synchronizes on a shared primitive constant, such as an interned String.

private static String LOCK = "LOCK";
...
synchronized(LOCK) { ...}
...

Such constants an interned and shared across all other classes loaded by the JVM. Thus, this could is locking on something that other code might also be locking. This could result in very strange and hard to diagnose blocking and deadlock behavior.

For further information please see http://www.javalobby.org/java/forums/t96352.html and http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/JETTY-352.

findingType.name: Empty synchronized block
findingType.shortMessage: Empty synchronized block should be removed
findingType.info:
The code contains an empty synchronized block:

synchronized(o) {}

Empty synchronized blocks are far more subtle and hard to use correctly than most people recognize, and empty synchronized blocks are almost never a better solution than less contrived solutions, for example, use of the util concurrent library.

findingType.name: Synchronize on updated field
findingType.shortMessage: Method synchronizes on an updated field. This is likely to be incorrect.
findingType.info:
This method synchronizes on an object references from a mutable field. This is unlikely to have useful semantics, since different threads may be synchronizing on different objects.

Multiple threads must synchronize on the same object to allow shared data to be safely read and written. It is therefore recommended that all locks be final fields or this or a static class (e.g., MyClass.class).

findingType.name: Field should be out of interface and package protected
findingType.shortMessage: Field should should be moved out of an interface and made package protected to avoid malicious mutation.
findingType.info:
A final static field that is defined in an interface references a mutable object such as an array or Hashtable. This mutable object could be changed by malicious code or by accident from another package.

To solve this, the field needs to be moved to a class and made package protected to avoid this vulnerability.

findingType.name: Field should be final and package protected
findingType.shortMessage: Field should be both made both final and package protected to avoid malicious mutation.
findingType.info:
A mutable static field could be changed by malicious code or by accident from another package.

The field could be made package protected and/or made final to avoid this vulnerability.

findingType.name: Field should be final
findingType.shortMessage: Field is not final but it should be to avoid malicious mutation.
findingType.info:
A mutable static field could be changed by malicious code or by accident from another package.

The field should be made final to avoid this vulnerability.

findingType.name: Field should be packaged protected
findingType.shortMessage: Field should be made package protected to avoid malicious mutation.
findingType.info:
A mutable static field could be changed by malicious code or by accident.

The field could be made package protected to avoid this vulnerability.

findingType.name: Field is a mutable Hashtable
findingType.shortMessage: Field is a mutable Hashtable that may be accessible by malicious code.
findingType.info:
A final static field references a Hashtable and can be accessed by malicious code or by accident from another package. This code can freely modify the contents of the Hashtable.

It is recommended that you consider replacing this Hashtable with a Map implementation, such as HashMap.

findingType.name: Field is a mutable array
findingType.shortMessage: Field is a mutable array that may be accessible by malicious code.
findingType.info:
A final static field references an array and can be accessed by malicious code or by accident from another package. This code can freely modify the contents of the array.

Consider encapsulating this field by reducing its visibility.

findingType.name: Field cannot be final
findingType.shortMessage: Field isn't final and can't be protected from malicious code.
findingType.info:
A mutable static field could be changed by malicious code or by accident from another package. Unfortunately, the way the field is used doesn't allow any easy fix to this problem.

Consider encapsulating this field by reducing its visibility.

findingType.name: Ambiguous invocation of inherited or outer method
findingType.shortMessage: Ambiguous invocation of either an inherited or outer method.
findingType.info:
An inner class is invoking a method that could be resolved to either a inherited method or a method defined in an outer class. By the Java semantics, it will be resolved to invoke the inherited method, but this may not be want you intend.

If you really intend to invoke the inherited method, invoke it by invoking the method on super, for example, invoke super.foo(17), and thus it will be clear to other readers of your code that you want to invoke the inherited method, not the method in the outer class.

You may also want to consider renaming one or both of the methods to avoid the confusion altogether.

findingType.name: Class naming convention violation
findingType.shortMessage: Class names should start with an upper case letter.
findingType.info:
Class names should be nouns, in mixed case with the first letter of each internal word capitalized. Try to keep your class names simple and descriptive. Use whole words—avoid acronyms and abbreviations. Unless, of course, the abbreviation is much more widely used than the long form, such as URL or HTML, it is recommended that you use mixed case. For example, MyUrlClass or HttpServlet.

Class names should always begin with an upper case character.

For further information, please reference Bloch's Effective Java (second edition) item 56.

findingType.name: Method naming convention violation
findingType.shortMessage: Method names should start with an lower case letter.
findingType.info:
Methods should be verbs, in mixed case with the first letter lowercase, with the first letter of each internal word capitalized.

Method names should always begin with a lower case character, and should not contain underscores.

For further information, please reference Bloch's Effective Java (second edition) item 56.

findingType.name: Field naming convention violation
findingType.shortMessage: Field names should start with an lower case letter.
findingType.info:
Names of fields that are not final should be in mixed case with a lowercase first letter and the first letters of subsequent words capitalized.

Final variables that should be fully capitalized and non-final variables should not include underscores.

For further information, please reference Bloch's Effective Java (second edition) item 56.

findingType.name: Very confusing method names
findingType.shortMessage: Very confusing method names, consider renaming one or both methods.
findingType.info:
The referenced methods have names that differ only by capitalization or the packages of their parameters. This is very confusing because if the capitalization and parameter package names were identical then one of the methods would override the other.

Consider renaming one or both methods to clarify their differences.

findingType.name: Very confusing intentional method names
findingType.shortMessage: Very confusing (but intentional) method names, consider trying to eliminate one of them.
findingType.info:
The referenced methods have names that differ only by capitalization or the packages of their parameters. This is very confusing because if the capitalization were identical then one of the methods would override the other.

From the existence of other methods, it seems that the existence of both of these methods is intentional, but is sure is confusing. You should try hard to eliminate one of them, unless you are forced to have both due to frozen APIs.

findingType.name: Confusing method names
findingType.shortMessage: Confusing method names, consider renaming one or both methods.
findingType.info:
The referenced methods have names that differ only by capitalization.

Consider renaming one or both methods to clarify their differences.

findingType.name: Method versus constructor confusion
findingType.shortMessage: Apparent method versus constructor confusion. Was this method intended to be a constructor?
findingType.info:
This regular method has the same name as the class it is defined in. It is likely that this was intended to be a constructor.

If it was intended to be a constructor, remove the declaration of a void return value. If you had accidentally defined this method, realized the mistake, defined a proper constructor but can't get rid of this method due to backwards compatibility, deprecate the method.

findingType.name: Suspicious hashcode() method name
findingType.shortMessage: Class defines hashcode(); should it be hashCode()?
findingType.info:
This class defines a method called hashcode. This method does not override the hashCode method in java.lang.Object, which is probably what was intended.

The method name and return type are suspiciously close to hashCode, which may mean you are intending to override the hashCode method.

findingType.name: Suspicious tostring() method name
findingType.shortMessage: Class defines tostring(); should it be toString()?
findingType.info: This class defines a method called tostring. This method does not override the toString method in java.lang.Object, which is probably what was intended.

findingType.name: Suspicious equal() method name
findingType.shortMessage: Class defines equal(); should it be equals()?
findingType.info: This class defines a method equal(Object). This method does not override the equals(Object) method in java.lang.Object, which is probably what was intended.

findingType.name: Class not an exception
findingType.shortMessage: Class is not derived from an Exception, even though it is named as such.
findingType.info:
This class is not derived from another exception, but ends with Exception. This will be confusing to users of this class.

Consider renaming this class to clarify this code.

findingType.name: Read() return value not checked
findingType.shortMessage: Method ignores results of one of the variants of the java.io.InputStream read() method.
findingType.info:
This method ignores the return value of one of the variants of java.io.InputStream.read() which can return multiple bytes. If the return value is not checked, the caller will not be able to correctly handle the case where fewer bytes were read than the caller requested.

This is a particularly insidious kind of bug, because in many programs, reads from input streams usually do read the full amount of data requested, causing the program to fail only sporadically.

findingType.name: Skip() return value not checked
findingType.shortMessage: Method ignores results of one of the variants of the java.io.InputStream skip() method.
findingType.info:
This method ignores the return value of java.io.InputStream.skip() which can skip multiple bytes. If the return value is not checked, the caller will not be able to correctly handle the case where fewer bytes were skipped than the caller requested.

This is a particularly insidious kind of bug, because in many programs, skips from input streams usually do skip the full amount of data requested, causing the program to fail only sporadically. With Buffered streams, however, skip() will only skip data in the buffer, and will routinely fail to skip the requested number of bytes.

findingType.name: ReadResolve() method must declare a return type of Object
findingType.shortMessage: The readResolve() method must be declared with a return type of Object.
findingType.info: In order for the readResolve() method to be recognized by the serialization mechanism it must declare a return type of java.lang.Object.

findingType.name: Transient field in a non-serializable class
findingType.shortMessage: Transient field in a class that is not Serializable.
findingType.info:
The field is marked as transient, but the class isn't Serializable, so marking it as transient has absolutely no effect.

This may be leftover marking from a previous version of the code in which the class was transient, or it may indicate a misunderstanding of how serialization works.

findingType.name: Suspicious transient field
findingType.shortMessage: Transient field that isn't set by deserialization.
findingType.info: This class contains a field that is updated at multiple places in the class, thus it seems to be part of the state of the class. However, since the field is marked as transient and not set in readObject or readResolve, it will contain the default value in any deserialized instance of the class.

findingType.name: Serialization method must be private
findingType.shortMessage: Method must be declared to be private in order for serialization to work.
findingType.info: This class implements the Serializable interface, and defines a method for custom serialization/deserialization. But since that method isn't declared private, it will be silently ignored by the serialization/deserialization API.

findingType.name: No suitable constructor for externalization
findingType.shortMessage: Class is Externalizable but it doesn't define a void constructor so it will fail at runtime.
findingType.info: This class implements the Externalizable interface, but does not define a void constructor. When Externalizable objects are deserialized, they first need to be constructed by invoking the void constructor. Because this class does not have one, serialization and deserialization will fail at runtime.

findingType.name: No suitable constructor for serialization
findingType.shortMessage: Class is Serializable but its superclass doesn't define a void constructor so it will fail at runtime.
findingType.info: This class implements the Serializable interface and its superclass does not. When such an object is deserialized, the fields of the superclass need to be initialized by invoking the void constructor of the superclass. Since the superclass does not have one, serialization and deserialization will fail at runtime.

findingType.name: No serialVersionUID field defined for serialization
findingType.shortMessage: Class is Serializable, but it doesn't define a serialVersionUID field.
findingType.info:
This class implements the Serializable interface, but does not define a serialVersionUID field.

A change as simple as adding a reference to a .class object will add synthetic fields to the class, which will unfortunately change the implicit serialVersionUID. For example, adding a reference to String.class will generate a static field class$java$lang$String.

Also, different source code to bytecode compilers may use different naming conventions for synthetic variables generated for references to class objects or inner classes. To ensure interoperability of Serializable across versions, consider adding an explicit serialVersionUID field.

This field can be generated within some Java IDEs. For example the below serialVersionUID field was generated by Eclipse.

public final class FutureDatabaseException extends Exception {
  ...
  private static final long serialVersionUID = 6446502447505736644L;
}

findingType.name: Comparator should be Serializable
findingType.shortMessage: Comparator doesn't implement Serializable.
findingType.info:
This class implements the Comparator interface. You should consider whether or not it should also implement the Serializable interface. If a comparator is used to construct an ordered collection such as a TreeMap, then the TreeMap will be serializable only if the comparator is also serializable.

As most comparators have little or no state, making them serializable is generally easy and good defensive programming.

findingType.name: Switch fallthrough
findingType.shortMessage: Switch statement found where one case falls through to the next case. Did you forget a break or return?
findingType.info: This method contains a switch statement where one case branch will fall through to the next case. Usually you need to end this case with a break or return.

findingType.name: Dead store due to switch fallthrough
findingType.shortMessage: Dead store due to switch statement fallthrough. Did you forget a break or return?
findingType.info: A value stored in the previous switch case is overwritten here due to a switch fall through. It is likely that you forgot to put a break or return at the end of the previous case.

findingType.name: Suspicious writeObject() is the only synchronized method
findingType.shortMessage: Suspicious that the writeObject() method is synchronized but nothing else is.
findingType.info: This class has a writeObject() method which is synchronized; however, no other method of the class is synchronized. Check that the concurrency policy of this class is implemented correctly.

findingType.name: Suspicious synchronized readObject() method
findingType.shortMessage: Suspicious that the readObject() method is synchronized, it probably does not need to be.
findingType.info:
This serializable class defines a readObject() which is synchronized. By definition, an object created by deserialization is only reachable by one thread, and thus there is no need for readObject() to be synchronized.

If the readObject() method itself is causing the object to become visible to another thread, that is an example of very dubious coding style.

findingType.name: Non-static serialVersionUID field
findingType.shortMessage: The serialVersionUID field is not static, but it should be.
findingType.info:
This class defines a serialVersionUID field that is not static.

The field should be made static if it is intended to specify the version UID for purposes of serialization. If it is not intended for this purpose it should probably be renamed to avoid confusion.

findingType.name: Non-final serialVersionUID field
findingType.shortMessage: The serialVersionUID is not final, but it should be.
findingType.info:
This class defines a serialVersionUID field that is not final.

The field should be made final if it is intended to specify the version UID for purposes of serialization. If it is not intended for this purpose it should probably be renamed to avoid confusion.

findingType.name: Non-long serialVersionUID field
findingType.shortMessage: serialVersionUID is not of type long, but it should be.
findingType.info:
This class defines a serialVersionUID field that is not long.

The field should be made long if it is intended to specify the version UID for purposes of serialization. If it is not intended for this purpose it should probably be renamed to avoid confusion.

findingType.name: Bad field in a serializable class
findingType.shortMessage: Non-transient, non-serializable instance field in a serializable class. This class could fail at runtime.
findingType.info:
This Serializable class defines a non-primitive instance field which is neither transient, Serializable, or java.lang.Object, and does not appear to implement the Externalizable interface or the readObject() and writeObject() methods.

Objects of this class will not be deserialized correctly if a non-Serializable object is stored in this field. Consider fixing this implementation so that it can be statically checked.

findingType.name: Serializable inner class inside a non-serializable class
findingType.shortMessage: Non-serializable class has a serializable inner class. This class could fail at runtime.
findingType.info:
This Serializable class is an inner class of a non-serializable class. Thus, attempts to serialize it will also attempt to serialize the instance of the outer class with which it is associated, leading to a runtime error.

If possible, making the inner class a static inner class should solve the problem. Making the outer class serializable might also work, but that would mean serializing an instance of the inner class would always also serialize the instance of the outer class, which is often not what you really want.

findingType.name: Serializable inner class
findingType.shortMessage: Serializable inner class will also serialize the associated outer instance. Is this intended?
findingType.info:
This Serializable class is an inner class. Any attempt to serialize it will also serialize the associated outer instance. The outer instance is serializable, so this won't fail, but it might serialize a lot more data than intended.

If possible, declaring the inner class to be static might be what you want to do to avoid this issue.

findingType.name: Non-serializable value stored into a serializable field
findingType.shortMessage: Non-serializable value stored into instance field of a serializable class.
findingType.info: A non-serializable value is stored into a non-transient field of a serializable class. This may cause the class to fail at runtime when it is serialized.

findingType.name: Thread start() call in constructor
findingType.shortMessage: This constructor invokes Thread.start() which is highly dubious.
findingType.info:
The constructor starts a thread. This is likely to be wrong if the class is ever extended/subclassed, since the thread will be started before the subclass constructor is started. This practice can also cause subtle race conditions.

Consider moving the thread start into a separate method, such as an init method.

findingType.name: Should field be static
findingType.shortMessage: This field is initialized to a compile-time static value. Should this field be static?
findingType.info: This class contains an instance final field that is initialized to a compile-time static value. Consider making the field static.

findingType.name: Unused field
findingType.shortMessage: This field is never used.
findingType.info: This field is never used. Consider removing it from the class.

findingType.name: Unread field
findingType.shortMessage: This field is never read.
findingType.info: This field is never read. Consider removing it from the class.

findingType.name: Questionable for loop
findingType.shortMessage: Complicated, subtle or wrong increment in for loop.
findingType.info: Are you sure this for loop is incrementing the correct variable? It appears that another variable is being initialized and checked by the for loop.

findingType.name: Null-only field
findingType.shortMessage: This field is always null. Check for errors or remove the field if it is useless.
findingType.info: All writes to this field are the constant value null, and thus all reads of the field will return null. It is highly likely that there is something muddled about this code. Check for errors, or remove the field if it is useless.

findingType.name: Unwritten field
findingType.shortMessage: This field is never written to. All reads of it will return the default value. Is this intended?
findingType.info:
This field is never written to. All reads of it will return the default value. Check for errors (e.g., should this field have been initialized?), or remove it if it is useless.

If this field is an object reference, i.e., not of a primitive type, then it will be null and dereferencing it will throw a NullPointerException.

findingType.name: Write to a static from an instance method
findingType.shortMessage: Write to a static field from an instance method. Is this intended?
findingType.info: This instance method writes to a static field. This is tricky to get correct if multiple instances of this class are being manipulated, and generally bad practice. Also check that this write has not created a race condition.

findingType.name: Load of a known null value
findingType.shortMessage: The variable referenced at this point is known to be null. Is this a mistake?
findingType.info:
The variable referenced at this point is known to be null due to an earlier check against null. Although this is valid, it might be a mistake

Perhaps you intended to refer to a different variable, or perhaps the earlier check to see if the variable is null should have been a check to see if it was non-null.

findingType.name: Dereference of readLine() result
findingType.shortMessage: This code dereferences the result of a call to readLine(). This code may throw a NullPointerException.
findingType.info: The result of invoking readLine() is immediately dereferenced by this code. If there are no more lines of text to read, readLine() method will return null and dereferencing that will throw a NullPointerException.

findingType.name: Inner class should be static
findingType.shortMessage: This inner class should be declared to be static.
findingType.info:
This class is an inner class, but does not use its embedded reference to the object which created it. This reference makes instances of the inner class larger, and may keep the reference to the creator object alive longer than necessary. If possible, the class should be made static.

If the inner class is anonymous then it will need to be named to be declared to be static. This is because anonymous inner classes cannot be marked as static.

If a reference to the outer object is required during construction of the inner instance, the inner class will need to be refactored so as to pass a reference to the outer instance to the constructor for the inner class (after construction the outer instance reference should no longer be needed).

findingType.name: Field not initialized in constructor
findingType.shortMessage: This code reads a field that is not initialized in any constructor.
findingType.info:
This is a read of a field is never initialized within any constructor, and is therefore could be null after the object is initialized. If this field is dereferenced it could cause a NullPointerException to be thrown.

This might be a coding error, or else the class containing the field is written in a way that depends upon methods being called in some specific order (perhaps a little bit dodgy, but not necessarily wrong).

findingType.name: Wait() outside loop
findingType.shortMessage: This call to wait() is not in loop. Are you sure the condition waited for is true?
findingType.info: This method contains a call to java.lang.Object.wait() which is not in a loop. If the monitor is used for multiple conditions, the condition the caller intended to wait for might not be the one that actually occurred.

findingType.name: Await() outside loop
