findingType.shortMessage: This call to Condition.await() is not in a loop. Are you sure the condition waited for is true?
findingType.info: This method contains a call to java.util.concurrent.Condition.await() (or variants) which is not in a loop. If the object is used for multiple conditions, the condition the caller intended to wait for might not be the one that actually occurred.

findingType.name: Use notifyAll() not notify()
findingType.shortMessage: Consider using notifyAll() rather than notify().
findingType.info:
This method calls notify() rather than notifyAll(). Java monitors are often used for multiple conditions. Calling notify() only wakes up one thread, meaning that the thread woken up might not be the one waiting for the condition that the caller just satisfied.

The thread chosen is arbitrary (i.e., it is not the first thread that waited); thus it's usually safer to call notifyAll() instead.

findingType.name: Avoid check for positive indexOf()
findingType.shortMessage: Method checks to see if result of String.indexOf() is positive rather than negative.
findingType.info: The method invokes String.indexOf and checks to see if the result is positive or non-positive. It is much more typical to check to see if the result is negative or non-negative. The reason for this is that a result of 0 indicates that the substring occurs at the beginning of the String—not that it was not found. The result is positive only if the substring checked for occurs at some place other than at the beginning of the String.

findingType.name: Line read by readLine() ignored
findingType.shortMessage: Method discards the result of readLine() after checking if it is non-null. Is it intended to throw away the line just read?
findingType.info: The value returned by readLine() is discarded after checking to see if it is non-null. In almost all situations, if the result is non-null, you will want to use that non-null value because it represents the line that was read. Note that calling readLine again will give you a different line.

findingType.name: Immutable object return value ignored
findingType.shortMessage: This code ignores the return value of an immutable object. Is this a mistake?
findingType.info:
The return value of this method should be checked. One common cause of this warning is to invoke a method on an immutable object, thinking that it updates the object. For example, in the following code fragment,

String dateString = getHeaderField(name);
dateString.trim();

the programmer seems to be thinking that the trim() method will update the String referenced by dateString. But since Strings are immutable, the trim() function returns a new String value, which is being ignored here. The code should be corrected to: 

String dateString = getHeaderField(name);
dateString = dateString.trim();

findingType.name: Null dereference
findingType.shortMessage: A null pointer is dereferenced here which will throw a NullPointerException at runtime.
findingType.info: A null pointer is dereferenced here. This will lead to a NullPointerException being thrown when the code is executed.

findingType.name: Store into a @NonNull field
findingType.shortMessage: Store of a possible null value into field annotated with @NonNull.
findingType.info: A value that could be null is stored into a field that has been annotated @NonNull.

findingType.name: Null dereference on exceptional path
findingType.shortMessage: This code has a null pointer dereference on an exceptional path.
findingType.info:
A pointer which is null on an exception path is dereferenced here. This will lead to a NullPointerException being thrown when the code is executed. Note that because the analysis currently does not prune infeasible exception paths, this may be a false warning.

Also note that the analysis considers the default case of a switch statement to be an exception path, since the default case is often infeasible.

findingType.name: Null dereference on some path
findingType.shortMessage: This code may dereference a null pointer and throw a NullPointerException.
findingType.info: A reference value dereferenced here might be null at runtime. This may lead to a NullPointerException being thrown when the code is executed.

findingType.name: Null dereference on some path from return
findingType.shortMessage: This code may dereference a null pointer and throw a NullPointerException due to return value of a called method.
findingType.info:
A reference value which is null on some exception control path is dereferenced here. This may lead to a NullPointerException when the code is executed.

The value may be null because it was returned from a method which is known to return possibly-null values.

findingType.name: Null dereference of paramenter
findingType.shortMessage: A method call passes null for an unconditionally dereferenced parameter. This may result in a NullPointerException being thrown if this code is executed.
findingType.info: A possibly-null value is passed to a method which unconditionally dereferences it. This may result in a NullPointerException being thrown at runtime if this code is executed.

findingType.name: NonNull parameter violation
findingType.shortMessage: This method call passes null to a non-null parameter.
findingType.info: This method passes a null value as the parameter of a method which must be non-null. Either this parameter has been explicitly annotated as @NonNull, or the analysis has determined that this parameter is always dereferenced.

findingType.name: NonNull return violation
findingType.shortMessage: This method may return null, but its return value is declared @NonNull.
findingType.info: This method may return a null value, but the method (or a superclass method which it overrides) is declared to return @NonNull.

findingType.name: Clone() may return null
findingType.shortMessage: This clone method may return null. This violates the contract for clone.
findingType.info:
This clone method seems to return null in some circumstances. This violates the contract for clone because it is never allowed to return a null value.

If you are convinced this path is unreachable, throw an AssertionError instead of returning null.

findingType.name: ToString() may return null
findingType.shortMessage: This toString() method may return null. This could cause other code to break and is a bad coding practice.
findingType.info:
This toString() method seems to return null in some circumstances. A liberal reading of the specification could be interpreted as allowing this, but it is probably a very bad idea because it could cause other code to break.

It is suggested that you return the empty string or some other appropriate string rather than null.

findingType.name: Null dereference guaranteed on branch
findingType.shortMessage: A null value is guaranteed to be dereferenced. This may result in a NullPointerException being thrown if this code is executed.
findingType.info: There is a statement or branch that if executed guarantees that a value is null at this point, and that value that is guaranteed to be dereferenced (except on forward paths involving runtime exceptions). This may result in a NullPointerException being thrown at runtime.

findingType.name: Null dereference guaranteed on exceptional path
findingType.shortMessage: A null value is guaranteed to be dereferenced on an exception path. This may result in a NullPointerException being thrown if this code is executed.
findingType.info: There is a statement or branch on an exception path that if executed guarantees that a value is null at this point, and that value that is guaranteed to be dereferenced (except on forward paths involving runtime exceptions). This may result in a NullPointerException being thrown at runtime.

findingType.name: Instance constructed before static finals assigned
findingType.shortMessage: This static initializer creates an instance before all static final fields have been assigned. This could cause errors if the constructors expect the final static fields to have been assigned.
findingType.info:
The class's static initializer creates an instance of the class before all of the static final fields are assigned.

This could cause subtle behavior problems if the constructors rely upon the final static field to have been assigned. It is recommended that this static initializer block be moved below the field declarations to avoid this problem.

findingType.name: Return zero length arrays instead of null
findingType.shortMessage: Consider returning a zero length array rather than null.
findingType.info:
It is nearly always a better design to return a length zero array rather than a null reference to indicate that there are no results (i.e., an empty list of results). This way, no explicit check for null is needed by clients of the method.

For example, change code similar to

public String[] getArrayOfStrings() {
  // do something
  return null;
}

to

public String[] getArrayOfStrings() {
  // do something
  return new String[0];
}

This can be placed into a constant because you only need one zero-length array for each type.

On the other hand, using null to indicate "there is no answer to this question", then it is probably appropriate. For example, File.listFiles() returns an empty list if given a directory containing no files, and returns null if the file is not a directory.

For more information see Bloch's Effective Java (second edition) item 43.

findingType.name: Useless control flow
findingType.shortMessage: The code appears to have useless control flow. Is this intentional or is it a mistake?
findingType.info:
This method contains a useless control flow statement, where control flow continues onto the same place regardless of whether or not the branch is taken. For example, this can be caused by having an empty statement block for an if statement

if (argv.length == 0) {
  // TODO: handle this case
}

or by inadvertently using an empty statement as the body of an if statement

if (argv.length == 1);
  System.out.println("I always run, regardless of indentation" + argv[0]);

findingType.name: Null check of previously dereferenced value
findingType.shortMessage: This null check would have previously thrown a NullPointerException if the value is null. Either the check is redundant or the previous dereference is erroneous.
findingType.info:
A value is checked here to see whether it is null, but this value can't be null because it was previously dereferenced and if it were null then a NullPointerException would have been thrown at the earlier dereference.

Essentially, this code and the previous dereference disagree as to whether this value is allowed to be null. Either the check is redundant or the previous dereference is erroneous. Clearly some fix to the code is necessary.

findingType.name: Redundant null check of null value
findingType.shortMessage: This code contains a redundant null check of a value known to be null. This check can be removed.
findingType.info: This method contains a redundant check of a known null value against the constant null. The redundant check can be removed from the code.

findingType.name: Redundant null check of non-null value
findingType.shortMessage: This code contains a redundant null check of a value known to be non-null. This check can be removed.
findingType.info: This method contains a redundant check of a known non-null value against the constant null. The redundant check can be removed from the code.

findingType.name: Redundant comparison of two null values
findingType.shortMessage: This method contains a redundant comparison of two references known to both be definitely null. Fix this muddled code.
findingType.info: This method contains a redundant comparison of two references known to both be definitely null.

findingType.name: Redundant comparison of a null and a non-null value
findingType.shortMessage: This method contains a redundant comparison of a reference known to be non-null with another reference known to be null. Fix this muddled code.
findingType.info: This method contains a redundant comparison of a reference known to be non-null with another reference known to be null.

findingType.name: Unreleased util concurrent lock
findingType.shortMessage: This method does not release a util concurrent dynamic lock on all paths.
findingType.info:
This method acquires a java.util.concurrent lock, but does not release it on all paths (exceptional or unexceptional) out of the method. In general, the correct idiom for using a util concurrent lock is

Lock l = ...;
l.lock();
try {
  // do something
} finally {
  l.unlock();
}

findingType.name: Suspicious reference comparison
findingType.shortMessage: This code contains a suspicious reference comparison. Should it be using equals() instead?
findingType.info: This method compares two reference values using the == or != operator, where the correct way to compare instances of this type is generally with the equals() method. Examples of classes which should generally not be compared by reference are java.lang.Integer, java.lang.Float, etc.

findingType.name: Avoid calling equals() on unrelated types
findingType.shortMessage: This code calls equals() comparing two different and unrelated types. Fix this muddled code.
findingType.info:
This method calls equals() on two references of different class types with no common subclasses. Therefore, the objects being compared are unlikely to be members of the same class at runtime (unless some application classes were not analyzed, or dynamic class loading can occur at runtime).

According to the contract of equals(), objects of different classes should always compare as unequal; therefore, according to the contract defined by java.lang.Object.equals(Object), the result of this comparison will always be false at runtime.

This finding may signpost muddled code that may contain subtle errors.

findingType.name: Avoid calling equals() with a null argument
findingType.shortMessage: This code calls equals() with a null argument.
findingType.info:
This method calls equals(Object), passing a null value as the argument. According to the contract of the java.lang.Object.equals(Object) method, this call should always return false.

This finding may signpost muddled code that may contain subtle errors. Inexperienced programmers sometimes confuse comparison concepts and use equals() to check for a null reference.

findingType.name: Mismatched wait()
findingType.shortMessage: This code calls wait() without obviously holding a lock on the object. This could throw IllegalMonitorStateException at runtime.
findingType.info: This method calls Object.wait() without obviously holding a lock on the object. Calling wait() without a lock held will result in an IllegalMonitorStateException being thrown at runtime.

findingType.name: Mismatched notify()
findingType.shortMessage: This code calls notify() or notifyAll() without obviously holding a lock on the object. This could throw IllegalMonitorStateException at runtime.
findingType.info: This method calls Object.notify() or Object.notifyAll() without obviously holding a lock on the object. Calling notify() or notifyAll() without a lock held will result in an IllegalMonitorStateException being thrown at runtime.

findingType.name: Self assignment
findingType.shortMessage: This code assigns a variable or field to itself. This may indicate a logic error or a typo.
findingType.info:
This method contains a self assignment of a local variable or field. For example, the below code self assigns a local variable.

public void foo() {
  int x = 3;
  x = x;
}

The below code self assigns a field.

int x;

public void foo() {
  x = x;
}

Such assignments are useless, and may indicate a logic error or typo. One common case where this highlights a logic error is when a parameter masks a field and it appears the parameter is being assigned to the field but, sadly, the parameter is being assigned to itself. An example of this mistake is shown below.

int x;

public void foo(int x) {
  x = x;
}

findingType.name: Double assignment
findingType.shortMessage: This code contains a double assignment of a variable or field. This may indicate a logic error or a typo.
findingType.info:
This method contains a double assignment of a local variable or a field. For example, the below code double assigns a local variable.

public void foo() {
  int x, y;
  x = x = 17;
}

The below code double assigns a field.

private int x, y;

public void foo() {
  x = x = 17;
}

Assigning to a local variable or a field twice is useless, and may indicate a logic error or typo.

findingType.name: Nonsensical computation
findingType.shortMessage: This code performs a nonsensical self computation involving a field (e.g., x & x). Is this intentional?
findingType.info: This method performs a nonsensical computation of a field or local variable with another reference to the same field or local variable (e.g., x&x or x-x). Because of the nature of the computation, this operation doesn't seem to make sense, and may indicate a typo or a logic error. Please double check that the computation is intended.

findingType.name: Self comparison
findingType.shortMessage: This code compares a field or local variable with itself. Is this intentional?
findingType.info: This method compares a field or local variable with itself, and may indicate a typo or a logic error. Make sure that you are comparing the right things.

findingType.name: Double.longBitsToDouble() invoked on an int
findingType.shortMessage: This code invokes Double.longBitsToDouble() passing an int argument which is unlikely to give the intended result.
findingType.info: The Double.longBitsToDouble method is invoked, but a 32-bit int value is passed as an argument. This almost certainly is not intended and is unlikely to give the intended result due to the primitive widening conversion which will take place.

findingType.name: Random used only once
findingType.shortMessage: This code creates a Random object but only uses it once.
findingType.info:
This code creates a java.util.Random object, uses it to generate one random number, and then discards the object. This produces mediocre quality random numbers and is inefficient. If possible, rewrite the code so that the object is created once and saved, and each time a new random number is required invoke a method on the existing Random object to obtain it.

If it is important that the generated random numbers not be guessable, you must not create a new Random instance for each random number; the values are too easily guessable. You should strongly consider using a java.security.SecureRandom instead (and avoid allocating a new SecureRandom for each random number needed).

findingType.name: Absolute value of random int
findingType.shortMessage: Bad attempt to compute absolute value of signed 32-bit random integer. Use Random.nextInt(int) instead.
findingType.info:
This code generates a random signed integer and then computes the absolute value of that random integer. If the number returned by the random number generator is Integer.MIN_VALUE, then the result will be negative as well because Math.abs(Integer.MIN_VALUE) == Integer.MIN_VALUE).

This problem can be avoided by passing a value into the nextInt method. For example, if you have

final Random r = new Random();

then change code like this that can generate all positive ints as well as Integer.MIN_VALUE

// Bad! not always non-negative
int i = Math.abs(r.nextInt());

to

int i = r.nextInt(Integer.MAX_VALUE);

which will generate a value between 0 (inclusive) and Integer.MAX_VALUE (exclusive). It you want a positive value (not including zero) use

int i = r.nextInt(Integer.MAX_VALUE) + 1;

which will generate a value between 1 (inclusive) and Integer.MAX_VALUE (inclusive).

findingType.name: Absolute value of hashCode()
findingType.shortMessage: Bad attempt to compute absolute value of signed 32-bit hashcode.
findingType.info:
This code generates a hashcode and then computes the absolute value of that hashcode. If the hashcode is Integer.MIN_VALUE (which is possible), then the result will be negative as well because Math.abs(Integer.MIN_VALUE) == Integer.MIN_VALUE.

It is likely that this is not what the code intended to do. It likely expects the resulting int value to be non-negative. If this is the case then the case where the hashcode returned is Integer.MIN_VALUE must be considered. For example, you would change

// Bad! not always non-negative
int i = Math.abs(o.hashCode());

to

int i;
int hash = o.hashcode();
if (hash == Integer.MIN_VALUE) {
  i = 0; // or any non-negative value you like, maybe Integer.MAX_VALUE
} else {
  i = Math.abs(hash);
}

or create a utility method that does this for you.

findingType.name: Remainder of a random int
findingType.shortMessage: Remainder of 32-bit signed random integer. Use Random.nextInt(int) instead.
findingType.info: This code generates a random signed integer and then computes the remainder of that value modulo another value. Since the random number can be negative, the result of the remainder operation can also be negative. Be sure this is intended, and strongly consider using the Random.nextInt(int) method instead.

findingType.name: Remainder of hashCode()
findingType.shortMessage: Remainder of hashCode() could be negative
findingType.info:
This code computes a hashcode, and then computes the remainder of that value modulo another value. Since the resulting hashcode can be negative, the result of the remainder operation can also be negative.

Assuming you want to ensure that the result of your computation is nonnegative, you may need to change your code. If you know the divisor is a power of 2, you can use a bitwise and operator instead. For example, instead of using

x.hashCode() % n

use

x.hashCode() & (n-1)

This is probably faster than computing the remainder as well. If you don't know that the divisor is a power of 2, take the absolute value of the result of the remainder operation. For example, use

Math.abs(x.hashCode() % n)

findingType.name: Bad comparison with a nonnegative value
findingType.shortMessage: Bad comparison of nonnegative value with negative constant.
findingType.info: This code compares a value that is guaranteed to be non-negative with a negative constant. This comparison will always be false. Check that this code is correct and consider removing this comparison.

findingType.name: Bad comparison with a signed byte
findingType.shortMessage: Bad comparison of a signed byte with a value outside its range.
findingType.info:
Signed bytes can only have a value in the range -128 to 127. Comparing a signed byte with a value outside that range is vacuous and likely to be incorrect. Check that this code is correct and consider removing this comparison.

To convert a signed byte b to an unsigned value in the range 0..255, use

0xff & b

findingType.name: Vacuous comparison with an int
findingType.shortMessage: Vacuous comparison of an integer value.
findingType.info:
There is an integer comparison that always returns the same value. For example, the expression

x <= Integer.MAX_VALUE

will always be true. Check that this code is correct and consider removing this comparison.

findingType.name: Suspicious modulo 1
findingType.shortMessage: Integer remainder modulo 1 always results in 0. Is this what was intended?
findingType.info: Any expression (exp % 1) is guaranteed to always return zero. Did you mean (exp & 1) or (exp % 2) instead?

findingType.name: Suspicious bitwise or of signed byte
findingType.shortMessage: Suspicious bitwise or of a signed byte value.
findingType.info:
Loads a value from a byte array and performs a bitwise or with that value. Values loaded from a byte array are sign extended to 32 bits before any any bitwise operations are performed on the value. Thus, if b[0] contains the value 0xff, and x is initially 0, then the code ((x << 8) | b[0]) will sign extend 0xff to get 0xffffffff, and thus give the value 0xffffffff as the result.

In particular, the following code for packing a byte array into an int is badly wrong:

int result = 0;
for(int i = 0; i < 4; i++)
  result = ((result << 8) | b[i]);

The following idiom will work instead:

int result = 0;
for(int i = 0; i < 4; i++)
  result = ((result << 8) | (b[i] & 0xff));

findingType.name: Incompatible bit masks: and
findingType.shortMessage: Incompatible bit masks are always unequal.
findingType.info: This method compares an expression of the form (a & C) to D, which will always compare unequal due to the specific values of constants C and D. This may indicate a logic error or typo. Check that this code is correct and consider removing this comparison.

findingType.name: Incompatible bit masks and zero
findingType.shortMessage: Check to see if ((...) & 0) == 0 which is always true.
findingType.info: This method compares an expression of the form (a & 0) to 0, which will always compare equal. This may indicate a logic error or typo. Check that this code is correct and consider removing this comparison.

findingType.name: Incompatible bit masks: or
findingType.shortMessage: Incompatible bit masks are always unequal.
findingType.info:
This method compares an expression of the form (a | C) to D. which will always compare unequal due to the specific values of constants C and D. This may indicate a logic error or typo. Check that this code is correct and consider removing this comparison.

Typically, this issue occurs because the code wants to perform a membership test in a bit set, but uses the bitwise or operator ("|") instead of the bitwise and operator ("&").

findingType.name: Incorrect lazy initialization
findingType.shortMessage: Incorrect lazy initialization of a field.
findingType.info:
This method contains an unsynchronized lazy initialization of a non-volatile field. Because the compiler or processor may reorder instructions, threads are not guaranteed to see a completely initialized object, if the method can be called by multiple threads.

You can make the field volatile to correct the problem. For more information, please see the Java Memory Model web site.

findingType.name: Suspicious util concurrent Lock monitor use
findingType.shortMessage: Suspicions intrinsic synchronization performed on a java.util.concurrent Lock object. This is probably a mistake.
findingType.info:
This method performs synchronization on an implementation of java.util.concurrent.locks.Lock. You should use the lock() and unlock() methods instead. For example, change

Lock l = ...;
synchronized (l) { // Bad!
  // access the resource protected by this lock.
}

to

Lock l = ...;
l.lock();
try {
  // access the resource protected by this lock
} finally {
  l.unlock();
}

findingType.name: Uncalled private method
findingType.shortMessage: This private method is unused. Consider removing the method.
findingType.info: This private method is never called. Although it is possible that the method is invoked through reflection, it is more likely that the method is never used, and should be removed.

findingType.name: Uncallable method in an anonymous class
findingType.shortMessage: Uncallable method defined in anonymous class. Should this method be overriding another method?
findingType.info:
This anonymous class defines a method that is not directly invoked and does not override a method in a superclass. Since methods in other classes cannot directly invoke methods declared in an anonymous class, it appears that this method is uncallable.

The method might simply be dead code, but it is also possible that the method is intended to override a method declared in a superclass, and due to an typo or other error the method does not, in fact, override the method it is intended to.

findingType.name: Open database resource exception path
findingType.shortMessage: This method may fail to close a database resource on exception. Move the close to a finally block.
findingType.info:
The method creates a database resource (such as a database connection or row set), does not assign it to any fields, pass it to other methods, or return it, and does not appear to close the object on all exceptional paths out of the method.

Failure to close database resources on all paths out of a method may result in poor performance, and could cause the application to have problems communicating with the database.

To fix this use a finally block. For example, see the code below.

Connection connection = dataSource.getConnection();
try {
  Statement statement = connection.createStatement();
  try {
    ResultSet resultSet = statement.executeQuery(some query);
    try {
      // Do stuff with the result set.
    } finally {
      resultSet.close();
    }
  } finally {
    statement.close();
  }
} finally {
  connection.close();
}

Note that there are some helpful utilities provided by the Apache Commons DbUtils project that may be useful in your program.

findingType.name: Use StringBuffer for String appends
findingType.shortMessage: This method concatenates Strings using + in a loop. Consider using StringBuffer to improve performance.
findingType.info:
The method seems to be building a String using concatenation in a loop. In each iteration, the String is converted to a StringBuffer/StringBuilder, appended to, and converted back to a String by the compiler. This can lead to a cost quadratic in the number of iterations, as the growing string is recopied in each iteration.

Better performance can be obtained by using a StringBuffer (or StringBuilder in Java 1.5) explicitly.

For example, consider changing

String s = "";
 for (int i = 0; i < field.length; ++i) {
  s = s + field[i]; // Bad!
}

to

final StringBuilder buf = new StringBuilder();
for (int i = 0; i < field.length; ++i) {
  buf.append(field[i]);
}
String s = buf.toString();

Also avoid using += for appending strings.

If you are using JDK 1.5 or above it is strongly recommended that you use StringBuilder rather than StringBuffer. In most cases the use of StringBuilder will improve code performance by avoid unnecessary synchronization.

findingType.name: Questionable use of toArray()
findingType.shortMessage: Method uses toArray() with no argument or a zero-length array argument. The no argument call may result in a ClassCastException.
findingType.info:
This method uses the toArray() method of a collection derived class, and passes nothing or a zero-length prototype array argument.

It is more efficient to use myCollection.toArray(new Foo[myCollection.size()]) If the array passed in is big enough to store all of the elements of the collection, then it is populated and returned directly. This avoids the need to create a second array (by reflection) to return as the result.

If you need to get an array of a class from a Collection, you should pass an array of the desired class as the parameter of the toArray method. Otherwise you will get a ClassCastException.

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.Collection;

public class Test {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    Collection c = new ArrayList();
    Integer obj = new Integer(1);
    c.add(obj);

    // this would trigger the rule (and throw a ClassCastException if executed)
    Integer[] a = (Integer[])c.toArray();

    // this wouldn't trigger the rule
    Integer[] b = (Integer[])c.toArray(new Integer[c.size()]);
  }
}

findingType.name: Suspicious JUnit assertion within Runnable.run()
findingType.shortMessage: A JUnit assertion in run method in another thread will not be noticed by JUnit. Are you trying to test concurrent code?
findingType.info:
A JUnit assertion is performed in a run method. This is suspicious if the code is running in another thread.

Failed JUnit assertions just result in exceptions being thrown. Thus, if this exception occurs in a thread other than the thread that invokes the test method, the exception will terminate the thread but not result in the test failing.

One approach to fix this problem is to save up the test failures encountered in the second thread (e.g., in a collection or some other scheme) and after the thread has completed report the problems in the JUnit thread.

findingType.name: SetUp() does not call super.setUp()
findingType.shortMessage: JUnit TestCase implements setUp but doesn't call super.setUp().
findingType.info: This class is a JUnit TestCase and implements the setUp method. The setUp method should call super.setUp(), but in this case it doesn't.

findingType.name: TearDown() does not call super.tearDown()
findingType.shortMessage: TestCase implements tearDown but doesn't call super.tearDown().
findingType.info: This class is a JUnit TestCase and implements the tearDown method. The tearDown method should call super.tearDown(), but in this case it doesn't.

findingType.name: TestCase suite is not static
findingType.shortMessage: TestCase implements a non-static suite method.
findingType.info: This class is a JUnit TestCase and implements the suite() method. The suite method should be declared to be static, but isn't.

findingType.name: Bad suite() method signature
findingType.shortMessage: TestCase declares a bad suite() method. Its signature appears to be wrong.
findingType.info:
This class is a JUnit TestCase and defines a suite() method. However, the suite method needs to be declared as either

public static junit.framework.Test suite()

or

public static junit.framework.TestSuite suite()

In this case the suite() method matches neither of these two signatures.

findingType.name: TestCase with no tests
findingType.shortMessage: This TestCase has no tests.
findingType.info: This class is a JUnit TestCase but has not implemented any test methods.

findingType.name: Badly overridden adapter
findingType.shortMessage: Class overrides a method implemented in super class adapter wrongly.
findingType.info:
This method intends to override a method found in a parent class, where that class is an Adapter that implements a listener defined in the java.awt.event or javax.swing.event package, however, it does not override the intended method. As a result, this method will not get called when the event occurs.

Consider fixing this method's signature and adding the @Override annotation to it.

findingType.name: Bad ResultSet access
findingType.shortMessage: This code attempts to access a ResultSet field with a index of 0. This is always a mistake.
findingType.info:
A call to getx or updatex methods of a ResultSet was made where the field index is 0. Because ResultSet field indexes start at 1, this is always a mistake.

For example, the code below is wrong and will always throw an SQLException.

ResultSet rs = ...
rs.getInt(0);

It is recommended that this index be changed to start at 1.

findingType.name: Bad PreparedStatement access
findingType.shortMessage: This code attempts to access a PreparedStatement parameter with index 0. This is always a mistake.
findingType.info:
A call to a setx method of a PreparedStatement was made where the parameter index is 0. Because PreparedSatement parameter indexes start at 1, this is always a mistake.

For example, the code below is wrong and will always throw an SQLException.

PreparedStatement ps = ...
int value = ...
ps.setInt(0, value);

It is recommended that this index be changed to start at 1.

findingType.name: Superfluous instanceof
findingType.shortMessage: Unnecessary type check done using instanceof operator. This check can be removed from the code.
findingType.info:
This code performs a type check using the instanceof operator where it can be statically determined that the object is of the type requested.

For example, the code below should be changed from

public Place getPlace(String name) {
  assert (name != null);
  Place result = getPlaceByName(name);
  if (result instanceof Place)  // Bad!
    return (Place) result;
  else
    return null;
}

to

public Place getPlace(String name) {
  assert (name != null);
  return getPlaceByName(name);
}

findingType.name: Bad Applet constructor
findingType.shortMessage: Bad Applet constructor relies on uninitialized AppletStub. Move this logic into init().
findingType.info:
This constructor calls methods in the parent Applet that rely on the AppletStub. Since the AppletStub isn't initialized until the init() method of this applet is called, these methods will not perform correctly.

It is recommended that this logic be moved from this constructor to the init() method.

findingType.name: Nonsensical comparison of array and non-array
findingType.shortMessage: This code is using equals() to compare an array with a non-array. This comparison will always be false.
findingType.info:
This method invokes the equals(Object o) method to compare an array with a reference that doesn't seem to be an array. If things being compared are of different types, they are guaranteed to be unequal and this comparison is almost certainly an error.

In the case where they are both arrays (i.e., the analysis is wrong), the equals method on arrays only determines if the two arrays are the same object (i.e., it just does ==). To compare the contents of the arrays, use the java.util.Arrays.equals(Object[], Object[]) method instead. For example, consider changing

if (array1.equals(array2)) {
  // do something
}

to

if (Arrays.equals(array1, array2)) {
  // do something
}

findingType.name: Suspicious array comparison
findingType.shortMessage: This code is using equals() to compare two arrays, which in this case is equivalent to using ==. Consider using Arrays.equals() instead.
findingType.info:
This method invokes the equals(Object o) method on an array. Since arrays do not override the equals method of Object, calling equals on an array is the same as comparing their addresses (i.e., using ==). To compare the contents of the arrays, use the java.util.Arrays.equals(Object[], Object[]) method instead. For example, consider changing

if (array1.equals(array2)) {
  // do something
}

to

if (Arrays.equals(array1, array2)) {
  // do something
}

findingType.name: Unnecessary use of currentThread() to call interrupted()
findingType.shortMessage: Unnecessary use of Thread.currentThread() simply to call interrupted(). Change to Thread.interrupted().
findingType.info:
This code invokes the Thread.currentThread() method just to call the interrupted() method. Because interrupted() is a static method, is more simple and clear to use Thread.interrupted() in your code.

For example, consider changing

if (Thread.currentThread().interrupted()) { // Bad!
  // do something
}

to

if (Thread.interrupted()) {
  // do something
}

findingType.name: Suspicious interrupted() call on an unknown Thread
findingType.shortMessage: This code invokes the static Thread.interrupted() method on an unknown Thread instance. This is likely not doing what the programmer intended.
findingType.info:
This method invokes the interrupted() method on a Thread object that does not appear to be the current thread. Because the interrupted() method is static, and is defined to always test whether the current thread has been interrupted this code is suspicious. Check that this finding is not signposting an error.

If it is intended to test if the current thread has been interrupted, then change code like

Thread other = ...
if (other.interrupted()) { // Bad!
  // do something
}

to

if (Thread.interrupted()) {
  // do something
}

findingType.name: Dead parameter is overwritten
findingType.shortMessage: A parameter that is dead upon entry (i.e., it is never read) to a method is overwritten. Does this code mistakenly believe that a write to the parameter will be conveyed back to the caller?
findingType.info:
The initial value of this parameter is ignored, but the parameter is overwritten here. This often indicates a mistaken belief by the programmer that the write to the parameter will be conveyed back to the caller.

For example, the below program will print 3 (not 4).

public class Foo {

  public static void main(String[] args) {
    int i = 3;
    muddled(i);
    System.out.println(i);
  }

  public static void muddled(int i) {
    i = 4;
  }
}

findingType.name: Dead local store
findingType.shortMessage: Dead store to a local variable. Is something wrong with this code's logic?
findingType.info:
This instruction assigns a value to a local variable, but the value is not read by any subsequent instruction. Often, this indicates an error, because the computed value is never used.

Note that Sun's javac compiler often generates dead stores for final local variables. Because FindBugs analysis done on bytecode, there is no easy way to eliminate these false positives.

findingType.name: Dead local store of null
findingType.shortMessage: Dead store of null to local variable. Is something wrong with this code's logic?
findingType.info: This code stores null into a local variable, and this stored value is not subsequently read. This store may have been introduced in assist the garbage collector, but as of Java SE 6.0, this is no longer needed or useful. Consider removing this assignment.

findingType.name: Method variable masks a field
findingType.shortMessage: This method defines a variable name that obscures a field with the same name. Is this intended.
findingType.info:
This method defines a local variable with the same name as a field defined in this class or a superclass. This may cause the method to read an uninitialized value from the field, leave the field uninitialized, or both. Consider changing either the variable name or the field name to avoid masking.

For example, the below code is broken

class Foo {
  private int height;
  private int weight;

  public void setHeight(int height) {
    height = height; // Bad! self-assignment
  }

  public void setWeight(int weight) {
    weight = weight; // Bad! self-assignment
  }
}

because it assigns the parameter to the method to itself. To fix it remove the masking or qualify with this.

class Foo {
  private int height;
  private int weight;

  public void setHeight(int value) {
    height = value;
  }

  public void setWeight(int weight) {
    this.weight = weight;
  }
}

Note that a naming convention on fields may used to avoid masking. For example all fields could be prefixed with f_ or m_ to clarify the name is a field. For example, see the example below.

class Foo {
  private int f_height;
  private int f_weight;

  public void setHeight(int height) {
    f_height = height;
  }

  public void setWeight(int weight) {
    f_weight = weight;
  }
}

findingType.name: Class masks a superclass field
findingType.shortMessage: This class defines field that masks a superclass field. This can be confusing.
findingType.info:
This class defines a field with the same name as a visible instance field in a superclass. This is confusing, and may indicate an error if methods update or access one of the fields when they intended to work with the other.

For example, consider the below code which masks the foo field.

class A {
  protected int foo;
}

class B extends A {
  protected int foo;
  void setFoo(int value) {
    foo = value; // Bad! writes B.foo not A.foo which may be confusing
  }
}

findingType.name: Inefficient Map iteration
findingType.shortMessage: Inefficient use of keySet() iterator instead of entrySet() iterator.
findingType.info:
This method accesses the value of a Map entry, using a key that was retrieved from a keySet() iterator. It is more efficient to use an iterator on the entrySet() of the map, and to thus avoid the Map.get(key) lookup for each key in the map.

For example, if you have

Map<String, Integer> nameToCount = new HashMap();

then you should replace code that looks like

for (final String key : nameToCount.keySet()) {
  final Integer value = nameToCount.get(key);
  // do something with 'key' and 'value'
}

with the more efficient

for (Map.Entry<String, Integer> entry : nameToCount.entrySet()) {
  final String key = entry.getKey();
  final Integer value = entry.getValue();
  // do something with 'key' and 'value'
}

findingType.name: Needless instantiation of a static-only class
findingType.shortMessage: This code needlessly instantiates a class that only supplies static methods. Remove this instantiation and access the static methods using the class name.
findingType.info:
This class allocates an object that is based on a class that only supplies static methods. This object does not need to be created, just access the static methods directly using the class name as a qualifier.

In addition, a private constructor should probably be added to the class with only static methods so that this needless instantiation will cause a compiler error.

For example, consider the below class that contains only a single static method.

package com.surelogic;

public class SimpleLogger {
  public static void log(String s) {
    System.out.println(s);
  }
}

You should change

SimpleLogger log = new SimpleLogger(); // Bad!
log.log("Starting up...");

to

SimpleLogger.log("Starting up...");

If this is deemed too lengthy then a static import can be used to shorten the calls. Just add

import static com.surelogic.SimpleLogger.log;

to the compilation unit using the logger and now

log("Starting up...");

will work.

In addition, consider changing the SimpleLogger class to

package com.surelogic;

public class SimpleLogger {
  public static void log(String s) {
    System.out.println(s);
  }

  private SimpleLogger() {
    // no instances
  }
}

to avoid this type of problem appearing again in future code.

findingType.name: Suspicious catch of Exception
findingType.shortMessage: Exception is caught when Exception is not thrown. This may mask potential problems.
findingType.info:
This method uses a try-catch block that catches Exception objects, but Exception is not thrown within the try block, and RuntimeException is not explicitly caught. This may signpost muddled exception handling that could mask potential problems.

It is a common bug pattern to say

try {
  // do something
} catch (Exception e) {
  // handle some problem
}

as a shorthand for catching a number of types of exception each of whose catch blocks is identical, but this construct also accidentally catches RuntimeException as well, masking potential bugs.

Examine this code carefully as it is suspicious. Are all RuntimeExceptions being handled by this code?

findingType.name: Doomed test for equality to NaN
findingType.shortMessage: Doomed test for equality to NaN. Did you mean to use Double.isNaN() or Float.isNaN()?
findingType.info:
This code checks to see if a floating point value is equal to the special Not A Number (NaN) value (e.g., if (x == Double.NaN)). However, because of the special semantics of NaN, no value is equal to Nan, including NaN. Thus, x == Double.NaN always evaluates to false.

To check to see if a value contained in x is the special Not A Number value, use Double.isNaN(x) (or Float.isNaN(x) if x is floating point precision).

findingType.name: Suspicious floating-point equality
findingType.shortMessage: Test for floating-point equality. This test may not produce the expected result.
findingType.info:
This operation compares two floating-point values for equality. Because floating-point calculations may involve rounding, calculated float and double values may not be accurate.

For values that must be precise, such as monetary values, consider using a fixed-precision type such as BigDecimal.

For values that need not be precise, consider comparing for equality within some range, for example: 

if (Math.abs(x - y) < .0000001) {
  // do something
}

Please see the Java Language Specification section 4.2.4 for further details.

findingType.name: Unnecessary math
findingType.shortMessage: Method calls static Math class method on a constant value.
findingType.info:
This method uses a static method from java.lang.Math on a constant value. This method's result in this case, can be determined statically, and is faster and sometimes more accurate to just use the constant. Methods detected are:

MethodParameter
abs-any-
acos0.0 or 1.0
asin0.0 or 1.0
atan 0.0 or 1.0
atan20.0
cbrt0.0 or 1.0
ceil-any-
cos0.0
cosh0.0
exp0.0 or 1.0
expm10.0
floor-any-
log0.0 or 1.0
log100.0 or 1.0
rint-any-
round-any-
sin0.0
sinh0.0
sqrt0.0 or 1.0
tan0.0
tanh0.0
toDegrees0.0 or 1.0
toRadians0.0

findingType.name: Circular dependency
findingType.shortMessage: Circular dependencies among classes detected. This signposts a poor design or implementation.
findingType.info: This class has a circular dependency with other classes. This makes building these classes difficult, as each is dependent on the other to build correctly. Consider using interfaces to break the hard dependency.

findingType.name: Redundant interfaces
findingType.shortMessage: This class implements the same interface as its superclass. Consider removing the redundant implements from this class.
findingType.info:
This class declares that it implements an interface that is also implemented by a superclass. This is redundant, once a superclass implements an interface, all subclasses by default also implement the interface. Therefore, you can remove this redundant statement.

This issue may point out that the inheritance hierarchy has changed since this class was created, and consideration should be made about which class should implement the interface.

findingType.name: Suspect Struts instance field
findingType.shortMessage: This class extends the Struts Action class and uses instance variables. This is likely to problematic.
findingType.info: This class extends from a Struts Action class, and uses a instance member variable. Since only one instance of a struts Action class is created by the Struts framework, and used in a multithreaded way, this paradigm is highly discouraged and most likely problematic. Consider removing these fields.

findingType.name: Suspect Servlet instance field
findingType.shortMessage: This class extends Servlet class and uses instance variables. This is likely to be problematic.
findingType.info: This class extends from a Servlet class, and uses a instance member variable. Since only one instance of a Servlet class is created by the container, and used in a multithreaded way, this paradigm is highly discouraged and most likely problematic. Consider removing these fields.

findingType.name: Public semaphores
findingType.shortMessage: Class exposes synchronization and semaphores in its public interface.
findingType.info:
This class uses synchronization along with wait(), notify() or notifyAll() on itself (the this reference). Client classes that use this class, may, in addition, use an instance of the class as a synchronizing object. Because two classes are using the same object for synchronization, multithreaded correctness is suspect. You should not synchronize nor call semaphore methods on a public reference. Consider using a internal private member variable to control synchronization. For example, consider changing

public class Foo {

  public synchronized void log(String s) {
    // do something
  }
	
  public int generate() {
    synchronized (this) {
      // do something
    }
    return 4;
  }
}

to

public class Foo {
	
  private final Object lock = new Object();

  public void log(String s) {
    synchronized (lock) {
      // do something
    }
  }
	
  public int generate() {
    synchronized (lock) {
      // do something
    }
    return 4;
  }
}

findingType.name: Integer multiplication result cast to long
findingType.shortMessage: This code casts the result of integer multiplication to a long. This might overflow.
findingType.info:
This code performs integer multiply and then converts the result to a long, as in:

long convertDaysToMilliseconds(int days) {
  return 1000 * 3600 * 24 * days; // Bad! int values may overflow
}

If the multiplication is done using long arithmetic, you can avoid the possibility that the result will overflow. To do this change at least one of the values to a long. For example, you could fix the above code by making the int literal 1000 a long literal as shown below.

long convertDaysToMilliseconds(int days) {
  return 1000L * 3600 * 24 * days;
}

or

static final long MILLISECONDS_PER_DAY = 24L * 3600 * 1000;

long convertDaysToMilliseconds(int days) {
  return days * MILLISECONDS_PER_DAY;
}

findingType.name: Int cast to a float then passed to Math.round()
findingType.shortMessage: This code casts an int value to a float value and then passes this value to Math.round(). It is likely that this is not what was intended.
findingType.info:
This code converts an int value to a float precision floating-point number and then passes the result to the Math.round() function, which returns the int/long closest to the argument. This operation should always be a no-op, since the converting an integer to a float should give a number with no fractional part.

It is likely that the operation that generated the value to be passed to Math.round() was intended to be performed using floating-point arithmetic. Check this code carefully for errors.

findingType.name: Int cast to a double then passed to Math.ceil()
findingType.shortMessage: This code casts an int value to a double value and then passes this value to Math.ceil(). It is likely that this is not what was intended.
findingType.info:
This code converts an int value to a double precision floating-point number and then passes the result to the Math.ceil() function, which rounds a double to the next higher integer value. This operation should always be a no-op, since the converting an integer to a double should give a number with no fractional part.

It is likely that the operation that generated the value to be passed to Math.ceil() was intended to be performed using double precision floating-point arithmetic. Check this code carefully for errors.

findingType.name: Integer division result cast to a floating-point type
findingType.shortMessage: The result of integer division is cast to a double or float. Should floating-point division have been done instead?
findingType.info:
This code casts the result of an integer division operation to a double or float. Doing division on integers truncates the result to the integer value closest to zero.

The fact that the result was cast to a double suggests that this precision should have been used for the division operation. What was probably meant was to cast one or both of the operands to double before performing the division. Here is an example:

int x = 2; int y = 5;

double value1 = x / y;          // Bad! yields 0.0

double value2 = x / (double) y; // Right! yields 0.4

findingType.name: Store of non-serializable Object into HttpSession
findingType.shortMessage: This code appears to be storing a non-serializable object into an HttpSession. This may cause an error if the session is passivated.
findingType.info: This code seems to be storing a non-serializable object into an HttpSession. If this session is passivated or migrated, an error will result. Consider making this object serializable.

findingType.name: Store of non-serializable Object
findingType.shortMessage: This code appears to be writing a non-serializable object to an ObjectOutput instance. This may throw an IOException.
findingType.info: This code seems to be passing a non-serializable object to the ObjectOutput.writeObject() method. If the object is, indeed, non-serializable, an error will result. Consider making this object serializable.

findingType.name: Primitive array passed to a vararg
findingType.shortMessage: Primitive array passed to function expecting a variable number of object arguments. The array will become one argument which may not be what was intended.
findingType.info: This code passes a primitive array to a function that takes a variable number of object arguments. This creates an array of length one to hold the primitive array and passes it to the function. Check this code and ensure that this behavior is intentional.

findingType.name: Equals() should work for all arguments
findingType.shortMessage: An equals method should not assume anything about the type of its argument. This code appears to be making assumptions.
findingType.info:
The equals(Object o) method shouldn't make any assumptions about the type of o. It should simply return false if o is not the same type as this. For example, examine the below code.

class Foo {
  @Override public boolean equals(Object o) {
    if (this == o) return true;
    if (o == null) return false;
    if (getClass() != o.getClass()) return false;  // <-- type check
    Foo other = (Foo) o;
    // check semantic equality of 'this' and 'other'
    ...
  }
  ...
}

findingType.name: Questionable Collection cast
findingType.shortMessage: Questionable cast to List, Set, or Map from Collection. Do you need to do this?
findingType.info: This code casts a Collection to a more specific type such as List, Set, or Map. Ensure that you are guaranteed that the object is of the type you are casting to. If all you need is to be able to iterate through a Collection, you don't need to cast it to a Set or List.

findingType.name: Impossible cast primitive array
findingType.shortMessage: This code contains an impossible cast involving a primitive array. It will always throw a ClassCastException.
findingType.info: This cast will always throw a ClassCastException. This code needs to be fixed.

findingType.name: Impossible cast
findingType.shortMessage: Impossible cast will always throw a ClassCastException. Fix this code.
findingType.info: This cast will always throw a ClassCastException. This code needs to be fixed.

findingType.name: Suspicious instanceof null
findingType.shortMessage: This code checks to see if a known null value an instance of a type. This will always return false. Is this code broken?
findingType.info:
This instanceof test will always return false, because the value being checked is guaranteed to be null.

Although this is legal code, make sure it isn't an indication of some misunderstanding or some other logic error. It is also recommended that you consider removing the check.

findingType.name: Impossible instanceof
findingType.shortMessage: This code contains an instanceof test that will always return false. Is this code broken?
findingType.info:
This instanceof test will always return false.

Although this is legal code, make sure it isn't an indication of some misunderstanding or some other logic error. It is also recommended that you consider removing the check.

findingType.name: Unconfirmed cast
findingType.shortMessage: Unchecked/unconfirmed cast
findingType.info:
This cast is unchecked, and not all instances of the type casted from can be cast to the type it is being cast to. Ensure that your program logic ensures that this cast will not fail, perhaps by adding an instanceof check.

if (o instanceof MyClass) {
  final MyClass mc = (MyClass) o;
  // do something
}

findingType.name: Questionable cast to a concrete collection
findingType.shortMessage: This code contains a questionable cast to concrete collection.
findingType.info:
This code casts an abstract collection type, such as Collection, List, or Set, to a specific concrete implementation type, such as ArrayList or HashSet. This might not be correct, and it may make your code fragile, since it makes it harder to switch to other concrete implementations at a future point.

It is recommended that you try to remove this cast from your code. Unless you have a sound reason to do so, just interact with the abstract collection type.

findingType.name: Suspicious regex pattern
findingType.shortMessage: "." is used as a regular expression. Is this what you intended?
findingType.info:
A String function is being invoked and "." is being passed to a parameter that takes a regular expression as an argument. Is this what you intended?

For example

String r = s.replaceAll(".", "/");

will return a String in which every character has been replaced by a / character.

findingType.name: Bad syntax for regex
findingType.shortMessage: This code uses an invalid regular expression. It will always throw a PatternSyntaxException.
findingType.info: This code uses a regular expression that is invalid according to the syntax for regular expressions. This statement will throw a PatternSyntaxException when executed. Please fix this code.

findingType.name: Bad use of File.separator for regex
findingType.shortMessage: This code uses File.separator for a regular expression. This will fail on Windows platforms.
findingType.info:
The code here uses File.separator where a regular expression is required. This will fail on Windows platforms, where the File.separator is a backslash, which is interpreted in a regular expression as an escape character. To fix this, on Windows, you need to use two backslashs in a row—not just one.

One approach to fixing this is to create a constant

public static final String regExSeparator = File.separatorChar == '\\' ? "\\\\" : File.separator;

which you use instead of File.separator.

findingType.name: Overwritten increment
findingType.shortMessage: This code preforms an increments operation and then immediately overwrites it. Is this a mistake?
findingType.info:
This code performs an increment operation (e.g., i++) and then immediately overwrites it. For example,

i = i++;

immediately overwrites the incremented value with the original value.

This is probably not what was intended. Most likely this code should be i++ (alone) or i = i + 1.

findingType.name: Questionable unsigned right shift
findingType.shortMessage: Unsigned right shift cast to short/byte.
findingType.info: The code performs an unsigned right shift, whose result is then cast to a short or byte, which discards the upper bits of the result. Since the upper bits are discarded, there may be no difference between a signed and unsigned right shift (depending upon the size of the shift).

findingType.name: Bad shift amount
findingType.shortMessage: This code performs an integer shift by an amount not in the range 0..31.
findingType.info: The code performs an integer shift by a constant amount outside the range 0..31. The effect of this is to use the lower 5 bits of the integer value to decide how much to shift by. This probably isn't want was expected, and it at least confusing.

findingType.name: Multiplying result of an int remainder
findingType.shortMessage: Integer multiply of result of an integer remainder operation. Is this a mistake?
findingType.info:
The code multiplies the result of an integer remaining by an integer constant. Be sure you don't have your operator precedence confused. For example

i % 60 * 1000

is

(i % 60) * 1000

not

i % (60 * 1000)

findingType.name: Invoking toString() on array
findingType.shortMessage: Invocation of toString() on an array produces a useless result. Did you mean to use Arrays.toString()?
findingType.info:
The code invokes toString() on an array, which will generate a fairly useless result such as [C@16f0472. Consider using the Arrays.toString() method to convert the array into a readable String that also shows the contents of the array.

For more information on this issue see puzzle 12 of Bloch and Gafter's Java Puzzlers.

findingType.name: Average computation could overflow
findingType.shortMessage: This code contains a computation that could overflow.
findingType.info:
This code computes the average of two integers using either division or signed right shift, and then uses the result as the index of an array. If the values being averaged are very large, this can overflow (resulting in the computation of a negative average).

Assuming that the result is intended to be nonnegative, you can use an unsigned right shift instead. In other words, rather that using

(low + high) / 2

use

(low + high) >>> 1

This bug exists in many earlier implementations of binary search and merge sort. Martin Buchholz found and fixed it in the JDK libraries, and Joshua Bloch widely publicized the bug pattern.

findingType.name: Bad check for odd
findingType.shortMessage: This code performs a check for oddness that won't work for negative values.
findingType.info:
The code uses x % 2 == 1 to check to see if a value is odd, but this won't work for negative numbers. For example, (-5) % 2 == -1 (not 1). If this code is trying to check for oddness, consider using 

x & 1 == 1

or

x % 2 != 0

both of which avoid this issue.

findingType.name: Hardcoded absolute filename
findingType.shortMessage: This code contains a hard coded reference to an absolute pathname. This can make your code difficult to deploy.
findingType.info:
This code constructs a File object using a hard coded to an absolute pathname. For example

new File("/home/dannyc/workspace/j2ee/src/share/com/sun/enterprise/deployment");

This can strongly tie the code the environment it is developed within and make it more difficult to deploy. Consider moving this file reference into a properties file or use some other more flexible scheme.

findingType.name: Bad month value
findingType.shortMessage: Bad constant value for month passed. This is likely a typo or a bug.
findingType.info: This code passes a constant month value outside the expected range of 0..11 to a method. Please fix this code.

findingType.name: Useless substring(0)
findingType.shortMessage: This code calls substring(0), which returns the original value. It may signpost a typo or a bug.
findingType.info: This code invokes substring(0) on a String, which returns the original value. This is likely a mistake and this code should be examined carefully for logic errors.

findingType.name: Never call next() from hasNext()
findingType.shortMessage: The hasNext() method in this code invokes next() which is almost certainly wrong.
findingType.info:
In this iterator implementation the hasNext() method invokes the next() method. This is almost certainly wrong, since the hasNext() method is not supposed to change the state of the iterator, and the next() method is supposed to change the state of the iterator.

Please examine the specification for an iterator and fix this code.

findingType.name: Avoid sleeping with a lock held
findingType.shortMessage: This code calls Thread.sleep() with a lock held which may impact performance and scalability.
findingType.info:
This code appears to call Thread.sleep() with a lock held. This may result in very poor performance and scalability, or a deadlock, since other threads may be waiting to acquire the lock.

If you must hold a lock, it is a much better idea to call wait() on the lock, which releases the lock and allows other threads to run. In addition consider using the classes in the java.util.concurrent package.

findingType.name: Duplicate branches
findingType.shortMessage: This code uses the same logic for two branches. Is this a coding mistake?
findingType.info: This method uses the same code to implement two branches of a conditional branch. Check this logic carefully to ensure that this isn't a coding mistake.

findingType.name: Duplicate switch clauses
findingType.shortMessage: This code uses the same logic for two switch clauses. Is this a coding mistake?
findingType.info: This method uses the same code to implement two clauses of a switch statement. This could be a case of duplicate code, but it might also indicate a coding mistake.

findingType.name: Inefficient member access
findingType.shortMessage: Method accesses a private member variable of owning class. This may be inefficient.
findingType.info: This method of an inner class reads from or writes to a private member variable of the owning class, or calls a private method of the owning class. The compiler must generate a special method to access this private member, causing this code to be less efficient. Relaxing the protection of the member variable or method will allow the compiler to treat this as a normal access.

findingType.name: XML factory bypass
findingType.shortMessage: This code directly allocates a specific implementation of and XML interface. Should you be using a factory?
findingType.info:
This method allocates a specific implementation of an XML interface. It is preferable to use the supplied factory classes to create these objects so that the implementation can be changed at runtime. See

  • javax.xml.parsers.DocumentBuilderFactory
  • javax.xml.parsers.SAXParserFactory
  • javax.xml.transform.TransformerFactory
  • org.w3c.dom.Document.createX

for details.

findingType.name: Useless abstract method
findingType.shortMessage: Abstract method is already defined in an implemented interface. Remove this method.
findingType.info: This abstract method is already defined in an interface that is implemented by this abstract class. This method can be removed, as it provides no additional value.

findingType.name: Confused inheritance
findingType.shortMessage: Class is final but declares at least one protected field.
findingType.info:
This class is declared to be final, but it declares fields to be protected. Since the class is final, it can not be subclassed, and the use of protected is confusing.

The access modifier for the field should be changed to private or public to represent the actual intended use for the field.

findingType.name: Questionable boolean assignment
findingType.shortMessage: This code assigns boolean literal in boolean expression. Is this a mistake? Did you mean ==?
findingType.info: This method assigns a literal boolean value (true or false) to a boolean variable inside an if or while expression. Most probably this is a mistake and the code was supposed to be a boolean comparison using ==, not an assignment using =.

findingType.name: Unresolvable reference
findingType.shortMessage: This class makes reference to unresolvable class or method.
findingType.info: This class makes a reference to a class or method that can not be resolved using against the libraries it is being analyzed with. This may be caused if the analysis was not told about the program's entire classpath.

findingType.name: Unrelated types
findingType.shortMessage: No relationship between a generic parameter and this method argument.
findingType.info: This call to a generic container's method contains an argument with a different class type from that of the container's parameter. Therefore, it is unlikely that the container contains any objects with the same type as the method argument used here.

findingType.name: Avoid static Calendar instances
findingType.shortMessage: This code contains a static Calendar instance. This may cause erratic behavior in your application.
findingType.info:
Calendar instances are inherently unsafe for multithreaded use. Sharing a single instance across thread boundaries without proper synchronization will result in erratic behavior of the application. Under JDK 1.4 problems seem to surface less often than under Java 5 where you will probably see random ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsExceptions or IndexOutOfBoundsExceptions in sun.util.calendar.BaseCalendar.getCalendarDateFromFixedDate().

You may also experience serialization problems.

Using an instance field is recommended.

For more information on this issue please see Sun bug #6231579 and Sun bug #6178997.

findingType.name: Avoid static SimpleDateFormat instances
findingType.shortMessage: This code contains a static SimpleDateFormat instance. This may cause erratic behavior in your application.
findingType.info:
As the Javadoc states, DateFormat objects are inherently unsafe for multithreaded use. Sharing a single instance across thread boundaries without proper synchronization will result in erratic behavior of the application.

You may also experience serialization problems.

Using an instance field is recommended.

For more information about this issue see Sun Bug #6231579 and Sun Bug #6178997.

findingType.name: Doesn't override equals()
findingType.shortMessage: This class doesn't override equals in its superclass. Is this a mistake?
findingType.info:
This class extends a class that defines an equals method. The class adds fields, but doesn't define an equals method itself. Thus, equality on instances of this class will ignore the identity of the subclass and the added fields.

Be sure this is what is intended, and that you don't need to override the equals method. Even if you don't need to override the equals method, consider overriding it anyone to document the fact that the equals method for the subclass just return the result of invoking super.equals(o).

For more information see Bloch's Effective Java (second edition) items 8 and 9.

findingType.name: Avoid same simple name as interface/class
findingType.shortMessage: Class names shouldn't shadow the simple name of implemented interfaces or extended classes. This can be confusing.
findingType.info:
This class/interface has a simple name that is identical to that of an implemented/extended interface/class, except that the interface/class is in a different package. For example

package org.alpha;

class Foo extends org.beta.Foo implements org.gamma.Foo {
  ...
}

This can be exceptionally confusing, create lots of situations in which you have to look at import statements to resolve references, and creates many opportunities to accidentally define methods that do not override methods in their superclasses.

findingType.name: No override due to wrong package for a parameter
findingType.shortMessage: Method doesn't override a method in a superclass due to the wrong package for parameter. Is this a mistake?
findingType.info:
The method in the subclass doesn't override a similar method in a superclass because the type of a parameter doesn't exactly match the type of the corresponding parameter in the superclass. For example, if you have

import org.alpha.Foo;

public class A {
  public int f(Foo x) {
    return 17;
  }
}

and

import org.beta.Foo;

public class B extends A {
  public int f(Foo x) { // Bad!
    return 42;
  }
}

The f(Foo) method defined in class B doesn't override the f(Foo) method defined in class A, because the argument types are Foo's from different packages.

In JDK 1.5 or above it is possible to have the compiler warn about this problem by annotating the f(Foo) method in B with @Override. The below would not compile due to this issue.

import org.beta.Foo;

public class B extends A {
  @Override public int f(Foo x) {
    return 42;
  }
}

findingType.name: Ignored return value
findingType.shortMessage: This code ignores the return value of a invoked method. This is a bad practice. Did the method accomplish what it was suppose to?
findingType.info: This method returns a value that is not checked. For example, the File.delete() method returns false if the file could not be successfully deleted rather than throwing an Exception. If you don't check the result, you won't notice if the method invocation signals unexpected behavior by returning an atypical return value.

findingType.name: Exception not thrown
findingType.shortMessage: Exception created and dropped rather than thrown. Did you forget to throw the exception?
findingType.info:
This code creates an exception (or error) object, but doesn't do anything with it. For example, something like 

if (x < 0) {
  new IllegalArgumentException("x must be nonnegative");
}

In this type of situation, it was probably the intent of the programmer to throw the created exception. For example

if (x < 0) {
  throw new IllegalArgumentException("x must be nonnegative");
}

findingType.name: Unrelated types compared using ==
findingType.shortMessage: This code appears to be using pointer equality to compare different types. Is this a logic error?
findingType.info:
This method uses using pointer equality to compare two references that seem to be of different types. The result of this comparison will always be false at runtime.

Examine this code carefully for logic errors.

findingType.name: Signed check of bitwise operation
findingType.shortMessage: This code checks for the sign of bitwise operation. Consider using != 0 instead.
findingType.info:
This code uses an expression such as

((event.detail & SWT.SELECTED) > 0)

Using bit arithmetic and then comparing the result with the greater-than operator can lead to unexpected results. The result depends on the value of SWT.SELECTED. If SWT.SELECTED is a negative number, then this code may not behave as expected. Even when SWT.SELECTED is not negative, it is good practice to use

((event.detail & SWT.SELECTED) != 0)

instead of > 0.

findingType.name: Lazy initialization and update of a static field
findingType.shortMessage: Incorrect lazy initialization and update of static field. This code may not be safe.
findingType.info: This method contains an unsynchronized lazy initialization of a static field. After the field is set, the object stored into that location is further accessed. The setting of the field is visible to other threads as soon as it is set. If the further accesses in the method that set the field serve to initialize the object, then you have a very serious multithreading bug, unless something else prevents any other thread from accessing the stored object until it is fully initialized.

findingType.name: Dead store of class literal
findingType.shortMessage: Dead store of a class literal. Are you trying to force class initialization?
findingType.info:
This instruction assigns a class literal to a variable and then never uses it. The behavior of this code differs in Java 1.4 and in Java 5. In Java 1.4 and earlier, a reference to Foo.class would force the static initializer for Foo to be executed, if it has not been executed already. In Java 5 and later, it does not.

For more information please see Sun's article on Java SE compatibility for more details and examples, and suggestions on how to force class initialization in Java 5.

findingType.name: Always value used where never required
findingType.shortMessage: A value annotated as carrying a type qualifier is used where a value that must not carry that qualifier is required.
findingType.info:
A value specified as carrying a type qualifier annotation is consumed in a location or locations requiring that the value not carry that annotation.

More precisely, a value annotated with a type qualifier specifying when=ALWAYS is guaranteed to reach a use or uses where the same type qualifier specifies when=NEVER.

For example, say that @NonNegative is a nickname for the type qualifier annotation @Negative(when=When.NEVER). The following code will generate this warning because the return statement requires a @NonNegative value, but receives one that is marked as @Negative.

public @NonNegative Integer example(@Negative Integer value) {
  return value;
}

findingType.name: Never value used where always required
findingType.shortMessage: A value annotated as never carrying a type qualifier is used where a value carrying that qualifier is required.
findingType.info:
A value specified as not carrying a type qualifier annotation is guaranteed to be consumed in a location or locations requiring that the value does carry that annotation.

More precisely, a value annotated with a type qualifier specifying when=NEVER is guaranteed to reach a use or uses where the same type qualifier specifies when=ALWAYS.

For example, say that @NonNegative is a nickname for the type qualifier annotation @Negative(when=When.NEVER). The following code will generate this warning because the return statement requires a @Negative value, but receives one that is marked as @NonNegative.

public @Negative Integer example(@NonNegative Integer value) {
  return value;
}

findingType.name: Maybe source value reaches always sink
findingType.shortMessage: A value that might not carry a type qualifier reaches a use requiring that type qualifier.
findingType.info:
