A value that might not carry a type qualifier annotation reaches a use which requires that annotation.

For example, consider the following method:

public @Untainted Object mustReturnUntainted(Object unknown) {
  return unknown;
}

The mustReturnUntainted method is required to return a value carrying the @Untainted annotation, but a value not known to carry that annotation is returned.

findingType.name: Maybe source value reaches never sink
findingType.shortMessage: An unknown value reaches a use which forbids values carrying type qualifier annotation.
findingType.info: A value which might carry a type qualifier annotation reaches a use which forbids values carrying that annotation.

findingType.name: Boolean-typed method returns null
findingType.shortMessage: A method with Boolean return type returns an explicit null value. This is a poor practice.
findingType.info: This method seems to be able to return null. This is considered a bad practice because it can be invoked as though it returned a value of type boolean, and the compiler will insert automatic unboxing of the Boolean value. If a null value is returned, a NullPointerException will be thrown when unboxing occurs.

findingType.name: Suspicious attempt to append to an ObjectOutputStream
findingType.shortMessage: This code appears to be trying to append to an ObjectOutputStream. This may not work, check this code carefully.
findingType.info:
This code opens a file in append mode and then wraps the result in an ObjectOutputStream. This approach does not allow you to append to an existing object output stream stored in the file. If you want to be able to append to an existing object output stream, you need to keep the object output stream open.

The only situation in which opening a file in append mode and then writing an object output stream could work is if on reading the file you plan to open it in random access mode and seek to the byte offset where the append started.

findingType.name: Mismatch of format string arguments and placeholder
findingType.shortMessage: The number of format-string arguments does not correspond to number of placeholders. Is this a coding error?
findingType.info: This code calls a format-string method with a variable number of arguments, but the number of arguments passed does not match with the number of % placeholders in the format string. This is probably not what the author intended. Examine this code carefully and fix the mistake.

findingType.name: Servlet cross-site scripting vulnerability
findingType.shortMessage: HTTP parameter directly written to Servlet output. This could create a security vulnerability.
findingType.info:
This code directly writes an HTTP parameter to Servlet output, which may create the possibility for a cross-site scripting vulnerability.

Please see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross-site_scripting for more information about this vulnerability.

findingType.name: JSP cross-site scripting vulnerability
findingType.shortMessage: An HTTP parameter directly written to JSP output. This could create a security vulnerability.
findingType.info:
This code directly writes an HTTP parameter to JSP output, which may create the possibility for a cross-site scripting vulnerability.

Please see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross-site_scripting for more information about this vulnerability.

findingType.name: Equals() doesn't override inherited equals(Object)
findingType.shortMessage: This code defines an equals() method that doesn't override the inherited equals(Object) method. Is this a mistake?
findingType.info: This class defines an equals() method, that doesn't override the normal equals(Object) method defined by java.lang.Object. Instead, it inherits an equals(Object) method from a superclass. The class should probably define a boolean equals(Object) method.

findingType.name: Possible null dereference on an infeasible path
findingType.shortMessage: This code contains a null pointer dereference on path that seems infeasible. Check that this code is correct.
findingType.info:
There is a branch of statements that, if executed, guarantees that a null value will be dereferenced, which would generate a NullPointerException when the code is executed.

Of course, the problem might be that the branch or statement is infeasible and that the null pointer exception can't ever be executed; deciding that is beyond the ability of the analysis. Due to the fact that this value had been previously tested for nullness, this is a definite possibility.

findingType.name: HTTP response splitting vulnerability
findingType.shortMessage: This code takes an HTTP parameter and writes it directly to the HTTP header output. This could create a security vulnerability.
findingType.info:
This code directly writes an HTTP parameter to an HTTP header, which allows for a HTTP response splitting vulnerability.

Please see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP_response_splitting for more information about this issue.

findingType.name: HTTP cookie formed from untrusted input
findingType.shortMessage: This code forms an HTTP cookie formed from untrusted input. This could create a security vulnerability.
findingType.info:
This code constructs an HTTP cookie using an untrusted HTTP parameter. If this cookie is added to an HTTP response, it will allow a HTTP response splitting vulnerability.

Please see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP_response_splitting for more information about this issue.

findingType.name: Class defines clone but does not implement Cloneable
findingType.shortMessage: This class defines clone() but doesn't implement Cloneable. Is this intended?
findingType.info: This class defines a clone() method but does not implement Cloneable. There are some situations in which this is OK (e.g., you want to control how subclasses can clone themselves), but just make sure that this is what you intended.

findingType.name: Hardcoded database password
findingType.shortMessage: This code uses a hardcoded constant password to connect to a database. Is this database secured?
findingType.info: This code creates a database connection using a hardcoded, constant password. Anyone with access to either the source code or the compiled code can easily learn the password. Check this code carefully as it may indicate a security problem with this code and its runtime environment.

findingType.name: Empty database password
findingType.shortMessage: This code uses an empty password to connect to a database. Is this database secured?
findingType.info: This code creates a database connection using a blank or empty password. This may indicate that the database is not protected by a password. Check this code carefully as it may indicate a security problem with this code and its runtime environment.

findingType.name: Synchronization on Boolean could deadlock
findingType.shortMessage: Synchronization on a Boolean value could lead to deadlock.
findingType.info:
This code code synchronizes on a boxed primitive constant, such as an Boolean.

private static Boolean inited = Boolean.FALSE;
...
public void m() {
  ...
  synchronized(inited) { // Bad!
    if (!inited) {
      init();
      inited = BOOLEAN.TRUE;
    }
  }
}

Since there normally exist only two Boolean objects, this code could be synchronizing on the same object as other, unrelated code, leading to unresponsiveness and possible deadlock.

For the example code above it is highly recommended that an AtomicBoolean from the java.util.concurrent.atomic package be used. For example,

import java.util.concurrent.atomic.AtomicBoolean;

private final AtomicBoolean inited = new AtomicBoolean(false);
...
public void m() {
  ...		
  if (inited.compareAndSet(false, true)) {
    init();
  }
}

findingType.name: Synchronization on boxed primitive value could lead to deadlock
findingType.shortMessage: This code synchronizes on boxed primitive value. This could lead to deadlock. Consider using a util concurrent atomic type instead.
findingType.info:
The code synchronizes on a boxed primitive constant, such as an Integer. 

private static Integer count = 0;
...
void m() {
  synchronized(count) { 
    count++;
  }
  ...
}

Since Integer objects can be cached and shared, this code could be synchronizing on the same object as other, unrelated code, leading to unresponsiveness and possible deadlock.

Consider using one of the atomic types provided by the package java.util.concurrent.atomic. For example, using AtomicInteger the above code would become

private final AtomicInteger count = new AtomicInteger(0);
...
void m() {
  final int incrementedCount = count.incrementAndGet();
  ...
}

findingType.name: Avoid synchronization on boxed primitive values
findingType.shortMessage: This code synchronizes on boxed primitive values. It is recommended that this type of code be avoided.
findingType.info:
The code synchronizes on an apparently unshared boxed primitive, such as an Integer.

private static final Integer fileLock = new Integer(1);
...
void m() {
  synchronized(fileLock) { 
    // do something
  }
  ...
}

It would be much better, in this code, to redeclare fileLock as

private static final Object fileLock = new Object();

The existing code might be OK, but it is confusing and a future refactoring, such as the "Remove Boxing" refactoring in IntelliJ, might replace this with the use of an intern'd Integer object shared throughout the JVM, leading to very confusing behavior and the potential for deadlock.

findingType.name: Synchronization on getClass() rather than a class literal
findingType.shortMessage: This code uses synchronization on getClass (the dynamic class) rather than a class literal. This can create a data race if the class is subclassed.
findingType.info:
This instance method synchronizes on this.getClass(). If this class is subclassed, subclasses will synchronize on the class object for the subclass, which isn't likely what was intended. For example, consider this code from java.awt.Label:

private static final String base = "label";
private static int nameCounter = 0;

String constructComponentName() {
  synchronized (getClass()) {
    return base + nameCounter++;
  }
}

Subclasses of Label won't synchronize on the same subclass, giving rise to a data race. Instead, this code should be synchronizing on Label.class

private static final String base = "label";
private static int nameCounter = 0;

String constructComponentName() {
  synchronized (Label.class) {
    return base + nameCounter++;
  }
}

In general, it is almost always a bad idea to synchronize on the dynamic class of an object.

findingType.name: Synchronization on field in futile attempt to guard that field
findingType.shortMessage: Synchronization on a mutable field in a futile attempt to guard that field. This code is likely not thread safe.
findingType.info:
This method synchronizes on a mutable field in what appears to be a misguided attempt to guard against simultaneous updates to that field. But guarding a field gets a lock on the referenced object, not on the field. This may not provide the mutual exclusion you need, and other threads might be obtaining locks on the referenced objects (for other purposes). An example of this pattern would be: 

private Long myNtfSeqNbrCounter = new Long(0);
private Long getNotificationSequenceNumber() {
  Long result = null;
  synchronized(myNtfSeqNbrCounter) {
    result = new Long(myNtfSeqNbrCounter.longValue() + 1);
    myNtfSeqNbrCounter = new Long(result.longValue());
  }
  return result;
}

One approach to fixing this problem is to create an immutable object to lock on. For example

private Long myNtfSeqNbrCounter = new Long(0);
private final Object myNtfSeqNbrCounterLock = new Object();

private Long getNotificationSequenceNumber() {
  Long result = null;
  synchronized(myNtfSeqNbrCounterLock) {
    result = new Long(myNtfSeqNbrCounter.longValue() + 1);
    myNtfSeqNbrCounter = new Long(result.longValue());
  }
  return result;
}

findingType.name: Useless assignment in return statement
findingType.shortMessage: This code contains a useless assignment in a return statement. Is this a mistake?
findingType.info: This statement assigns to a local variable in a return statement. This assignment has no lasting effect. Please verify that this statement does the right thing as this could signpost a bug.

findingType.name: Servlet reflected cross-site scripting vulnerability
findingType.shortMessage: This Servlet seems to have a cross-site scripting vulnerability. This should be examined carefully and eliminated.
findingType.info:
This code directly writes an HTTP parameter to a server error page using HttpServletResponse.sendError. Echoing this untrusted input allows for a reflected cross-site scripting vulnerability.

For more information please see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross-site_scripting.

This analysis looks only for the most blatant, obvious cases of cross-site scripting.

findingType.name: Class too big for analysis
findingType.shortMessage: This class is too big for analysis. It could not be checked by FindBugs.
findingType.info: This class is bigger than can be effectively handled, and was not fully analyzed for errors by FindBugs.

findingType.name: Equals() compares class names
findingType.shortMessage: This equals compares class names rather than class objects. Just compare the class objects.
findingType.info:
This equals method checks to see if two objects are the same class by checking to see if the names of their classes are equal. You can have different classes with the same name if they are loaded by different class loaders. Just check to see if the class objects are the same. For example

this.getClass() == o.getClass()

For more information see Bloch's Effective Java (second edition) items 8 and 9.

findingType.name: Unusual equals() method
findingType.shortMessage: This is an unusual equals() method. It might be OK but is worth checking.
findingType.info:
This class doesn't do any of the patterns we recognize for checking that the type of the argument is compatible with the type of the this object. There might not be anything wrong with this code, but it is worth reviewing.

For more information see Bloch's Effective Java (second edition) items 8 and 9.

findingType.name: Equals() fails for subtypes
findingType.shortMessage: This equals method will fail for subtypes. Consider making it more robust.
findingType.info:
This class has an equals method that will be broken if it is inherited by subclasses. It compares a class literal with the class of the argument, e.g., in class Foo it might check if Foo.class == o.getClass(). It is better to check if this.getClass() == o.getClass().

For more information see Bloch's Effective Java (second edition) items 8 and 9.

findingType.name: Equals() always returns true
findingType.shortMessage: This equals method always returns true. This violates the symmetric property of the equals method.
findingType.info:
This class defines an equals method that always returns true. This is imaginative, but not very smart. Plus, it means that the equals method is not symmetric. It is not at all clear what semantics are intended here and this class will likely cause problems if placed inside of a collection.

For more information see Bloch's Effective Java (second edition) items 8 and 9.

findingType.name: Equals() always returns false
findingType.shortMessage: This equals method always returns false. This violates the reflexive requirement of the equals method.
findingType.info:
This class defines an equals method that always returns false. This means that an object is not equal to itself, and it is impossible to create useful Maps or Sets of this class.

More fundamentally, it means that equals is not reflexive, one of the requirements of the equals method.

The likely intended semantics are object identity—that an object is equal to itself. This is the behavior inherited from java.lang.Object. If you need to override an equals inherited from a different superclass, you can use:

@Override public boolean equals(Object o) {
  return this == o;
}

For more information see Bloch's Effective Java (second edition) items 8 and 9.

findingType.name: Avoid mutable servlet fields
findingType.shortMessage: This code contains a mutable servlet field that could cause race conditions. Remove this field or make it immutable.
findingType.info: A web server generally only creates one instance of a servlet or JSP class (i.e., it treats the class as a singleton), and will have multiple threads invoke methods on that instance to service multiple simultaneous requests. Thus, having a mutable instance field generally creates race conditions. It is recommended that this field be removed or made immutable.

findingType.name: Ignored static readResolve() method
findingType.shortMessage: The readResolve() method must not be declared to be static. It will be ignored by the serialization mechanism.
findingType.info: In order for the readResolve method to be recognized by the serialization mechanism, it must not be declared as a static method.

findingType.name: Private readResolve() is not inherited
findingType.shortMessage: private readResolve() is not inherited by subclasses.
findingType.info:
This class defines a private readResolve method. Since it is private, it won't be inherited by subclasses.

This might be intentional and OK, but should be reviewed to ensure it is what is intended.

findingType.name: Suspicious repeated conditional test
findingType.shortMessage: This repeated conditional test is suspicious and may indicate a typo in the code.
findingType.info:
The code contains a conditional test is performed twice, one right after the other. For example

x == 0 || x == 0

Perhaps this is a typo and the the second occurrence is intended to be something else, such as

x == 0 || y == 0

findingType.name: Futile attempt to change max pool size of ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor
findingType.shortMessage: This code seems to make a futile attempt to change the max pool size of a ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor. This is probably a mistake.
findingType.info:
While ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor inherits from ThreadPoolExecutor, a few of the inherited tuning methods are not useful for it. In particular, because it acts as a fixed-sized pool using corePoolSize threads and an unbounded queue, adjustments to maximumPoolSize have no useful effect.

This code appears to be trying to use these useless inherited methods.

For more information, please see the corresponding Javadoc.

findingType.name: Avoid creation of ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor with zero core threads
findingType.shortMessage: Creation of a ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor with zero core threads. This is probably a mistake.
findingType.info:
A ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor with zero core threads will never execute anything; changes to the max pool size are ignored. Check this code carefully and fix this problem.

For more information, please see the corresponding Javadoc.

findingType.name: Call to an unsupported method
findingType.shortMessage: Call to an unsupported method
findingType.info: All targets of this method invocation throw an UnsupportedOperationException. Examine this code carefully and consider if it is correct.

findingType.name: Avoid equals() check for incompatible operand
findingType.shortMessage: This equals implementation checks to see if the operand is some particular incompatible type. This is not recommended and may create unexpected behaviors.
findingType.info:
This equals method is checking to see if the argument is some incompatible type (i.e., a class that is neither a supertype nor subtype of the class that defines the equals method). For example, the Foo class might have an equals method that looks like: 

@Override public boolean equals(Object o) {
  if (o instanceof Foo)
    return name.equals(((Foo)o).name);
  else if (o instanceof String)
    return name.equals(o);
  else return false;

This is considered bad practice, as it makes it very hard to implement an equals method that is symmetric and transitive. Without those properties, very unexpected behaviors are possible.

findingType.name: Parameter must be nonnull but is marked as nullable
findingType.shortMessage: This parameter must be nonnull but is marked as nullable. Either the use or the annotation is wrong.
findingType.info: This parameter is always used in a way that requires it to be nonnull, but the parameter is explicitly annotated as being @Nullable. Either the use of the parameter or the annotation is wrong.

findingType.name: The type of a supplied argument doesn't match format specifier
findingType.shortMessage: The type of a supplied argument doesn't match format specifier. This code will always throw an exception at runtime.
findingType.info:
One of the arguments is incompatible with the corresponding format string specifier. As a result, this will generate a runtime exception when executed. For example,

String.format("%d", "1")

will throw an exception, since the string "1" is incompatible with the format specifier %d.

findingType.name: Non-Boolean argument formatted using %b format specifier
findingType.shortMessage: A non-Boolean argument is being formatted using %b format specifier. This is probably a typo or a bug.
findingType.info: An argument not of type Boolean is being formatted with a %b format specifier. This won't throw an exception; instead, it will print true for any nonnull value, and false for null. This feature of format strings is strange, and may not be what you intended.

findingType.name: Array formatted in useless way using format string
findingType.shortMessage: Array formatted in useless way using format string
findingType.info:
One of the arguments being formatted with a format string is an array. This will be formatted using a fairly useless format, such as [I@304282, which doesn't actually show the contents of the array. This behavior is probably not desired.

Consider wrapping the array using Arrays.asList(...) before handling it off to be formatted or using Arrays.toString(...).

findingType.name: No previous argument for format string
findingType.shortMessage: No previous argument for format string. This code will always throw an exception at runtime.
findingType.info:
The format string specifies a relative index to request that the argument for the previous format specifier be reused. However, there is no previous argument. For example,

formatter.format("%<s %s", "a", "b")

would throw a MissingFormatArgumentException when executed.

findingType.name: Format string placeholder incompatible with passed argument
findingType.shortMessage: This format string placeholder is incompatible with its passed argument. This code will always throw an exception at runtime.
findingType.info:
The format string placeholder is incompatible with the corresponding argument. For example, 

System.out.println("%d\n", "hello");

The %d placeholder requires a numeric argument, but a string value is passed instead. A runtime exception will occur when this statement is executed.

findingType.name: Too few arguments are passed for this format string
findingType.shortMessage: This code contains a format string that is passed too few arguments. This code will always throw an exception at runtime.
findingType.info: Not enough arguments are passed to satisfy a placeholder in the format string. A runtime exception will occur when this statement is executed.

findingType.name: Illegal format string
findingType.shortMessage: This code contains an illegal format string. This code will always throw an exception at runtime.
findingType.info: The format string used in this code is syntactically invalid, and a runtime exception will occur when this statement is executed. Examine and fix this code.

findingType.name: More arguments are passed than are actually used in the format string
findingType.shortMessage: This code passes more arguments than are actually used in the format string. This is probably a typo or a bug.
findingType.info: A format-string method with a variable number of arguments is called, but more arguments are passed than are actually used by the format string. This won't cause a runtime exception, but the code may be silently omitting information that was intended to be included in the formatted string. Check this code carefully.

findingType.name: Bitwise add of signed byte value
findingType.shortMessage: This code performs a suspicious bitwise add of signed byte value. Sign extension may cause an unexpected result to be computed.
findingType.info:
Adds a byte value and a value which is known to have its 8 lower bits clear. Values loaded from a byte array are sign extended to 32 bits before any any bitwise operations are performed on the value. Thus, if b[0] contains the value 0xff, and x is initially 0, then the code ((x << 8) + b[0]) will sign extend 0xff to get 0xffffffff, and thus give the value 0xffffffff as the result.

In particular, the following code for packing a byte array into an int is badly wrong:

int result = 0;
for(int i = 0; i < 4; i++) {
  result = ((result << 8) + b[i]);
}

However, the following idiom will work instead:

int result = 0;
for(int i = 0; i < 4; i++) {
  result = ((result << 8) + (b[i] & 0xff));
}

findingType.name: Suspicious use hashCode() method on an array
findingType.shortMessage: This code calls a.hashCode() on an array. Did you mean to call Arrays.hashCode(a)?
findingType.info:
This code invokes hashCode() on an array type. Calling hashCode() on an array returns the same value as System.identityHashCode, and ignores the contents and length of the array. Therefore, this code is highly suspect and may not do what the programmer intended it to.

If you need a hashcode that depends on the contents of an array a, use java.util.Arrays.hashCode(a).

findingType.name: Avoid c.removeAll(c) to clear a collection
findingType.shortMessage: Don't use c.removeAll(c) to clear a collection. Use c.clear() instead.
findingType.info: If you want to remove all elements from a collection c, use c.clear() rather than c.removeAll(c).

findingType.name: Vacuous call to a collection
findingType.shortMessage: This code appears to be nonsensical. Consider removing it. It may indicate a type or a bug.
findingType.info:
This call doesn't make sense. For any Collection c, calling

c.containsAll(c)

should always be true, and

c.retainAll(c)

should have no effect.

This is highly suspicious code that may signpost a bug or a typo.

findingType.name: Collections should not contain themselves
findingType.shortMessage: Collections should not contain themselves
findingType.info: This call to a generic collection's method would only make sense if a collection contained itself, e.g., if s.contains(s) were true. This is unlikely to be true and would cause problems if it were true (such as the computation of the hash code of such a collection resulting in infinite recursion). It is likely that the wrong value is being passed as a parameter.

findingType.name: Explicit annotation inconsistent with use
findingType.shortMessage: Explicit annotation is inconsistent with use.
findingType.info: A value is used in a way that requires it to be never be a value denoted by a type qualifier, but there is an explicit annotation stating that it is not known where the value is prohibited from having that type qualifier. Either the usage or the annotation is incorrect.

findingType.name: Explicit annotation inconsistent with use
findingType.shortMessage: Explicit annotation is inconsistent with use.
findingType.info: A value is used in a way that requires it to be always be a value denoted by a type qualifier, but there is an explicit annotation stating that it is not known where the value is required to have that type qualifier. Either the usage or the annotation is incorrect.

findingType.name: Method may fail to clean up stream or resource
findingType.shortMessage: Method may fail to clean up stream or resource
findingType.info:
This method may fail to clean up (close, dispose of) a stream, database object, or other resource requiring an explicit cleanup operation.

In general, if a method opens a stream or other resource, the method should use a try/finally block to ensure that the stream or resource is cleaned up before the method returns. For example, the code below properly closes its reader in a finally block.

try {
  final BufferedReader in = new BufferedReader(new FileReader("data.txt"));
  try {
    String str;
    while ((str = in.readLine()) != null) {
      System.out.println(str);
    }
  } finally {
    in.close();
  }
} catch (IOException e) {
  e.printStackTrace();
}

See Weimer and Necula, Finding and Preventing Run-Time Error Handling Mistakes, for a description of the analysis technique.

findingType.name: Empty initializer
findingType.shortMessage: It is questionable coding practice to have an empty initializer.
findingType.info:
It is highly questionable to have an empty initializer. Consider removing it from your code.

public class Foo {
  static {} // Why ?
  {} // Again, why ?
}

findingType.name: Empty catch block
findingType.shortMessage: Are you swallowing an exception which should either be acted on or reported?
findingType.info:
An exception is caught, but nothing is done. In most circumstances, this swallows an exception which should either be acted on or reported.

public void doSomething() {
  try {
    FileInputStream fis = new FileInputStream("/tmp/bugger");
  } catch (IOException ioe) {
      // not good
  }
}

findingType.name: Empty if
findingType.shortMessage: It is questionable coding practice to have an empty if statement.
findingType.info:
A condition is being checked but nothing is done about it. Consider removing the check if it doesn't have side-effects.

If the check has side-effects just call the check and ignore the result. For example, if (sideEffect()) {} would be replaced with sideEffect().

public class Foo {
  void bar(int x) {
    if (x == 0) {
      // empty!
    }
  }
}

findingType.name: Empty while
findingType.shortMessage: It is questionable coding practice to have an empty while statement.
findingType.info:
This while statement appears to do nothing. If it is a timing loop, then you should use Thread.sleep() for it; if it's a while loop that does a lot in the exit expression, then consider rewriting it to make what it is doing clearer.

public class Foo {
  void bar(int a, int b) {
    while (a == b) {
      // empty!
    }
   }
}

findingType.name: Empty try block
findingType.shortMessage: It is questionable coding practice to have an empty try block.
findingType.info:
This try block is empty. It should be removed from the code.

public class Foo {
  public void bar() {
    try {
    } catch (Exception e) {
      e.printStackTrace();
    }
  }
}

findingType.name: Empty finally block
findingType.shortMessage: It is questionable coding practice to have an empty finally block.
findingType.info:
This finally block is empty. It should be removed from the code.

public class Foo {
  public void bar() {
    try {
      int x=2;
    } finally {
      // empty!
    }
  }
}

findingType.name: Empty switch
findingType.shortMessage: It is questionable coding practice to have an empty switch statement.
findingType.info:
This switch statement is empty. Consider removing it from the code.

public class Foo {
  public void bar() {
    int x = 2;
    switch (x) {
      // once there was code here
      // but it's been commented out or something
    }
  }
}

findingType.name: Jumbled incrementer
findingType.shortMessage: Avoid jumbled loop incrementers because it's usually a mistake.
findingType.info:
Avoid jumbled loop incrementers—it's usually a mistake, and it's confusing even if it's what's intended.

public class JumbledIncrementerRule1 {
  public void foo() {
    for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
      for (int k = 0; k < 20; i++) {
        System.out.println("Hello");
      }
    }
  }
}

findingType.name: For should be a while
findingType.shortMessage: This for loop can be simplified to a while loop.
findingType.info:
This loop can be simplified to a while and made more concise.

public class Foo {
  void bar() {
    for (;true;) true; // No Init or Update part, may as well be: while (true)
  }
}

findingType.name: Return from within finally block
findingType.shortMessage: It is questionable coding practice to return from a finally block because this can discard exceptions.
findingType.info:
It is questionable coding practice to return from a finally block because this can discard exceptions.

public class Bar {
  public String foo() {
    try {
      throw new Exception( "My Exception" );
    } catch (Exception e) {
      throw e;
    } finally {
      return "A. O. K."; // Very bad.
    }
  }
}

For more information on this issue see puzzle 36 of Bloch and Gafter's Java Puzzlers.

findingType.name: Unnecessary return
findingType.shortMessage: Avoid unnecessary return statements
findingType.info:
It is questionable coding practice to place a return statement where the method would simply return without it. This unnecessary return can be removed from your code.

public class Foo { public void bar() { int x = 42; return; } }

findingType.name: Unconditional if
findingType.shortMessage: Avoid if statements that are always true or always false. Can this be removed?
findingType.info:
It is questionable coding practice to have an if statement that is always true or always false. Unless this is test code (or some other special purpose code) the if can be removed. Just remove the if and keep the block if the statement was always true. Delete both the conditional and the block if the statement was always false.

public class Foo {
  public void close() {
    if (true) {
      // ...
    }
  }
}

findingType.name: Empty statement not in loop
findingType.shortMessage: It is questionable coding practice to include an empty statement, i.e., a semicolon by itself. Consider removing this empty statement.
findingType.info:
It is questionable coding practice to include an empty statement, i.e., a semicolon by itself, that is not used as the sole body of a for loop or while loop. This could also be a double semicolon, which is useless and should be removed.

public class MyClass {
  public void doit() {
    // this is probably not what you meant to do
    ;
    // the extra semicolon here this is not necessary
    System.out.println("look at the extra semicolon");;
  }
}

findingType.name: Unnecessary final modifier
findingType.shortMessage: This class has the final modifier, therefore all of its methods are automatically final.
findingType.info:
This class has the final modifier, therefore all of its methods are automatically final. Any final declarations on methods may be removed.

public final class Foo {
   // This final modifier is not necessary, since the class is final
   // and thus, all methods are final
   private final void foo() {
   }
}

findingType.name: Collapsible if
findingType.shortMessage: Sometimes two if statements can be consolidated by separating their conditions with a boolean short-circuit operator.
findingType.info:
Sometimes two if statements can be consolidated by separating their conditions with a boolean short-circuit operator. For example, the below code

if (x) {
  if (y) {
    // do stuff
  }
}

can be changed to

if (x && y) {
  // do stuff
}

When making this change ensure that the expression y has no side-effects.

findingType.name: Useless overriding method
findingType.shortMessage: This overriding method merely calls the same method defined in a superclass. It should simply inherit the method.
findingType.info:
This overriding method merely calls the same method defined in a superclass.

@Override public String foo() {
  return super.foo();  // Why bother overriding?
}

It is strongly recommended that you remove this method and simply inherit the method from the superclass. This problem may indicate a lack of understanding about how inheritance works in the Java programming language.

findingType.name: Avoid decimal literals in BigDecimal construction
findingType.shortMessage: Use of float or double literals when construction BigDecimal instances can result in imprecision. Use the String argument constructor instead..
findingType.info:
One might assume that new BigDecimal(.1) is exactly equal to .1, but it is actually equal to .1000000000000000055511151231257827021181583404541015625. This is the case because .1 cannot be represented exactly as a double (or, for that matter, as a binary fraction of any finite length). Thus, the long value that is being passed in to the constructor is not exactly equal to .1, appearances notwithstanding.

The String argument constructor, on the other hand, is perfectly predictable: new BigDecimal(".1") is exactly equal to .1, as one would expect. Therefore, it is generally recommended that the String argument constructor be used in preference to this one.

findingType.name: Ignored operation on an immutable object
findingType.shortMessage: An operation on an Immutable object (e.g., a BigDecimal or a BigInteger) won't change the object itself. Thus, ignoring the result is probably an error.
findingType.info:
An operation on an immutable object (e.g., a BigDecimal or a BigInteger) won't change the object itself. The result of the operation is a new object. Therefore, ignoring the operation result is probably a mistake.

import java.math.*;
class Test {
  void method1() {
    BigDecimal bd=new BigDecimal(10);
    bd.add(new BigDecimal(5));      // this will trigger the rule
  }
  void method2() {
    BigDecimal bd=new BigDecimal(10);
    bd = bd.add(new BigDecimal(5)); // this won't trigger the rule
  }
}

findingType.name: Unused null check before equals()
findingType.shortMessage: After checking an object reference for null, you should invoke equals() on that object rather than passing it to another object's equals() method.
findingType.info:
After checking an object reference for null, you should invoke equals() on that object rather than passing it to another object's equals() method.

public class Example {

  public String method1() { return "ok";}
  public String method2() { return null;}

  public void method(String a) {
    String b;
    /*
     * I don't know if method1() can be "null" but I know "a" is not null...
     * I'd better write a.equals(method1())
     */
    if (a != null && method1().equals(a)) { // will trigger the rule
      // do something
    }

    if (method1().equals(a) && a != null) { // won't trigger the rule
      // do something
    }

    if (a != null && method1().equals(b)) { // won't trigger the rule
      // do something
    }

    if (a != null && "LITERAL".equals(a)) { // won't trigger the rule
      // do something
    }

    if (a != null && !a.equals("go")) {     // won't trigger the rule
      a = method2();
      if (method1().equals(a)) {
        //do something
      }
    }
  }
}

findingType.name: Avoid ThreadGroup
findingType.shortMessage: It is best to avoid the use of ThreadGroup. Consider updating this code to use a util concurrent Executor.
findingType.info:
It is best to avoid the use of ThreadGroup. Although it is intended to be used in a threaded environment it contains methods that are not thread-safe.

public class Bar {
  void buz() {
    ThreadGroup tg = new ThreadGroup("My threadgroup");
    tg = new ThreadGroup(tg, "my thread group");
    tg = Thread.currentThread().getThreadGroup();
    tg = System.getSecurityManager().getThreadGroup();
  }
}

A better framework is provided by the util concurrent library found in the java.util.concurrent package. This library was added to JDK 1.5. In particular, the Exceutor framework is worth considering.

findingType.name: Broken null check expression
findingType.shortMessage: This null check appears to be broken since it can throw a NullPointerException. It is likely that you used || instead of && or vice versa.
findingType.info:
This null check appears to be broken since it can throw a NullPointerException. It is likely that you used || instead of && or vice versa.

class Foo {
  String bar(String string) {
    // should be &&
    if (string != null || !string.equals(""))
      return string;
    // should be ||
    if (string == null && string.equals(""))
      return string;
  }
}

findingType.name: Use BigInteger and BigDecimal constants
findingType.shortMessage: This code creates an instance of BigInteger or BigDecimal for which a constant exists. It is recommended that you use the constant instead of creating another object.
findingType.info:
There is no need to create instances of already existing BigInteger or BigDecimal objects.

// Don't do this -- use the defined constants
BigInteger bi = new BigInteger(1);
BigInteger bi2 = new BigInteger("0");
BigInteger bi3 = new BigInteger(0.0);
BigInteger bi4;
bi4 = new BigInteger(0);
bi4 = BigInteger.ZERO; // OK

Just use the predefined constants, such as BigInteger.ZERO, BigInteger.ONE, (and for 1.5 on) BigInteger.TEN, BigDecimal.ZERO, BigDecimal.ONE, and BigDecimal.TEN.

findingType.name: Avoid octal literals
findingType.shortMessage: Integer literals should not start with zero. Zero means that the rest of literal will be interpreted as an octal value which might not be what you want.
findingType.info:
Integer literals should not start with zero. Zero means that the rest of literal will be interpreted as an octal value which might not be what you want.

int i = 012;   // sets i to 10 not  12
int j = 010;   // sets j to  8 not  10
int k = i * j; // sets k to 80 not 120

If you really want the octal literal, it is recommended that it be commented very clearly to avoid programmer confusion.

findingType.name: If must use braces
findingType.shortMessage: Avoid if statements without curly braces.
findingType.info:
This rule flags all if statements that do not use curly braces because this has been deemed a questionable coding practice. To fix this change

if (expression)
  statement1;
else
  statement2;

to

if (expression) {
  statement1;
} else {
  statement2;
}

findingType.name: While must use braces
findingType.shortMessage: Avoid while loops without curly braces.
findingType.info:
This rule flags all while loops that do not use curly braces because this has been deemed a questionable coding practice. To fix this change

while (expression)
  statement;

to

while (expression) {
  statement;
}

findingType.name: For must use braces
findingType.shortMessage: Avoid for loops without curly braces.
findingType.info:
This rule flags all for loops that do not use curly braces because this has been deemed a questionable coding practice. To fix this change

for (e ; e ; e)
  statement;

to

for (e ; e ; e)
  statement;
}

findingType.name: Clone() method signature must include throws CloneNotSupportedException
findingType.shortMessage: This clone method does not declare that it can throw CloneNotSupportedException. Its signature appears to be wrong.
findingType.info:
The method clone has the wrong signature, it should throw a CloneNotSupportedException. So change the code below

public Object clone() { // will cause this finding to appear
  return super.clone();
}

to

public Object clone() throws CloneNotSupportedException {
  return super.clone();
}

findingType.name: High NPath complexity
findingType.shortMessage: This method has a high NPath complexity. Can you reduce its complexity?
findingType.info: The NPath complexity of a method is the number of acyclic execution paths through that method. A threshold of 200 is generally considered the point where measures should be taken to reduce complexity.

findingType.name: Excessive method length
findingType.shortMessage: This method is very long. Can you make it more concise?
findingType.info: Violations of this rule usually indicate that the method is doing too much. This may signpost a poor design. Try to reduce the method size by creating helper methods and removing any copy/pasted code.

findingType.name: Excessive parameter list
findingType.shortMessage: This method takes too many parameters. Can it be redesigned to take less?
findingType.info: Long parameter lists can indicate that a new object should be created to wrap the numerous parameters. Basically, try to group the parameters together.

findingType.name: Excessive class length
findingType.shortMessage: This class is very long. Can you make it more concise?
findingType.info: Long Class files are indications that the class may be trying to do too much. Try to break it down, and reduce the size to something manageable.

findingType.name: High cyclomatic complexity
findingType.shortMessage: This method has a high cyclomatic complexity. Can you reduce its complexity?
findingType.info: Complexity is determined by the number of decision points in a method plus one for the method entry. The decision points are if, while, for, and case labels. Generally, 1-4 is low complexity, 5-7 indicates moderate complexity, 8-10 is high complexity, and 11+ is very high complexity.

findingType.name: Excessive public count
findingType.shortMessage: This class has too many public methods and attributes. Can you reduce this number?
findingType.info: A large number of public methods and attributes declared in a class can indicate the class may need to be broken up as increased effort will be required to thoroughly test it.

findingType.name: Too many fields
findingType.shortMessage: This class has too many fields. Can you reduce this number?
findingType.info: Classes that have too many fields could be redesigned to have fewer fields, possibly through some nested object grouping of some of the information. For example, a class with city/state/zip fields could instead have one Address field.

findingType.name: NCSS method count
findingType.shortMessage: This rule uses the NCSS (Non Commenting Source Statements) algorithm to determine the number of lines of code for a given method.
findingType.info: This rule uses the NCSS (Non Commenting Source Statements) algorithm to determine the number of lines of code for a given method. NCSS ignores comments, and counts actual statements. Using this algorithm, lines of code that are split are counted as one.

findingType.name: NCSS type count
findingType.shortMessage: This rule uses the NCSS (Non Commenting Source Statements) algorithm to determine the number of lines of code for a given type.
findingType.info: This rule uses the NCSS (Non Commenting Source Statements) algorithm to determine the number of lines of code for a given type. NCSS ignores comments, and counts actual statements. Using this algorithm, lines of code that are split are counted as one.

findingType.name: NCSS constructor count
findingType.shortMessage: This rule uses the NCSS (Non Commenting Source Statements) algorithm to determine the number of lines of code for a given constructor.
findingType.info: This rule uses the NCSS (Non Commenting Source Statements) algorithm to determine the number of lines of code for a given constructor. NCSS ignores comments, and counts actual statements. Using this algorithm, lines of code that are split are counted as one.

findingType.name: Unnecessary constructor
findingType.shortMessage: This constructor is not required to be explicitly declared. You may remove it from your code and it will be automatically generated for you.
findingType.info: This rule detects when a constructor is not necessary; i.e., when there's only one constructor, it's public, has an empty body, and takes no arguments. In this case Java will generate a default constructor for you.

findingType.name: Null assignment warning
findingType.shortMessage: Null is being assigned to a variable which could indicate a muddled implementation.
findingType.info:
Assigning a null to a variable (outside of its declaration) is usually bad form. Some times, the assignment is an indication that the programmer doesn't completely understand what is going on in the code.

This sort of assignment may in rare cases be useful to encourage garbage collection. If that's what it's being using it for, by all means, disregard this finding.

findingType.name: Only one return
findingType.shortMessage: This method has more than one exit point or its one exit point is not the last statement in the method. This has been deemed a questionable coding practice.
findingType.info:
It has been determined that each method should have only one exit point, and that should be the last statement in the method.

public void foo(int x) {
  if (x > 0) {
    return "hey"; // oops, multiple exit points!
  }
  return "hi";
}

findingType.name: Superfluous method modifiers in an interface
findingType.shortMessage: This interface has superfluous modifiers on method declarations that are implied by their context.
findingType.info:
Fields in interfaces are automatically public static final, and methods are public abstract. Classes or interfaces nested in an interface are automatically public and static (all nested interfaces are automatically static). For historical reasons, modifiers which are implied by the context are accepted by the compiler, but are superfluous. Below are some examples.

public interface Foo {
  public abstract void bar();    // both abstract and public are ignored by the compiler
  public static final int X = 0; // public, static, and final all ignored
  public static class Bar {}     // public, static ignored
  public static interface Baz {} // ditto
}
public class Bar {
  public static interface Baz {} // static ignored
}

findingType.name: Avoid assignment in operand
findingType.shortMessage: This code makes an assignment in an operand. This has been deemed questionable coding practice because it can be complicated and hard to read.
findingType.info:
Avoid assignments in operands; this can make code more complicated and harder to read. Consider changing the below code

int x = 2;
if ((x = getX()) == 3) {
  System.out.println("3!");
}

to

int x = getX();
if (x == 3) {
  System.out.println("3!");
}

findingType.name: Have at least one constructor
findingType.shortMessage: This class does not have an explicit constructor. Consider adding one.
findingType.info:
This class lacks an explicit constructor. An implicit constructor has been generated for it by the compiler. If you consider this to be a bad coding practice then add an explicit constructor to this class.

public class Foo {
  // no explicit constructor!  not good!
}

findingType.name: Avoid import from sun.*
findingType.shortMessage: This class imports from the sun.* packages. This should be avoided because these packages are not portable and are likely to change.
findingType.info:
Avoid importing anything from the 'sun.*' packages because these packages are not portable and are likely to change.

import sun.misc.foo;
public class Foo {
  ...
}

findingType.name: Suspicious octal escape inside a string literal
findingType.shortMessage: This is a suspicious octal escape sequence inside a String literal. Is this what is intended?
findingType.info:
A suspicious octal escape sequence was found inside a String literal. The Java language specification (section 3.10.6) says an octal escape sequence inside a literal String shall consist of a backslash followed by:

OctalDigit | OctalDigit OctalDigit | ZeroToThree OctalDigit OctalDigit

Any octal escape sequence followed by non-octal digits can be confusing, e.g. "\038" is interpreted as the octal escape sequence \03 followed by the literal character 8.

public void foo() {
  // interpreted as octal 12, followed by the character '8'
  System.out.println("suspicious: \128");
}

See the Java Language Specification for further details.

findingType.name: Call super in all constructors
findingType.shortMessage: This constructor does not call super() explicitly.
findingType.info:
It is a good practice to call super() in a constructor. If super() is not called but another constructor (such as an overloaded constructor) is called, this rule will not report it.

public class Foo extends Bar{
  public Foo() {
    // call the constructor of Bar explicitly
    super(); // if this was missing this rule would complain
   }
   public Foo(int code) {
     this(); // no problem with this
     // do something with 'code'
   }
}

findingType.name: Unnecessary parentheses
findingType.shortMessage: This expression is wrapped in unnecessary parentheses, making it look like a function call.
findingType.info:
Sometimes expressions are wrapped in unnecessary parentheses, making them look like a function call. Consider removing the unnecessary parentheses.

For example, consider changing

public boolean bar() {
  return (true); // Bad!
}

to

public boolean bar() {
  return true;
}

findingType.name: Singular field
findingType.shortMessage: This field is only used by one method. Can it be replaced by a local variable?
findingType.info: A field that's only used by one method could perhaps be replaced by a local variable.

findingType.name: Use boolean inversion
findingType.shortMessage: Use bitwise inversion to invert this boolean value; it's the fastest way to do this.
findingType.info:
Use bitwise inversion to invert boolean values—it's the fastest way to do this.

boolean b = true;
b = !b;    // slow
b ^= true; // fast

See Speed-kings of inverting booleans by Dr. Heinz M. Kabutz for more details. It also may be prudent to check this result on your particular JVM.

findingType.name: Dataflow anomaly analysis
findingType.shortMessage: An anomaly has been detected via PMD dataflow analysis.
findingType.info:
The dataflow analysis tracks local definitions, undefinitions and references to variables on different paths on the data flow. From those informations there can be found various problems.

  1. UR - Anomaly: There is a reference to a variable that was not defined before. This is a bug and leads to an error.
  2. DU - Anomaly: A recently defined variable is undefined. These anomalies may appear in normal source text.
  3. DD - Anomaly: A recently defined variable is redefined. This is ominous but don't have to be a bug.

findingType.name: Coupling between objects
findingType.shortMessage: This class seems to have a high number of unique attributes, local variables and return types within an object. This can indicate a high degree of coupling. Can you reduce its coupling?
findingType.info: This rule counts unique attributes, local variables and return types within an object. A number higher than specified threshold can indicate a high degree of coupling.

findingType.name: Excessive imports
findingType.shortMessage: This class has too many imports. Can you reduce this count?
findingType.info: A high number of imports can indicate a high degree of coupling within an object. Rule counts the number of unique imports and reports a violation if the count is above the defined threshold.

findingType.name: Loose coupling violation
findingType.shortMessage: Avoid using implementation types (i.e., HashSet); use the interface (i.e, Set) instead.
findingType.info:
Avoid using implementation types (i.e., HashSet); use the interface (i.e, Set) instead.

import java.util.*;
public class Bar {
  // Use List instead
  private ArrayList list = new ArrayList();
  // Use Set instead
  public HashSet getFoo() {
    return new HashSet();
  }
}

findingType.name: Use singleton pattern
findingType.shortMessage: Consider refactoring this class to be a singleton.
findingType.info:
If you have a class that has nothing but static methods, consider making it a singleton. Note that this doesn't apply to abstract classes, since their subclasses may well include non-static methods. Also, if you want this class to be a singleton, remember to add a private constructor to prevent instantiation.

The singleton pattern in Java is typically implemented as a variation the below. So instead of

public final class Foo {
  public static void m1() {
    // do something
  }

  private Foo() {
    // no instances...a utility
  }
}

use

public final class Foo {
  private static final INSTANCE = new Foo();

  public static Foo getInstance() {
    return INSTANCE;
  }

  private Foo() {
    // singleton
  }

  public void m1() {
    // do something
  }
}

Clients change calls to m1() from Foo.m1() to Foo.getInstance().m1().

findingType.name: Use boolean expressions directly
findingType.shortMessage: Use boolean expressions directly to simplify your code.
findingType.info:
Avoid unnecessary comparisons in boolean expressions—this complicates simple code.

For example, consider changing

public class Foo {

  private int bar = 2;

  public boolean isBarEqualTo(int x) {
    if (bar == x) {
     return true;
    } else {
     return false;
    }
  }

  private boolean bar = (isFoo() == true);

  public isFoo() {
    return false;
  }
}

to

public class Foo {

  private int bar = 2;

  public boolean isBarEqualTo(int x) {
    return bar == x;
  }

  private boolean bar = isFoo();

  public isFoo() {
    return false;
  }
}

findingType.name: Switch with no default
findingType.shortMessage: This switch statement should have a default label.
findingType.info:
It has been deemed questionable coding practice to not have a default label for each switch.

int x = 2;
switch (x) {
  case 2: int j = 8; // no default?
}

findingType.name: Avoid deeply nested if statements
findingType.shortMessage: This is a deeply nested if that may be hard to read. Can the level of nesting be reduced?
findingType.info: Deeply nested if statements have been deemed to be questionable coding practice because they can be hard to read.

findingType.name: Avoid reassigning parameter values
findingType.shortMessage: This method reassigns the values of one or more of its parameters. This is a questionable practice.
findingType.info:
Reassigning values to parameters has been deemed a questionable coding practice. Use a temporary local variable instead.

private void foo(String bar) {
  bar = "something else";  // don't do this
}

findingType.name: Switch density too high
findingType.shortMessage: This switch statement has a high ratio of statements to labels. Consider moving the statements into new methods, or creating subclasses based on the switch variable.
findingType.info:
A high ratio of statements to labels in a switch statement implies that the switch statement is probably doing too much work. Consider moving the statements into new methods, or creating subclasses based on the switch variable (to replace the switch statement with polymorphism).

switch (x) {
  case 1: {
    // lots of statements
    break;
  } case 2: {
    // lots of statements
    break;
  }
}

findingType.name: Constructor calls an overridable method
findingType.shortMessage: This constructor calls, directly or indirectly, an overridable method. This is considered dangerous if this class is subclassed.
findingType.info:
Calling overridable methods during construction poses a risk of invoking methods on an incompletely constructed object and can be difficult to discern. It may leave the sub-class unable to construct its superclass or forced to replicate the construction process completely within itself, losing the ability to call super().

If the default constructor contains a call to an overridable method, the subclass may be completely uninstantiable. Note that this includes method calls throughout the control flow graph, i.e., if a constructor Foo() calls a private method bar() that calls a public (and thus overridable) method buz(), this denotes a potential problem.

The code below provides an example where this finding can cause confusing program behavior.

public class SeniorClass {
  public SeniorClass() {
    toString(); // may throw NullPointerException if overridden
  }
  public String toString() {
    return "IAmSeniorClass";
  }
}

public class JuniorClass extends SeniorClass {
  private String name;
  public JuniorClass() {
    super(); // Automatic call leads to a NullPointerException because 'name' is still null
    name = "JuniorClass";
  }
  public String toString() {
    return name.toUpperCase();
  }
}

findingType.name: Accessor class generation
findingType.shortMessage: This class uses private constructors from outside of the constructor's class which can cause the generation of an accessor.
findingType.info:
Instantiation by way of private constructors from outside of the constructor's class often causes the generation of an accessor. A factory method, or non-privatization of the constructor can eliminate this situation. The generated class file is actually an interface. It gives the accessing class the ability to invoke a new hidden package scope constructor that takes the interface as a supplementary parameter. This turns a private constructor effectively into one with package scope, and is challenging to discern.

public class Outer {
  void method(){
    Inner ic = new Inner(); // Causes generation of an accessor class
  }
  public class Inner {
    private Inner(){}
  }
}

This could be resolved by making the constructor not be private or by creating a factory method such as:

Inner getInstance() {
  return new Inner();
}

It is recommended to check if this generation still occurs on your JDK. If not then this finding is not an issue.

findingType.name: Avoid non-static initializer
findingType.shortMessage: Do this code really need to use a non-static initializer block, it is rarely used and is confusing.
findingType.info:
A non-static initializer block will be called any time a constructor is invoked (just prior to invoking the constructor). While this is a valid language construct, it is rarely used and is confusing.

It is often possible to move the code in the initializer block into a constructor. Also consider using the this() invocation technique to avoid copying of common constructor code. For example: 

class Foo {

  private Foo() {
    // common code
  }

  public Foo(String s) {
    this();
    // more code
  }
}

findingType.name: Default label should be last in switch
findingType.shortMessage: By convention, the default label should be the last label in a switch statement.
findingType.info:
It is considered questionable coding practice to have the default label not be last in a switch statement.

switch (a) {
  case 1:
    // do something
    break;
  default:  // the default case should be last, by convention
    break;
  case 2:
    break;
}

findingType.name: Non-case label in switch
findingType.shortMessage: This code contains a non-case label (e.g. a named break/continue label) within a switch statement. This legal, but confusing.
findingType.info:
A non-case label (e.g. a named break/continue label) was present in a switch statement. This legal, but confusing. It is easy to mix up the case labels and the non-case labels. It is recommended that this code be changed to avoid this confusion.

switch (a) {
  case 1:
    // do something
    break;
  mylabel: // this is legal, but confusing!
    break;
  default:
    break;
}

findingType.name: Confusing negated if
findingType.shortMessage: Avoid negation in the test of this if statement. This can be confusing.
findingType.info:
In an if expression with anelse clause, avoid negation in the test. For example, rephrase

if (x != y)
  diff();
else
  same();

as

if (x == y)
  same();
else
  diff();

Most if (x != y) cases without an else are often return cases, so consistent use of this rule makes the code easier to read. Also, this resolves trivial ordering problems, such as 'does the error case go first?' or 'does the common case go first?'.

findingType.name: Avoid instantiation to call getClass()
findingType.shortMessage: This code instantiates an object just to call getClass() on it; use the .class public member instead.
findingType.info:
Avoid instantiating an object just to call getClass() on it; use the .class public member instead. For example, replace

Class c = new String().getClass();

with this

Class c = String.class;

findingType.name: Use Locale parameterized version of SimpleDateFormat constructor
findingType.shortMessage: It is recommended that you specify a Locale when creating a new instance of SimpleDateFormat.
findingType.info:
Consider specifying a Locale when creating a new instance of SimpleDateFormat.

// Should specify Locale.US (or whatever)
private SimpleDateFormat sdf = new SimpleDateFormat("pattern");

findingType.name: Immutable field
findingType.shortMessage: This is a private field that never changes once it is initialized. Consider making it a final field.
findingType.info:
A private field whose value never changes once it is initialized either in the declaration of the field or by a constructor can be declared to be final. This aids in converting existing classes to immutable classes.

public class Foo {
  private int x; // could be final
  public Foo() {
     x = 7;
  }
  public void foo() {
    int a = x + 2;
  }
}

findingType.name: Avoid protected fields in final classes
findingType.shortMessage: This field is declared to be protected in a final class. Consider changing it to be private.
findingType.info:
Do not use protected fields in final classes since they cannot be subclassed. Clarify your intent by changing these fields to use either the private or package access (default) modifiers instead.

public final class Bar {
  private int x;   // Ok
  protected int y; // 'Bar' cannot be subclassed, so should 'y' really private or package visible???
  ...
}

findingType.name: Assignment to a non-final static field
findingType.shortMessage: This assignment to a non-static field may be unsafe. Is this what was intended?
findingType.info:
Identifies a possible unsafe usage of a static field. Consider making this field immutable. If this field is intended to be mutable then ignore this finding.

public class StaticField {
   static int x;
   public FinalFields(int y) {
     x = y; // is this intended?
   }
}

findingType.name: Non-instantiatable class
findingType.shortMessage: This class has only private constructors and does not have any static methods of fields. This class appears to be unusable.
findingType.info:
A class that has only private constructors and does not have any static methods or fields cannot be used.

/**
 * This class is unusable, since it cannot be
 * instantiated (private constructor),
 * no static method can be called, and
 * no static field can be accessed.
 */
public class Foo {
  private Foo() {}
  void foo() {}
}

findingType.name: Avoid synchronized at the method level
findingType.shortMessage: Consider finer-grained synchronization than at the method level.
findingType.info:
Method level synchronization can backfire when new code is added to the method. Block-level synchronization helps to ensure that only the code that needs synchronization gets it. Block-level synchronization can also help to improve encapsulation.

public class Foo {

  // Try to avoid this
  synchronized void foo() {
    ...
  }

  // Prefer this approach
  void bar() {
    synchronized(this) {
      ...
    }
    ...
  }
}

findingType.name: Avoid instanceof checks in catch
findingType.shortMessage: Place each caught exception in its own catch clause. Don't use instanceof.
findingType.info:
Each caught exception type should be handled in its own catch clause. Do not use instanceof check. For example, replace

try {
  // do something
} catch (Exception ee) {
  if (ee instanceof IOException) {
    cleanup();
  }
}

with

try {
  // do something
} catch (IOException ee) {
  cleanup();
}

findingType.name: Abstract class has no abstract methods
findingType.shortMessage: This abstract class does not contain any abstract methods. Is it an incomplete implementation?
findingType.info:
This abstract class does not contain any abstract methods. An abstract class suggests an incomplete implementation, which is to be completed by subclasses implementing the abstract methods. If the class is intended to be used as a base class only (not to be instantiated directly) a protected constructor can be provided prevent direct instantiation.

public abstract class Foo {
  void int method1() { ... }
  void int method2() { ... }
  // consider using abstract methods or removing
  // the abstract modifier and adding protected constructors
}

findingType.name: Unnecessary null check before instanceof
findingType.shortMessage: This code checks for null before an instanceof check. The null check can be safely removed.
findingType.info:
There is no need to check for a null value before an instanceof check. This is because the instanceof keyword returns false when given a null argument. For example, it is safe to change

if (x != null && x instanceof Bar) {
  // do something
}

to

if (x != null && x instanceof Bar) {
  // do something
}

findingType.name: Compare objects with equals() not ==
findingType.shortMessage: Consider using equals() to compare object references. Avoid comparing them with ==.
findingType.info:
It has been determined that it is a questionable code practice to compare object references with ==, use equals() instead. For example, change a == b to a.equals(b).

If this practice is followed be sure that the object being dereferenced to call equals() (in our example this is a) is not null.

findingType.name: Position literals first in String comparisons
findingType.shortMessage: Position the String literal first in this comparison. This way may throw a NullPointerException.
findingType.info: Always position literals first in String comparisons. This ensures that if the String is null then the comparison will not throw a NullPointerException, it'll just return false. For example, always use "hello".equals(s) rather than s.equals("hello").

findingType.name: Avoid unnecessary local variable before return
findingType.shortMessage: This code appears to create an unnecessary local variable just to return it. Consider removing this local variable.
findingType.info:
Avoid unnecessarily creating local variables just to return them.

public int foo() {
  int x = doSomething();
  return x;  // instead, just 'return doSomething();'
}

findingType.name: Avoid non-thread save singleton
findingType.shortMessage: This singleton does not appear to be thread-safe. Consider making it thread-safe.
findingType.info:
Non-thread-safe singletons can result in bad state changes. Eliminate static singletons if possible by instantiating the object directly. Static singletons are usually not needed as only a single instance exists anyway. Other possible fixes are to synchronize the entire method or to use an initialize-on-demand holder class. (do not use the double-check idiom). For more information see Bloch's Effective Java (first edition) item 48.

For example, change the below code

private static Foo foo = null;

// Not thread-safe -- multiple simultaneous callers
// may see partially initialized objects
public static Foo getInstance() {
  if (foo == null)
    foo = new Foo();
  return foo;
}

to

private static final Foo INSTANCE = new Foo();

public static Foo getInstance() {
  return INSTANCE;
}

or synchronize the getInstance() method.

If you are using Java 5 or above a single element enum is recommended by Bloch as the best way to implement a singleton. For example

public enum Foo {
  INSTANCE;

  // singleton methods
  public void m1() { ... }
}

would be used as Foo.INSTANCE.m1(). This approach has several advantages including built-in serialization machinery and a guarantee against multiple instantiation.

findingType.name: Uncommented empty method
findingType.shortMessage: This empty method should be commented to indicate that it is intentionally empty.
findingType.info: This method does not contain any statements, but there is no comment indicating that this lack of statements is intentional. By explicitly commenting empty methods it is easier to distinguish between intentional (commented) and unintentional empty methods.

findingType.name: Uncommented empty constructor
findingType.shortMessage: This empty constructor should be commented to indicate that it is intentionally empty.
findingType.info: This constructor does not contain any statements, but there is no comment. By explicitly commenting empty constructors it is easier to distinguish between intentional (commented) and unintentional empty constructors.

findingType.name: Avoid constants-only interface
findingType.shortMessage: This interface only acts as a container of constants. This is a poor usage pattern.
findingType.info:
An interface should be used only to model a behavior of a class: using an interface as a container of constants is a poor usage pattern.

// Bad! poor use of an interface
public interface ConstantsInterface {
  public static final int CONSTANT1 = 0;
  public static final String CONSTANT2 = "1";
}

findingType.name: Preserve original stack trace
findingType.shortMessage: This code throws a new exception from a catch block without passing the original exception into the new exception. This causes the true stack trace to be lost. Consider changing this code.
findingType.info:
Throwing a new exception from a catch block without passing the original exception into the new exception will cause the true stack trace to be lost, and can make it difficult to debug effectively. Ensure that you pass the original exception into the constructor of the new exception. For example, change

try{
  Integer.parseInt("a");
} catch(Exception e){
  throw new Exception(e.getMessage());
}

to

try{
  Integer.parseInt("a");
} catch(Exception e){
  throw new Exception(e);
}

findingType.name: Use isEmpty() to check if a collection is empty
findingType.shortMessage: Use the isEmpty() method to see if a java.util.Collection is empty rather than comparing the value of size() to 0.
findingType.info:
The isEmpty() method on java.util.Collection objects is provided to see if a collection has any elements. Comparing the value of size() of the collection to 0 merely duplicates existing behavior. For example, change

List foo = getList();
if (foo.size() == 0) {
  // do something
}

to

List foo = getList();
if (foo.isEmpty()) {
  // do something
}

findingType.name: Avoid overloading finalize()
findingType.shortMessage: This method overloads the finalize() method with one that has one or more parameters. It is not be called by the VM.
findingType.info:
Methods named finalize() should not have parameters. It is easy to confuse such a method with a finalizer and could lead to a bug. This method will not be called by the VM. It is recommended that you use another name.

public class Foo {
  // This method is confusing and might be a bug
  protected void finalize(int a) {
    ...
  }
}

findingType.name: Avoid duplicate import
findingType.shortMessage: This compilation unit has an import that duplicates another import. Remove the duplication.
findingType.info:
It is considered bad practice for a compilation unit to contain duplicate import statements. For example, consider changing

import java.util.Set;
import java.util.*;
public class Foo {
  ...
}

to

import java.util.*;
public class Foo {
  ...
}

findingType.name: Never explicitly import from java.lang
findingType.shortMessage: This compilation unit explicitly imports part or all of the java.lang package. This package is automatically imported.
findingType.info:
Never explicitly import anything from the java.lang package. Classes in this package are automatically imported. For example, both of the import statements shown below are unnecessary and can be removed.

import java.lang.String;

import java.lang.*;

See the Java Language Specification for further details.

findingType.name: Remove unused import
findingType.shortMessage: This import is not necessary. Consider removing it from the compilation unit.
findingType.info:
Imports that are not required by the compilation unit create a dependency. For example, consider the below code.

import org.apache.log4j.Logger;
public class Foo {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    System.out.println("Hello!");
  }
}

This compilation unit will not compile without the Apache Log4j Jar on its classpath despite the fact that it never uses the imported Log4j Logger class.

Unused or unnecessary imports are considered bad coding practice and can create unnecessary coupling between classes.

Many IDEs, such as Eclipse, can help you to automatically remove unused imports from your program.

findingType.name: Use proper class loader
findingType.shortMessage: Avoid getClassLoader() in J2EE. Use Thread.currentThread().getContextClassLoader() instead.
findingType.info:
In J2EE getClassLoader() might not work as expected. Therefore, use Thread.currentThread().getContextClassLoader() instead.

For example, consider changing

ClassLoader cl = Bar.class.getClassLoader();

to

ClassLoader cl = Thread.currentThread().getContextClassLoader();

findingType.name: MDB and SessionBean naming convention
findingType.shortMessage: This class appears to be a MessageDrivenBean or a SessionBean but is not suffixed by 'Bean'.
findingType.info:
The EJB Specification states that any MessageDrivenBean or SessionBean should be suffixed by 'Bean'. For example:

public class SomeBean implements SessionBean { ... }

findingType.name: Remote Home naming convention
findingType.shortMessage: This class appears to be the Remote Home interface of a Session EJB but is not suffixed by 'Home'.
findingType.info:
The Remote Home interface of a Session EJB should be suffixed by 'Home'. For example:

public interface MyBeautifulHome extends javax.ejb.EJBHome { ... }

findingType.name: Local naming convention
findingType.shortMessage: This class appears to be the Local interface of a Session EJB but is not suffixed by 'Local'.
findingType.info:
The Local Interface of a Session EJB should be suffixed by 'Local'. For example:

public interface MyLocal extends javax.ejb.EJBLocalObject { ... }

findingType.name: Local Home naming convention
findingType.shortMessage: This class appears to be the Local Home interface of a Session EJB but is not suffixed by 'LocalHome'.
findingType.info:
The Local Home interface of a Session EJB should be suffixed by 'LocalHome'. For example:

public interface MyBeautifulLocalHome extends javax.ejb.EJBLocalHome { ... }

findingType.name: Remote naming convention
findingType.shortMessage: The remote interface of a Session EJB should not be suffixed.
findingType.info:
The Remote interface of a Session EJB should NOT be suffixed. For example, use

public interface BadSuffix extends javax.ejb.EJBObject { ... }

rather than any of the following:

public interface BadSuffixSession extends javax.ejb.EJBObject { ... }

public interface BadSuffixEJB extends javax.ejb.EJBObject { ... }

public interface BadSuffixBean extends javax.ejb.EJBObject { ... }

findingType.name: Bean members should serialize
findingType.shortMessage: This class is a bean, or is referenced by a bean directly or indirectly. Therefore, it needs to be serializable.
findingType.info:
If a class is a bean, or is referenced by a bean directly or indirectly it needs to be serializable. Member variables need to be marked as transient, static, or have accessor methods in the class. Marking variables as transient is the safest and easiest modification.

Accessor methods should follow the Java naming conventions, i.e., if you have a variable foo, you should provide getFoo and setFoo methods.

For example, consider the below code

private transient int someFoo; //good, it's transient
private static int otherFoo;   // also OK
private int moreFoo;           // OK, has proper accessors, see below
private int badFoo;            // Bad! probably should be marked transient

private void setMoreFoo(int moreFoo) {
  this.moreFoo = moreFoo;
}

private int getMoreFoo() {
  return this.moreFoo;
}
