findingType.name: JUnit spelling
findingType.shortMessage: Some JUnit framework methods are easy to misspell. Did you misspell this method's name?
findingType.info:
Some JUnit framework methods are easy to misspell. For example, consider the below broken code.

public class Foo extends TestCase {
  public void setup() { ... }    // oops, should be setUp
  public void TearDown() { ... } // oops, should be tearDown
}

findingType.name: JUnit assertions should include a message
findingType.shortMessage: Consider including a message as to what went wrong.
findingType.info:
JUnit assertions should include a message, i.e., use the three argument version of assertEquals(), not the two argument version.

For example, consider changing

assertEquals("foo", "bar");

to

assertEquals("foo is not semantically equal to bar", "foo", "bar");

findingType.name: JUnit tests should include asserts
findingType.shortMessage: This JUnit test case does not have an assertion. Is this intentional?
findingType.info:
JUnit tests should include at least one assertion. This makes the tests more robust, and using assert with messages provide the developer a clearer idea of what the test does.

For example, consider changing

public void testSomething() {
  Bar b = findBar();
  b.work();
}

to

public void testSomething() {
  Bar b = findBar();
  assertNotNull("bar was not able to be found", b);
  b.work();
}

findingType.name: Test class without test cases
findingType.shortMessage: Test classes end with the suffix Test. Having a non-test class with that name is not a good practice.
findingType.info: Test classes end with the suffix Test. Having a non-test class with that name is not a good practice, since most people will assume it is a test case. Test classes, for JUnit, have test methods named testx. Where x is the name of the test.

findingType.name: Unnecessary boolean assertion
findingType.shortMessage: Consider removing assertTrue(true) and assertFalse(false). If you just want a test to halt, use the fail method.
findingType.info: A JUnit test assertion with a boolean literal is unnecessary since it always will evaluate to the same thing. Consider using flow control, in case of assertTrue(false) or similar, or simply removing statements like assertTrue(true) and assertFalse(false). If you just want a test to halt, use the fail() method.

findingType.name: Use specific JUnit methods instead of assertTrue()
findingType.shortMessage: Check object references using more specific JUnit methods rather than assertTrue.
findingType.info:
Check object references using assertNull, assertNotNull, assertSame, assertNotSame, or assertEquals rather than assertTrue. This is easier to understand.

For example, change

void testCode() {
  Object a = doSomething();

  assertTrue(a == null);   // Bad!
  assertTrue(a != null);   // Bad!

  assertTrue(a == b);      // Bad!
  assertTrue(a != c);      // Bad!

  assertTrue(a.equals(b)); // Bad!
}

to

void testCode() {
  Object a = doSomething();

  assertNull(a);
  assertNotNull(a);

  assertSame(a, b);
  assertNotSame(a, c);

  assertEquals(a, b);
}

findingType.name: Simplify boolean assertion
findingType.shortMessage: Avoid negation in an assertTrue() or assertFalse() tests.
findingType.info:
Avoid negation in an assertTrue or assertFalse test. Rephrase assertTrue(!expr) as assertFalse(expr).

For example, change

public void testX() {
  assertTrue("not empty", !r.isEmpty()); // Bad!
  assertFalse(!r.isEmpty());             // Bad!
}

to

public void testX() {
  assertFalse("not empty", r.isEmpty());
  assertTrue(r.isEmpty());
}

findingType.name: Use informative Exception logging
findingType.shortMessage: This code appears to lose information. Consider using the logging statement with 2 arguments: a String and a Throwable.
findingType.info:
To make sure the full stacktrace is printed out, use the logging statement with 2 arguments: a String and a Throwable.

For example, consider changing

public class Main {
  private static final Log _LOG = LogFactory.getLog(Main.class);
  ...
  void bar() {
    try {
      // do something that can go wrong
    } catch(Exception e) {
      _LOG.error(e); // Bad!
    }
  }
}

to

public class Main {
  private static final Log _LOG = LogFactory.getLog(Main.class);
  ...
  void bar() {
    try {
      // do something that can go wrong
    } catch(Exception e) {
      _LOG.error(e.getMessage(), e);
    }
  }
}

findingType.name: Use the proper logger
findingType.shortMessage: Consider declaring your logger to be private static final and ensure it has the correct class.
findingType.info:
A logger should normally be defined to be private static final and have the correct class.

A non-static private final logger is also allowed for rare cases where loggers need to be passed around, with the restriction that the logger needs to be passed into the constructor.

For example, consider changing

public class Foo {
  protected Log LOG = LogFactory.getLog(Testclass.class);
  ...
}

to

public class Foo {
  private static final Log LOG = LogFactory.getLog(Foo.class);
  ...
}

findingType.name: Avoid more than one Logger
findingType.shortMessage: Normally only one Logger is used in each class. Consider removing a Logger.
findingType.info:
This class contains two Logger references. Typically only one Logger is used in each class.

For example, one of the below loggers should probably be removed.

class Foo{
    private static final Logger LOG = Logger.getLogger(Foo.class.getName());
    ...
    private static final Logger LOGGER = Logger.getLogger(Foo.class.getName());
}

findingType.name: Logger is not static final
findingType.shortMessage: Consider declaring this Logger to be static and final.
findingType.info:
In most cases, the Logger can be declared static and final.

For example, consider changing

class Foo{
  private Logger log = Logger.getLogger(Foo.class.getName());
  ...
}

to

class Foo{
  private static final Logger LOG = Logger.getLogger(Foo.class.getName());
  ...
}

findingType.name: Use of System.out or System.err println()
findingType.shortMessage: Avoid calls to System.(out|err).print, consider using a logger.
findingType.info: Avoid print calls to System.out or System.err, consider using a logger instead.

findingType.name: Avoid calls to printStackTrace()
findingType.shortMessage: Avoid calls to printStackTrace(); use a logger call instead.
findingType.info: Avoid calls to printStackTrace() which dumps the trace to System.out, consider using a logger call instead.

findingType.name: Replace Hashtable with Map
findingType.shortMessage: Consider replacing this Hashtable with the newer java.util.Map.
findingType.info:
Consider replacing this Hashtable with the newer java.util.Map.

The collections framework was released with JDK 1.2 and effectively makes types such as Vector, Hashtable, and Enumeration obsolete. Avoid using these types in newer code. In general, the performance of the new collections will be superior because they do not synchronize each of their methods.

findingType.name: Replace Enumeration with Iterator
findingType.shortMessage: Consider replacing this Enumeration with the newer java.util.Iterator.
findingType.info:
Consider replacing this Enumeration with the newer java.util.Iterator.

The collections framework was released with JDK 1.2 and effectively makes types such as Vector, Hashtable, and Enumeration obsolete. Avoid using these types in newer code. In general, the performance of the new collections will be superior because they do not synchronize each of their methods.

findingType.name: JUnit 4 tests should use @Before
findingType.shortMessage: Use the @Before annotation in JUnit 4.
findingType.info:
In JUnit 3, the setUp method was used to set up all data entities required in running tests. JUnit 4 skips the setUp method and executes all methods annotated with @Before before running each test.

For example, change

public void setUp() {
  // operations to do before running each test
}

to

@Before public void setUp() {
  // operations to do before running each test
}

findingType.name: JUnit 4 tests should use @After
findingType.shortMessage: Use the @After annotation in JUnit 4.
findingType.info:
In JUnit 3, the tearDown method was used to clean up all data entities required in running tests. JUnit 4 skips the tearDown method and executes all methods annotated with @After after running each test

For example, change

public void tearDown() {
  // operations to do after running each test
}

to

@After public void tearDown() {
  // operations to do after running each test
}

findingType.name: JUnit 4 tests should use @Test
findingType.shortMessage: Use the @Test annotation in JUnit 4.
findingType.info:
In JUnit 3, the framework executed all methods which started with the word test as a unit test. In JUnit 4, only methods annotated with the @Test annotation are executed.

For example, change

public void testStuff() {
  // do some testing
}

to

@Test public void testStuff() {
  // do some testing
}

findingType.name: JUnit 4 suites should use the suite annotation
findingType.shortMessage: Use @RunWith(Suite.class) annotation rather than a suite() method.
findingType.info:
In JUnit 3, test suites are indicated by the suite() method. In JUnit 4, suites are indicated through the @RunWith(Suite.class) annotation.

For example, in you are using JUnit 4 change

public class BadExample extends TestCase{
  public static Test suite(){
    return new Suite();
  }
}

to

@RunWith(Suite.class)
@SuiteClasses( { TestOne.class, TestTwo.class } )
public class GoodTest {
}

findingType.name: Short variable name
findingType.shortMessage: Detects when a field, local, or parameter has a very short name.
findingType.info: Detects when a field, local, or parameter has a very short name.

findingType.name: Long variable name
findingType.shortMessage: Detects when a field, formal or local variable is declared with a long name.
findingType.info: Detects when a field, formal or local variable is declared with a long name.

findingType.name: Short method name
findingType.shortMessage: Detects when very short method names are used.
findingType.info: Detects when very short method names are used.

findingType.name: Abstract naming
findingType.shortMessage: Abstract classes should be named AbstractX.
findingType.info: Abstract classes should be named Abstractx. Where x is the class name. This convention can help to clarify the nature of the class.

findingType.name: Avoid dollar signs
findingType.shortMessage: Avoid using dollar signs in variable/method/class/interface names.
findingType.info: Avoid using dollar signs in variable/method/class/interface names. Dollar signs are typically only used for generated class names.

findingType.name: Suspicious constant field name
findingType.shortMessage: This field name is all uppercase characters, which in Sun's Java naming conventions indicate a constant. However, the field is not final.
findingType.info: A field name of all uppercase characters, by Sun's Java naming conventions, indicates a constant. However, this field is not final. Should this field be declared to be final?

findingType.name: Avoid field name matching type name
findingType.shortMessage: This class uses a name for both a field name and a type name. This can be confusing.
findingType.info: It is somewhat confusing to have a field name matching the declaring class name. While this is totally legal, this probably means that type and or field names could be more precise.

findingType.name: Avoid field name matching method name
findingType.shortMessage: This class uses a name for both a field name and a method name. This can be confusing.
findingType.info: It is somewhat confusing to have a field name with the same name as a method. While this is totally legal, having information (field) and actions (method) with the same name is not as clear as it could be.

findingType.name: No package
findingType.shortMessage: This class or interface does not have a package definition and is within the default package. This is not recommended.
findingType.info:
A class or interface that does not have a package definition is located within the default package. Placing classes and interfaces in the default package is not recommended.

Consider placing this class or interface into a package.

findingType.name: Bad package case
findingType.shortMessage: This package definition contains upper case characters. This violates normal package naming convention.
findingType.info:
When a package definition contains upper case characters this violates package naming conventions.

Consider removing the upper case characters.

findingType.name: Misleading variable name
findingType.shortMessage: This local variable name starts with 'm_'. This convention usually indicates a field and thus is confusing.
findingType.info: A a non-field has a name starting with m_. This usually indicates a field and thus is confusing.

findingType.name: Use isX() not getX()
findingType.shortMessage: This boolean getter method is named getX(). Consider renaming this method to isX().
findingType.info: Methods named getX() that return a boolean may be misnamed. The convention is to name these methods isX().

findingType.name: Local variable could be final
findingType.shortMessage: This local variable assigned only once can be declared final.
findingType.info: A local variable that is assigned only once can be declared to be final.

findingType.name: Method argument could be final
findingType.shortMessage: This method argument is never assigned can be declared final.
findingType.info: A method argument that is never assigned can be declared to be final.

findingType.name: Avoid instantiating objects in loops
findingType.shortMessage: This code is instantiating new objects inside of a loop. Can this be avoided?
findingType.info: Take care when creating new objects inside of a loop as this may create a lot of objects. Is this creation intentional?

findingType.name: Prefer ArrayList over Vector
findingType.shortMessage: This code uses the old Vector collection. Consider updating this to ArrayList (or LinkedList).
findingType.info:
The collections framework was released with JDK 1.2 and effectively makes types such as Vector, Hashtable, and Enumeration obsolete. Avoid using these types in newer code. In general, the performance of the new collections will be superior because they do not synchronize each of their methods.

If you use this Vector in concurrent code, you can use Collections.synchronizedList method to "wrap" a list or consider one of the collections provided in the java.util.concurrent package.

findingType.name: Inefficient use of startsWith()
findingType.shortMessage: Because it passes in a String literal of length 1, this call to String.startsWith() can be rewritten using String.charAt(0) to improve performance.
findingType.info:
Because this code passes in a String literal of length 1, this call to String.startsWith() can be rewritten using String.charAt(0) to save some time.

For example, consider changing

boolean checkIt(String x) {
  return x.startsWith("a");
}

to

boolean checkIt(String x) {
  return x.charAt(0) == 'a';
}

findingType.name: Use Arrays.asList()
findingType.shortMessage: To create a list from an array consider using Arrays.asList() rather than a loop.
findingType.info:
The class java.util.Arrays has an asList method that should be used when you want to create a new List from an array of objects. It is faster than executing a loop to copy all the elements out of the array one by one.

For example, consider the below code

Integer[] intArray = new Integer[100];
Arrays.fill(intArray, Integer.valueOf(2));

// Bad! creates a copy using a loop
List<Integer> l1 = new ArrayList<Integer>(100);
for (int i = 0; i < 100; i++) {
	l1.add(intArray[i]);
}

// Changes to this list also modify the array
List<Integer> l2 = Arrays.asList(intArray);

// This list is a copy (just like 'l1' that was created above)
List<Integer> l3 = new ArrayList<Integer>(Arrays.asList(intArray));

l2.set(0, Integer.valueOf(10)); // sets the first element of 'intArray' and 'l2'
System.out.println(Arrays.toString(intArray));

findingType.name: Avoid copying arrays with a loop
findingType.shortMessage: This code appears to use a loop to copy data between two arrays. To improve performance, consider using System.arraycopy or one of the methods provide by the Arrays utility class.
findingType.info:
Instead of using a loop to copy data between two arrays use System.arraycopy or one of the static method declared within the Arrays utility class. This can improve the performance of your program.

For example, consider the below code

int[] a = new int[10];
Arrays.fill(a, 30);

// Bad! uses a loop
int[] b1 = new int[10];
for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
  b1[i] = a[i];
}

// this is better
int[] b2 = new int[10];
System.arraycopy(a, 0, b2, 0, 10);

// this is also better
int[] b3 = Arrays.copyOf(a, a.length);

findingType.name: Avoid unnecessary wrapper object creation
findingType.shortMessage: This code creates a wrapper object simply to convert from a String to a primitive type or from a primitive type to a String. Use the static parse or toString methods declared on the wrapper types instead.
findingType.info:
There is not need to create a wrapper object simply to convert from a String to a primitive type. Use the static parse methods declared on the wrapper types instead.

There is also no need to create a wrapper object simply to convert from a primitive type to a String. Use the static toString methods declared on the wrapper types instead.

For example, consider the below code.

int i, i2;

i = Integer.valueOf(s).intValue();          // Bad! this wastes an object
i = Integer.parseInt(s);                    // this is better

i2 = Integer.valueOf(i).intValue();         // Bad! this wastes an object
i2 = i;                                     // this is better

String s3 = Integer.valueOf(i2).toString(); // Bad! this wastes an object
s3 = Integer.toString(i2);                  // this is better

findingType.name: Inefficient conversion to a String
findingType.shortMessage: This code appears to convert a type to a String using an empty string literal and concatenation. To improve performance, consider using the toString() method on each wrapper type.
findingType.info:
Using an empty string literal and concatenation is an inefficient way to convert any type to a String. Consider using the static toString() method on each wrapper type.

For example, consider changing

String s = "" + 123; // Bad!

to

String s = Integer.toString(123);

findingType.name: Avoid catching Throwable
findingType.shortMessage: This code catches Throwable which is dangerous because it casts too wide of a net. Consider changing this to a more specific exception type that the block is actually designed to handle.
findingType.info:
Catching Throwable is considered dangerous because it casts too wide of a net; it can catch things like OutOfMemoryError or KernelError that no program can recover from.

It is recommended that this catch block be made more specific about exactly what exception it is designed to handle.

findingType.name: Avoid methods that throw Exception
findingType.shortMessage: This method declares that it may throw any exception. This is overly broad. Consider making this declaration more specific.
findingType.info: It is recommended that this method be more specific about what exceptions it may actually throw. Declaring that a method throws Exception is considered overly broad.

findingType.name: Avoid using exceptions for flow control
findingType.shortMessage: This code appears to use exceptions as control flow. This can lead to poorly preforming GOTO-like code and, in most cases, should be avoided.
findingType.info:
Using Exceptions as flow control leads to GOTO-like code and obscures true exceptions when debugging. In addition, the performance of such code can be half of the performance of code that avoids this confusing technique.

For example, the code below has the problem identified by this finding.

void bar() {
  try {
    try {
      // do something
    } catch (Exception e) {
      throw new WrapperException(e); // this is essentially a GOTO to the WrapperException catch block
    }
  } catch (WrapperException e) {
    // do something
  }
}

Most (but not all) APIs provide ways to avoid using exceptions for control flow.

For further information please see Bloch's Effective Java (second edition) item 57.

findingType.name: Avoid catching NullPointerException
findingType.shortMessage: This code catches a NullPointerException. Normal code should not catch this exception. Consider removing the catch block.
findingType.info:
Code should never throw NullPointerException under normal circumstances. Such a catch block may hide the original programming error, causing other more subtle errors in its wake.

Consider removing this catch block unless this is test code or some other special purpose code.

findingType.name: Avoid throwing raw exception types
findingType.shortMessage: This code throws a raw exception type. Consider throwing a subclassed exception or error instead.
findingType.info:
Avoid throwing base exception types. Rather than throw a raw RuntimeException, Throwable, Exception, or Error, use a subclassed exception or error instead.

Some commonly reused exceptions are:

IllegalArgumentException
IllegalStateException
NullPointerException
IndexOutOfBoundsException
ConcurrentModificationException
UnsupportedOperationException

For more information please see Bloch's Effective Java (second edition) item 60.

findingType.name: Avoid throwing NullPointerException
findingType.shortMessage: This code explicitly throws a NullPointerException. This can be confusing. Consider throwing IllegalArgumentException instead.
findingType.info:
Avoid throwing a NullPointerException;ndash;it's confusing because most people will assume that the virtual machine threw it. Consider throwing an IllegalArgumentException instead; this will be clearly seen as a programmer-initiated exception.

For example, consider changing

public void log(String msg) {
  if (msg == null) throw new NullPointerException("msg must be non-null");
  ...
}

to

public void log(String msg) {
  if (msg == null) throw new IllegalArgumentException("msg must be non-null");
  ...
}

findingType.name: Avoid rethrowing
findingType.shortMessage: This code contains a catch block that seems to merely rethrow a caught exception. Consider removing this catch block.
findingType.info:
Catch blocks that merely rethrow a caught exception only add to code size and runtime complexity. Consider removing this catch block.

For example, consider changing

void bar() {
  try {
    // do something
  }  catch (NullPointerException e) {
    throw e;
  }
}

to

void bar() {
  // do something
}

findingType.name: Avoid extending java.lang.Error
findingType.shortMessage: This class extends java.lang.Error. The Error type represents system exceptions and probably should not be extended. Consider extending RuntimeException instead.
findingType.info:
Errors are system exceptions. Do not extend them. If you are trying to declare an unchecked exception that your program can use then consider extending RuntimeException instead.

For example, consider changing

public class Foo extends Error {
  // Bad!
}

to

public class Foo extends RuntimeException {
}

findingType.name: Avoid duplicate String literals
findingType.shortMessage: This code contains duplicate String literals. Consider declaring the String as a constant field.
findingType.info:
Code containing duplicate String literals can usually be improved by declaring the String as a constant field.

For example, consider changing

class Foo {
  public void bar() {
    buz("Howdy");
    buz("Howdy");
    buz("Howdy");
    buz("Howdy");
  }

  public void buz(String msg) {
    System.out.println(msg);
  }
}

to

class Foo {
  private static final String HOWDY = "Howdy";

  public void bar() {
    buz(HOWDY);
    buz(HOWDY);
    buz(HOWDY);
    buz(HOWDY);
  }

  public void buz(String msg) {
    System.out.println(msg);
  }
}

findingType.name: Inefficient StringBuffer concatenation
findingType.shortMessage: This code concatenates non-literals in a StringBuffer constructor or append(). Consider avoiding this to improve performance.
findingType.info:
It is best to avoid concatenating non-literals in a StringBuffer constructor or append().

For example, consider changing

StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer("tmp = " + System.getProperty("java.io.tmpdir"));

to

StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer("tmp = ");
sb.append(System.getProperty("java.io.tmpdir"));

If you are using JKD 1.5 or above it is strongly recommended that you use StringBuilder rather than StringBuffer. In most cases the use of StringBuilder will improve code performance by avoid unnecessary synchronization.

findingType.name: Unnecessary case change for equality check
findingType.shortMessage: This code could be made faster by using equalsIgnoreCase() rather than toUpperCase/toLowerCase().equals().
findingType.info:
Using String.equalsIgnoreCase() is faster than using toUpperCase() or toLowerCase() followed by a call to equals(). This is because a new String does not need to be created.

For example, consider changing

String s = ...
if (s.toUpperCase.equals("SELECT")) {
  // do something
}
if (s.toUpperCase.equalsIgnoreCase("FROM")) {
  // do something
}

to

String s = ...
if (s.equalsIgnoreCase("SELECT")) {
  // do something
}
if (s.equalsIgnoreCase("FROM")) {
  // do something
}

findingType.name: Use StringBuffer.length()
findingType.shortMessage: It is recommended that you use StringBuffer.length() to determine the length of a StringBuffer.
findingType.info:
Use StringBuffer.length() to determine the length of a StringBuffer rather than converting to a String via StringBuffer.toString() and then making the check.

For example, consider changing

StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();
...
if (StringBuffer.toString().equals("")) {
  // do something
}
if (StringBuffer.toString().length() == 3) {
  // do something
}

to

StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();
...
if (StringBuffer.length == 0) {
  // do something
}
if (StringBuffer.length() == 3) {
  // do something
}

If you are using JKD 1.5 or above it is strongly recommended that you use StringBuilder rather than StringBuffer. In most cases the use of StringBuilder will improve code performance by avoid unnecessary synchronization.

findingType.name: Avoid appending a char as a String
findingType.shortMessage: Avoid concatenating characters as strings with StringBuffer.append calls.
findingType.info:
Avoid concatenating characters as strings with calls to the StringBuffer.append method.

For example, consider changing

StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();
sb.append("a"); // Bad!

to

StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();
sb.append('a');

If you are using JKD 1.5 or above it is strongly recommended that you use StringBuilder rather than StringBuffer. In most cases the use of StringBuilder will improve code performance by avoid unnecessary synchronization.

findingType.name: Consecutive String literal appends
findingType.shortMessage: This code makes several consecutively calls to StringBuffer.append with String literals. Consider consolidating all the literals into one.
findingType.info:
It is inefficient to repeatably call StringBuffer.append(String) with string literals. Consider consolidating all the literals into one call.

For example, consider changing

StringBuffer buf = new StringBuffer();
buf.append("Hello").append(" ").append("World"); // Bad!

to

StringBuffer buf = new StringBuffer();
buf.append("Hello World");

If you are using JKD 1.5 or above it is strongly recommended that you use StringBuilder rather than StringBuffer. In most cases the use of StringBuilder will improve code performance by avoid unnecessary synchronization.

findingType.name: Inefficient use of String.indexOf()
findingType.shortMessage: This code can improve its performance by using String.indexOf(char) when checking for the index of a single character.
findingType.info:
Use String.indexOf(char) rather than String.indexOf(String) when checking for the index of a single character because it executes faster.

For example, consider changing

if (s.indexOf("d") {  // Bad!
  // do something
}

to

if (s.indexOf('d') {
  // do something
}

findingType.name: Inefficient empty string check
findingType.shortMessage: This code is an inefficient approach to check if a string is whitespace-only or empty. Consider using the StringUtils.isBlank method from Apache Commons Lang library.
findingType.info:
Using String.trim().length() == 0 is an inefficient way to check if a String is really empty except for whitespace. This is because it creates a new String object just to check its size.

One solution is to include the Apache Commons Lang library in your code and use the StringUtils utility. The isBlank method checks if a string is whitespace, empty, or null. For example, you would change

if (s.trim().length() == 0) { // Bad!
  // do something
}

to

if (StringUtils.isBlank(s)) {
  // do something
}

If you do not want to use the Apache Commons Lang library then consider creating a static function that loops through a string, checking Character.isWhitespace() on each character and returning false if a non-whitespace character is found. The code Apache uses is

public static boolean isBlank(String str) {
  int strLen;
  if (str == null || (strLen = str.length()) == 0) {
    return true;
  }
  for (int i = 0; i < strLen; i++) {
    if ((Character.isWhitespace(str.charAt(i)) == false)) {
      return false;
    }
  }
  return true;
}

findingType.name: Insufficient StringBuffer initial size
findingType.shortMessage: This code fails to pre-size a StringBuffer which may cause it to resize many times. Consider passing a larger initial capacity to the StringBuffer constructor.
findingType.info:
Failing to pre-size a StringBuffer properly can cause it to re-size many times. This rule checks the characters that are actually passed into StringBuffer.append() method and tries to make a best guess about the "worst case" scenario with regard to overall size. An empty StringBuffer constructor sets the initial capacity of the object to 16 characters. This default is assumed if the length of the constructor can not be determined.

StringBuffer bad = new StringBuffer();
bad.append("This is a long string, will exceed the default 16 characters");

StringBuffer good = new StringBuffer(41);
good.append("This is a long string, which is pre-sized");

Being more accurate with your initial capacity can help to improve your program's performance.

If you are using JKD 1.5 or above it is strongly recommended that you use StringBuilder rather than StringBuffer. In most cases the use of StringBuilder will improve code performance by avoid unnecessary synchronization.

findingType.name: Unnecessary String.valueOf() call
findingType.shortMessage: This code calls String.valueOf() to append to a String. Consider just using the + operator.
findingType.info:
There is no need to call String.valueOf() to append to a string. Just use +.

For example, consider changing the below code

public String convert(int i) {
  String s = "a" + String.valueOf(i); // Bad!
  return s;
}

to

public String convert(int i) {
  String s = "a" + i;
  return s;
}

findingType.name: Confusing StringBuffer instantiation with char
findingType.shortMessage: This code instantiates a StringBuffer object with a char, e.g., StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer('c'). However, the char will be converted into int to initialize StringBuffer size.
findingType.info:
Calling the StringBuffer constructor with a char causes the char to be converted to an int to initialize the StringBuffer size.

For example, if the intent is to place the character in the StringBuffer then change

StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer('c'); // Bad!

to

StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer("c");

If you are using JKD 1.5 or above it is strongly recommended that you use StringBuilder rather than StringBuffer. In most cases the use of StringBuilder will improve code performance by avoid unnecessary synchronization.

findingType.name: Avoid storing a passed array
findingType.shortMessage: This code takes an array as a parameter and stores it directly to a field. Consider making a defensive copy of the array.
findingType.info:
This code stores an array directly to a field. This makes this code susceptible to mutations made by code that still has a reference to this array and its contents. Consider making a defensive copy of the array and its contents. this prevents future change by outside code from effecting this class.

For example, consider changing

public class Foo {
  private String [] x;

  public void foo (String [] param) {
    // Bad!
    this.x = param;
  }
}

to

public class Foo {
  private String [] x;

  public void foo (String [] param) {
    this.x = Arrays.copyOf(param, param.length);
  }
}

Note that in this example the contents of the array are immutable strings. Hence, we do not need to clone the contents in this example. In general, you will need to consider if the contents of the array need to be cloned.

findingType.name: Unused local variable
findingType.shortMessage: This local variable is declared but it is never read. Consider removing it.
findingType.info:
This local variable is declared but it is never read. Consider removing it from your code.

For example, consider changing

public void doSomething() {
  int i = 5; // unused
  System.out.println("doing something");
}

to

public void doSomething() {
  System.out.println("doing something");
}

findingType.name: Unused parameter
findingType.shortMessage: This code accepts a parameter then appears to never use it. Avoid passing parameters to methods or constructors and then not using those parameters. Consider removing the parameter.
findingType.info:
Avoid passing parameters to methods or constructors and then not using those parameters.

For example, consider changing

 private void bar(String howdy) {
   System.out.println("bar");
}

to

private void bar() {
   System.out.println("bar");
}

findingType.name: Avoid hardcoded IP addresses
findingType.shortMessage: Avoid using hard-coded IP address
findingType.info:
An application with hard coded IP may become impossible to deploy in some cases. It never hurts to externalize IP addresses.

public class Foo {
  private final String ip = "127.0.0.1"; // This is a bad idea !
  ...
}

findingType.name: Check return values from ResultSet method calls
findingType.shortMessage: This code appears to ignore the the return value from a call on a ResultSet method. The code should deal with this return value explicitly to handle problems.
findingType.info:
Always check the return value from calling ResultSet.{next,previous,first,last}. If the return value is false, the code should deal with it explicitly.

For example, the below code

// Bad! ignores what 'next()' returns
Statement stat = conn.createStatement();
ResultSet rst  = stat.executeQuery("SELECT name FROM person");
rst.next();  // what if it returns 'false'?
String firstName = rst.getString(1);

should be changed to

Statement stat = conn.createStatement();
ResultSet rst  = stat.executeQuery("SELECT name FROM person");
if (rst.next()) {
  String firstName = rst.getString(1);
} else {
  // here you deal with the error...at least log it and recover
}

findingType.name: Avoid using short
findingType.shortMessage: Avoid using the short type as it can adversely impact the performance of your code.
findingType.info:
Java uses the short type to reduce memory usage, not to optimize calculation. On the contrary, the JVM does not has any arithmetic capabilities with the short type, so it must convert the short into int, then do the proper calculation and then convert int back to short. Therefore, use of the short type may actually be slower than using int.

public class UsingShort {
  private short doNotUseShort = 0;

  public UsingShort() {
    short shouldNotBeUsed = 1;
    doNotUseShort += shouldNotBeUsed;
  }
}

findingType.name: Avoid using volatile fields
findingType.shortMessage: Avoid using volatile fields.
findingType.info:
The volatile keyword is generally used to fine tune a concurrent Java application, and therefore, requires a expert knowledge of the Java Memory Model. Moreover, it is often misused. Therefore, consider carefully if this use of the volatile keyword is correct.

It is also recommended to consider if the use of one of the atomic classes from util.concurrent is a better implementation choice. For example, the below code

public class ThrDeux {
  private volatile int counter = 1;
  private volatile String var = "Hi";
}

could be changed to

import java.util.concurrent.atomic.AtomicInteger;
import java.util.concurrent.atomic.AtomicReference;

public class ThrDeux {
  private final AtomicInteger counter = new AtomicInteger(1);
  private final AtomicReference<String> var = new AtomicReference<String>("Hi");
}

findingType.name: Avoid using native code (JNI)
findingType.shortMessage: Avoid using native code. Try to reimplement so that JNI is not needed.
findingType.info: The Java language allows for a wide range of functionality, so it should be very rare to have to rely on non-Java code, and in particular, on the Java Native Interface (JNI). Since the use of JNI makes an application less portable, and harder to maintain, it is not recommended.

findingType.name: Avoid changing class/method accessibility at runtime
findingType.shortMessage: Avoid changing class/method accessibility at runtime.
findingType.info:
Methods in java.lang.reflect, such as getDeclaredConstructors(), getDeclaredConstructor(Class[]) and setAccessible(), allow someone to alter, at runtime, the accessibility of fields, classes, or methods, even if they are declared to be private.

import java.lang.reflect.AccessibleObject;
import java.lang.reflect.Method;
import java.security.PrivilegedAction;

public class Violation {
  public void invalidCallsInMethod() throws SecurityException, NoSuchMethodException {
    // Possible call to forbidden getDeclaredConstructors
    Class[] arrayOfClass = new Class[1];
    this.getClass().getDeclaredConstructors();
    this.getClass().getDeclaredConstructor(arrayOfClass);
    Class clazz = this.getClass();
    clazz.getDeclaredConstructor(arrayOfClass);
    clazz.getDeclaredConstructors();

    // Possible call to forbidden setAccessible
    clazz.getMethod("", arrayOfClass).setAccessible(false);
    AccessibleObject.setAccessible(null, false);
    Method.setAccessible(null, false);
    Method[] methodsArray = clazz.getMethods();
    int nbMethod;
    for ( nbMethod = 0; nbMethod < methodsArray.length; nbMethod++ ) {
      methodsArray[nbMethod].setAccessible(false);
    }

    // Possible call to forbidden PrivilegedAction
    PrivilegedAction priv = (PrivilegedAction) new Object(); priv.run();
  }
}

There are legitimate specialized uses of these methods, but observer caution that a security risk is not being introduced into your system if their use is allowed.

findingType.name: Class with only private constructors should be final
findingType.shortMessage: A class which only has private constructors should be declared final.
findingType.info:
A class with only private constructors should be final, unless the private constructor is called by a inner class. The code below

public class Foo {
  private Foo() { ... }
  // no other constructors or inner classes
  ...
}

could be changed to

public final class Foo {
  private Foo() { ... }
  // no other constructors or inner classes
  ...
}

findingType.name: Empty method in abstract class should be abstract
findingType.shortMessage: Consider if an empty method in an abstract class should be abstract.
findingType.info:
An empty method in an abstract class should instead be abstract, as developer may rely on this empty implementation, rather than code an appropriate one. The code below

public abstract class ShouldBeAbstract {
  public Object couldBeAbstract() {
    return null;
  }
  public void couldBeAbstractToo() {
  }
}

could be changed to

public abstract class ShouldBeAbstract {
  public abstract Object couldBeAbstract();
  public abstract void couldBeAbstractToo();
}

One exception to this rule of thumb is if the class is providing a reasonable default behavior that is to do nothing.

findingType.name: Too many static imports
findingType.shortMessage: Too many static imports may lead to unmaintainable code.
findingType.info:
If you overuse the static import feature it can make your program unreadable and unmaintainable. This feature pollutes the namespace with all the imported static members. Readers of your code (including you, a few months after you wrote it) will not know which class a static member comes from (Sun 1.5 Language Guide).

import static Lennon;
import static Ringo;
import static George;
import static Paul;
import static Yoko; // Too much !

findingType.name: Static EJB fields should be final
findingType.shortMessage: EJB's shouldn't have non-final static fields. This can cause bugs when the container distributes the application across several JREs.
findingType.info: According to the J2EE specification (reference section 21.1.2 of the EJB 3.0 Specification), an EJB should not have any static fields with write access. However, static read-only fields are allowed. This ensures proper behavior, especially when instances are distributed by the container across several JREs.

findingType.name: Do not use threads in a J2EE web application
findingType.shortMessage: To be J2EE-compliant, a web application should not use any threads.
findingType.info: The J2EE specification explicitly forbids the use of threads within a container-based application (reference section 21.1.2 of the EJB 3.0 Specification)

findingType.name: Avoid using multiple unary operators
findingType.shortMessage: Avoid using multiple unary operators to make your code clearer.
findingType.info:
Using multiple unary operators may be a bug. It can also be confusing. Check that the usage is not a bug and consider simplifying the expression.

// These are typo bugs, or at best needlessly complex and confusing:
int i = - -1;
int j = + - +1;
int z = ~~2;
boolean b = !!true;
boolean c = !!!true;

// These are better:
int i = 1;
int j = -1;
int z = 2;
boolean b = true;
boolean c = false;

// And these just make your brain hurt:
int i = ~-2;
int j = -~7;

findingType.name: Avoid classes with too many methods
findingType.shortMessage: A class with too many methods may indicate poor object-oriented design.
findingType.info: A class with too many methods is probably a good prospect for refactoring in order to reduce its complexity and find a way to have more fine grained objects.

findingType.name: No abstract methods in an abstract class
findingType.shortMessage: No abstract methods in abstract class, consider other approaches to prevent instantiation.
findingType.info:
If the abstract class does not provides any methods, it may be just a data container that is not to be instantiated. In this case, it's probably better to use a private or a protected constructor in order to prevent instantiation than make the class misleadingly abstract.

public abstract class Foo {
  void int method1() { ... }
  void int method2() { ... }
  // consider using abstract methods or removing
  // the abstract modifier and adding protected constructors
}

findingType.name: Avoid switch statements with only a few branches
findingType.shortMessage: Avoid switch statements with only a few branches. Use an if statement instead.
findingType.info:
Switch statements are designed complex branches, and allow branches to share treatment. Using a switch for only two branches is ill advised, as switches are not as easy to understand as if statements.

public void bar() {
  switch (condition) {
  case ONE:
    // do something
    break;
  default:
    // do something
    break; // not enough for a 'switch', a simple 'if' would be more appropriate
  }
}

In this case, it's most likely is a good idea to use a if statement instead, at least to increase code readability.

findingType.name: Avoid throwing exceptions in finally clauses
findingType.shortMessage: Avoid throwing exceptions in finally clauses. It is confusing and may mask exceptions or code defects.
findingType.info:
Throwing exceptions in a finally block is confusing. It may mask exceptions or a code defect. Further, it may render code cleanup unstable.

public void bar() {
  try {
    // Here do some stuff
  } catch( Exception e) {
    // Handling the issue
  } finally {
    // is this really a good idea ?
    throw new Exception();
  }
}

It is highly recommended to redesign the implementation of this code.

findingType.name: Avoid StringBuffer-typed fields
findingType.shortMessage: Avoid keeping StringBuffer objects as a field.
findingType.info: StringBuffer objects can grow quite a lot, and can become a source of memory leaks (if the owning class has a long life time).

findingType.name: Ignored tool artifacts
findingType.shortMessage: Findings in this finding type can be ignored.
findingType.info: This is special finding type that contains all tool artifacts that Sierra ignores. The tool artifact may be ignored if another tool has a superior analysis or if it is a tool diagnostic report.
